column2: LEAD: The Mets gathered in Shea Stadium yesterday for the first time since they won the World Series five months ago, and said they were ready to open the season there today without conceding anything, despite the stunning losses of Dwight Gooden and Roger McDowell.

LEAD: A Federal jury today acquitted a City Councilman and his aide of three counts but deadlocked on 11 others in an indictment alleging that the men tried to extort $1 million from a riverfront developer.
LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3*TELEBYTE TECHNOLOGY (OTC) Year to Dec 31 1986 1985 Sales 4,044,667 3,142,089 Net loss 197,779 245,190 Shares outst 1,938,672 1,937,963

LEAD: After years of nomadic or cramped existence, some of New York City's best-known performers - Twyla Tharp, the Big Apple Circus and Dance Theater Workshop - are competing with one another for an extraordinary, if unlikely, new home: the old ferry house at the foot of Whitehall Street.

LEAD: Major league umpires were on the job yesterday, working for about 25 percent more money than they earned on opening day last year. The pay increase - and their presence on the field - resulted from an all-night negotiating session that produced an agreement two hours before the first scheduled game.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3*MBS TEXTBOOK EXCHANGE Qtr to Feb 28 1987 1986 Sales 9,123,000 8,251,000 Net inc 589,000 361,000 6mo sales 16,300,000 14,400,000 Net inc 663,000 365,000 The company went public in February.
LEAD: The Exxon Capital Corporation is offering about $432.3 million of zero coupon bonds, with maturities running from 1990 to 2001, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

LEAD: Cable-less Yankee fans in the outer boroughs had cause to kick their sets anew yesterday, when the team's opener, no less, was televised locally only by SportsChannel. The game was the first of 100 allocated by the Yankees to cable this year, in a reversal of the portioning the last two seasons, when cable got just 40 games and WPIX got 100.
LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3*INTERNATIONAL REMOTE IMAGNG SYSTEMS INC (OTC) Year to Dec 31 1986 1985 Revenue 3,806,000 1,828,000 Net loss 1,271,000 1,904,000

LEAD: Pope John Paul II today began a six-day visit to Argentina, where he offered a kindly lecture on political responsibilities to the leaders of this young democracy.

LEAD: IN the first minutes of Martin Halpern's play ''Day Six,'' Len Cariou unleashes an oratorical torrent in which the actor-singer's musical and dramatic skills fuse into a moment of thunderous intensity. Improvising an inspirational tirade on the sin of pride, he condemns ''proud blaspheming cynics,'' who he warns are joining sides with Satan.

LEAD: A leading Palestinian academic was found guilty of incitement today by an Israeli military court for writing in an English-language newsletter of a West Bank university that Palestinians should reject and resist the Israeli occupation.
LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3*SMARTCARD INTERNATIONAL (OTC) Year to Dec 31 1986 1985 Revenue 252,374 25,082 Net loss 1,025,068 330,903

LEAD: Scali, McCabe, Sloves will be making the television advertising for the Toys ''R'' Us retail chain of more than 300 stores. The previous agency was Grey Advertising, which resigned the account a month or so ago.

LEAD: The fight between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company moves back into the Texas court system now, with both companies saying today that they want to find a way for Texaco to secure its potential liability without crippling itself.
LEAD: * Herbert A. Miller named senior vice president, director of broadcast production at FCB/Leber Katz Partners.

LEAD: Protesters marched through East Jerusalem today in support of a hunger strike by Palestinian prison inmates.
LEAD: * British Telecommunications, London, announced the creation of British Telecom Inc. as its American subsidiary.

LEAD: It is often said, by President Reagan among others, that Mikhail Gorbachev needs an arms control agreement for economic reasons. If limits were put on the arms race, the Soviet Union could devote more resources and talent to solving the severe problems of its civilian economy.
LEAD: A 26-year-old man who fled from the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens last month has surrendered to the authorities in California, the Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday.
LEAD: Once again, the Islanders and the Capitals, who can't seem to get out of each other's way when the playoffs come around, are eyeing each other familiarly.
LEAD: Marvelous Marvin Hagler was robbed, he contended in the news conference held about an hour after he lost his World Boxing Council middleweight championship title tonight in a split decision.

LEAD: The Minneapolis Grain Exchange began trading futures yesterday in high-fructose corn syrup, a sweetener used in soft-drink and food processing.

LEAD: A WAR of words has broken out between the Department of Education and the General Accounting Office, an oversight agency created by Congress. The issue is bilingual education and the dispute centers on a report, ''Bilingual Education: A New Look at the Research Evidence,'' which the agency produced at the request of the chairman of the House Committee on Education and

LEAD: THE ''writing process'' - the ideas that ferment in the mind before pen hits paper - has long been considered a mystery. So students are usually taught mechanics: grammar, syntax, usage, spelling. But teachers who emphasize mechanics ignore 99 percent of the process and perform a disservice to students, according to David S.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would temporarily lay off more than 6,200 workers as it converts assembly plants to make new models and adjusts its production to meet slumping auto sales.
LEAD: President Chaim Herzog began the first trip to West Germany by an Israeli head of state today, visiting the bleak memorial at the site of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp.

LEAD: The Kitchen, more formally known as the Kitchen Center for Video, Music, Dance, Performance and Film, announced yesterday that it had bought its current home, a building at 512 West 19th Street from the Dia Art Foundation for $1.4 million.

LEAD: As California struggles to relieve crowding in its prisons, a study by the State Attorney General's office found that more than one of every three young men in California was arrested at least once from 1974 through 1985.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: JUST when you need help most, your accountant may be at the breaking point.

LEAD: THE nearby explosion of a star and a lucky succession of scientific accidents are combining to create a new branch of astronomy, in which new instruments sensitive to streams of neutrino particles could serve as the counterparts of light-gathering telescopes.

LEAD: THE Brooklyn Philharmonic under Lukas Foss brought us two contemporary pieces of unfailing graciousness Sunday afternoon. This Academy of Music event ended with Brahms's much-played First Symphony, but it began with delicacies from England and America. The first was Oliver Knussen's ''Music for a Puppet Court,'' and the second Samuel Barber's Violin

LEAD: Representative Jack Kemp, officially a candidate for President, leaving Capitol Hill for Buffalo and other stops yesterday, the first day of his national campaign. Family members touring with the new candidate included his wife, Joanne, and daughter Jennifer. Page A22. (NYT/Paul Hosefros)

LEAD: Eleanor Burke Leacock, a professor of anthropology at City College of the City University of New York, died of a stroke Thursday at the Straub Medical Center Hospital in Honolulu. She was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: As the waters of the Schoharie Creek receded this morning, nearby residents gathered to gape at wreckage pulled from the muddy swirl, and cars, buses and 18-wheel trailer trucks diverted from the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway started crawling along their narrow, normally quiet roads.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A Queens lawyer who has been described as a ''power broker'' for the late Donald R. Manes was sentenced yesterday to five years in Federal prison, given five more years on probation and ordered to pay nearly $413,500 in fines and restitution.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A study by a team of South African doctors says that detainees have been victims of physical and mental abuse.

LEAD: William Bowers, a screenwriter who received Academy Award nominations for his scripts for ''The Gunfighter'' (1950) and ''The Sheepman'' (1958), died of respiratory failure March 27 at the Woodland Hills Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 71 years old.
LEAD: The conventional wisdom was that boxing comebacks like Sugar Ray Leonard's were doomed to failure.

LEAD: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on Namibia at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Committee on Natural Resources - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

LEAD: From Manhattan to Rochester, hundreds of New Yorkers have been dreaming of flying high in an illegal pyramid scheme called the airplane game. But law-enforcement officials warn that they may lose the $1,500 to $2,500 they have invested in hopes of winning $10,000 or more.

LEAD: In the bond market, where worries about the Pennzoil Company's lawsuit had already reduced prices of the bonds of Texaco Inc., the Supreme Court ruling yesterday led to another sharp drop in Texaco issues.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3*NEWPARK RESOURCES INC (NYSE) Year to Dec 31 1986 1985 Revenue 34,800,000 84,800,000 Net inc b31,800,000 c135,400,000 Share earns 2.14 - b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5.5 million and an extraordinary credit of $66.4 million on debt restructuring.

LEAD: A picture yesterday with a biographical sketch of Kim Young Sam, a critic of the South Korean Government, was published in error. It actually showed another critic, Kim Dae Jung. A second picture of Kim Dae Jung also appeared, correctly, with the sketch of him.

LEAD: The area winners of the Grand National Team Championship, which began at the club level in New York City and on Long Island five months ago, are Saul Bronstein, George Tornay, Mike Engel, August Boehm and John Roberts, all of Manhattan, and Tom Smith of Greenwich, Conn.
LEAD: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone called on the Reagan Administration today to rescind the tariffs it plans to impose this month on selected electronic products from Japan.

LEAD: President Reagan will appoint M. Peter McPherson, the Administrator of the Agency for International Development, to succeed Richard G. Darman as Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, Administration sources said yesterday. An announcement is likely today, they said.
LEAD: Whether the first night of prime-time programming for the Fox Broadcasting Company was a success depends on how one interprets the overnight figures.

LEAD: Tom Webster, the Rangers' head coach, had a re-evaluation yesterday of the ear infection that has kept him from coaching full-time. He was told that the infection still exists and he was given a new medication. Webster will be examined again in two weeks, at which time the Rangers may be forced to make a decision regarding his future.

LEAD: For the first time in his 27 years as an educator, Charles McIlwain played hooky today, closing the principal's office at the Centennial Elementary School here and heading to the city for Julius Erving's last game at Madison Square Garden.
LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3*SKIPPER'S INC (OTC) Qtr to March 22 1987 1986 Revenue 17,693,000 18,193,000 Net inc 412,000 242,000 Share earns .15 .09 Shares outst 2,730,715 2,727,097

LEAD: ALICE TULLY HALL, which has a medium-sized seating capacity, looked only about two-thirds full for Sunday afternoon's duo piano concert by Katia and Marielle Labeque, whom this writer had always supposed to be deliriously popular. Was the presence of Bartok on the program poison for their public? Or have they perhaps been overexposed locally?
LEAD: Governor Cuomo stepped up his criticism of the State Legislature today amid new indications that it was prepared to deny funds for a commission he has formed to investigate government ethics.

LEAD: Back home after his unsuccessful shopping trip, Jack Morris returned to his old, and new, place of work. Still in the uniform of the Detroit Tigers, an outfit Morris sought to change during the winter, the pitcher lost a game and re-established a point.

LEAD: Twelve hours before a bridge over the Schoharie Creek collapsed Sunday on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, the rush of water through a dam 40 miles upstream hit a ''historic high,'' a vice president of the New York Power Authority said yesterday.

LEAD: Tony Hrkac of the University of North Dakota, named the outstanding college hockey player in the country this season, was signed yesterday by the St. Louis Blues. Hrkac, 21, said he decided early last week that he was going to skip his last two years of eligibility. Hrkac, a center, led North Dakota to the National Collegiate Athletic Association title this season.

LEAD: Unemployment in the European Community dipped in February to 11.7 percent of the civilian work force, from a record 11.8 percent the month before, the community said today. The number of jobless people dropped by slightly more than 100,000, to 17 million, the community's statistics office said in its monthly labor market report.

LEAD: Just as Mayor Harold Washington appeared to be coasting easily toward re-election here Tuesday in a crowded field, the sudden withdrawal of a major challenger has put the race on an uncertain turn.
LEAD: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney responded with obvious pleasure today to President Reagan's statement that he would consider an acid rain agreement between Canada and the United States.

LEAD: L. Michael Dowling, who had been president of Ogilvy & Mather Public Affairs in Washington, has gone west to head the newly formed Ogilvy & Mather Public Relations/West in Los Angeles, which is made up of that office and one in San Francisco, as well as the Ogilvy & Mather/Cole & Weber Public Relations offices in Seattle and Portland.
LEAD: Some of Texaco's suppliers said today that they were growing increasingly concerned that the nation's third-largest oil company would seek protection from creditors in bankruptcy court.

LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today announced the appointment of a new director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, naming a longtime bureau employee, J. Michael Quinlan.

LEAD: The Sanyo Electric Company of Japan said today that it would market a telephone that can be instructed to accept calls only from certain numbers. A Sanyo official, Shigehiko Masuda, said that when the ''selection'' system was turned on, callers reaching the phone would be asked to dial the last four digits of their own phone numbers.

LEAD: ''MAN-MADE FAMINE'' means what the title says; food shortages in Africa are caused by men, individual men, not men in the sense of mankind. The one-hour documentary at 11 o'clock tonight, part of Channel 13's ''Intercom'' series, presents a feminist view of famine.

LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc., a leading manufacturer of computer work stations based in Mountain View, Calif., has lowered the price of its entry-level model, the Sun-3/50M, to $4,995, from $7,900. The move puts Sun more directly in competition with new personal computers for technical users, including those from Apple Computer Inc.
LEAD: Japan's moves to cut the production of computer chips could lead to a shortage of the vital semiconductors, some computer and semiconductor industry executives said today.

LEAD: Antoni Niemczak of Poland, the runner-up in the 1986 New York City Marathon who later was disqualified when a drug test detected the use of a steroid, will not receive any prize money, Fred Lebow, the race's director, said yesterday. The second-place prize money of $25,000 had been withheld since the Nov.

LEAD: ONE did not have to be at the Embassy Suites Hotel in Phoenix yesterday as members of the Phoenix Advertising Club listened to the guest luncheon speaker to know they were at the edge of their seats.
LEAD: For Chong Yong Hi, a 35-year-old housewife, her country's phenomenal economic growth means an apartment of her own after years of scrimping and living five to a room.

LEAD: Relief supplies were allowed into the Palestinian district of Shatila in southern Beirut today, the first big shipment since the siege of the area by Shiite Moslem militiamen began five months ago.

LEAD: The Cannon Group said it would sell its 50 percent interest in HBO/ Cannon Home Video to Time Inc.'s Home Box Office, its partner in the venture. Analysts said the deal, valued at $20 million, would give the financially troubled Cannon enough capital to continue its curtailed production schedule.

LEAD: Tektronix Inc., a manufacturer of electronic measurement and test equipment based in Beaverton, Ore., said it had agreed to buy about 2.1 million shares of its common stock from the beneficiaries of Howard Vollum, a company founder who died in February. The price is $35.875 a share, or about $75 million.

LEAD: A federally required inspection of the bridge that collapsed Sunday morning on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway did not cover crucial underwater portions of the structure, state authorities said today.

LEAD: The Trans-American Natural Gas Corporation filed a $100 million lawsuit in Federal court, charging the Coastal Corporation and its chairman, Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., with antitrust violations.

LEAD: They came to pay tribute to the tall, lanky kid from Long Island who went on to change the way basketball is played, adding a brand of personal flash that has spawned an entire generation of acrobatic specialists.

LEAD: The Army is setting up a program with a toll-free telephone number that is intended to help catch spies, discover possible security risks and train soldiers to identify both, Army officials said today.

LEAD: At his current pace - 36.67 points on 27.84 field goals attempted per game - Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls will finish the regular season a week from Friday with not only a higher scoring average but also more shots tried than anyone else in N.B.A. history except Wilt Chamberlain. LEAD: A report in the Business People column yesterday listed one company erroneously among those that are leaders in vision care. The SmithKline Beckman Corporation's Allergan unit belongs in the group, but not Becton, Dickinson & Company.
LEAD: Federal investigators questioned Mayor Koch for more than an hour last Friday about Bess Myerson and her companion, Carl A. Capasso, the Mayor said last night.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3*BIW CABLE SYSTEMS INC (OTC) Qtr to Dec 31 1986 1985 Sales 8,963,097 12,626,897 Net loss 3,395,933 318,225 Yr sales 44,374,197 48,748,867 Net loss b6,613,317 c49,421 Share earns - .02 b-Includes a $1.8 million writedown of inventories taken in the first quarter.
LEAD: Scattered outbreaks of violence were reported today as Egyptians voted to elect a national legislature.

LEAD: The Klooster International Tournament in Ter Apel, the Netherlands, ended in a tie for first place among the Dutch grandmasters Hans Ree and John Van der Wiel and the West German grandmaster Eric Lobron. Each scored 3 1/2-1 1/2 in the six-man round robin celebrating the 50th anniversary of the Ter Apel Chess Club.

LEAD: Peter Taylor was named winner today of the Ritz-Hemingway award, one of the richest literary prizes in the world, for his novel ''A Summons to Memphis,'' a family drama set in the author's native Tennessee.

LEAD: The Conservative Coalition, which consists largely of Republicans, is trying to raise money for its political action committee by attacking the National Republican Senatorial Committee and the bonuses it paid officers and consultants last year.
LEAD: Don King and Bob Arum, the rival promoters, engaged in a pushing and shoving match at the end of the Sugar Ray Leonard-Marvelous Marvin Hagler middleweight title fight last night.

LEAD: When Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada first met President Reagan in 1985, the President promised to study acid rain and the three million tons of pollutants the United States disgorges north to Canada each year.

LEAD: Jan Cado, a Czechoslovak triple jumper who competed in last month's world indoor track and field championships in Indianapolis, has defected to the United States, according to a published report. Cado finished fourth in the European Indoor Championships in February with a distance of 55 feet 7 3/4 inches and was 10th in the world championships with a distance of 53-7.

LEAD: WITH its announcements in New York and Miami Beach last week, I.B.M. finally put an end to many months of speculation about its new family of personal computers. Now, in turn, there will be many months of speculation about what it all means.

LEAD: Three members of the Devils -Pat Verbeek and Kirk Muller, both forwards, and Bruce Driver, a defenseman - were named to the Team Canada roster for the World Hockey Championship tournament, which begins April 17 in Vienna. Driver, however, has a sore shoulder and will need a checkup before it is determined whether he will be able to play.

LEAD: In a major setback to Texaco Inc.'s battle for survival, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a Federal District Court should not have excused the company from posting a bond of more than $10 billion while it appealed a damage award that the Pennzoil Company won against Texaco in 1985.

LEAD: Q. Is it possible to make fuel from old tires, and if so how? A. Several recycling companies have developed procedures for turning scrap tires into high-energy fuel for use in generating electricity. For example, Waste Recovery Inc. of Dallas shreads worn out tires into small pieces about two inches square.
LEAD: ''Pediatric AIDS will soon be everybody's problem.'' - Dr. C. Everett Koop, the Surgeon General of the United States. [ A23:3. ]

LEAD: It almost seemed eerie, as if this was a game being played in the middle of September, not early April. They could have been two teams huddled near first place, caught in the midst of a decisive and emotional stretch run. But there was a persistent chill throughout the day, and the rain and storm clouds that had settled over the weekend refused to quietly fade away.

LEAD: Albany's discussions on how to forgo the bonanza expected from a change in Federal tax law now bear fruit: a long-term plan to reduce state income taxes. The plan was inspired by a desire to make the state more competitive with its neighbors in keeping and wooing business. It's a constructive compromise, but improving competitiveness does not depend on low taxes alone.
LEAD: Lupe Aquino, a junior middleweight from Santa Paula, Calif., defeated Davey Moore of the Bronx tonight in a bout before the Sugar Ray Leonard-Marvelous Marvin Hagler fight.

LEAD: Although most of its business is at Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, Faberge has assigned the introduction of its McGregor line of cologne and aftershave for men to Smith/ Greenland. The budget, according to the agency, will be from $2 million to $3 million.

LEAD: Promising to support a weapons shield in space, ''freedom fighters'' abroad, free enterprise in the marketplace and traditional family values at home, Representative Jack F. Kemp announced his Presidential candidacy today.

LEAD: WITH all its faults, the Stone Age may have had its points. For one thing, people hadn't yet learned the knack of smelting ore and thereby creating junkyards; whatever it was that brought down the Neanderthals, metal pollution could hardly have played much part.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation said yesterday that it expects to write off $294 million in the first quarter to reflect costs from two nuclear power plants. As a result, the company said, it expects a loss for the quarter, in contrast to a profit a year earlier of $79.6 million.

LEAD: Grace Paley is to appear in a free reading Friday at 12:15 P.M. in the ground floor auditorium at Chase Manhattan Plaza, Pine Street, just east of Nassau Street. Ms. Paley is to read from unpublished works.
LEAD: The New York City Transit Authority has revised its policy on drugs, to limit the circumstances under which 45,000 employees can be ordered to take drug tests.

LEAD: In a stunning display of boxing artistry and perseverance, Sugar Ray Leonard, with just one fight in five years, scored a 12-round split decision over Marvelous Marvin Hagler to win the World Boxing Council's middleweight championship tonight at the Caesars Palace outdoor arena.

LEAD: About a month ago, Dave Poulin was asked to select the team he would prefer to play in the opening round of the playoffs. ''Why bother?'' the Philadelphia Flyers' center said. ''You know it's going to be the Rangers.''
LEAD: Executives at CBS News decided yesterday to suspend the pay of Andy Rooney, the ''60 Minutes'' commentator who has been outspoken in his criticism of network management.
LEAD: Question: How many press secretaries does it take to change a light bulb?

LEAD: As thousands of Government troops swept northern El Salvador over the weekend seeking leftist rebels who destroyed one of the army's most important bases last week, the guerrillas themselves nonchalantly held a town meeting in this village just four miles from the devastated fort.

LEAD: Bob Arum was on the crowded platform at the weigh-in in the auditorium at Caesars Palace this morning, and he was hollering and waving his arms at one of his assistants. ''Where's Marvin?'' Arum shouted. ''Still taking the exam,'' came the reply.

LEAD: The Supreme Court, rejecting an emergency request by a Western Airlines union, refused to interfere with the $860 million merger of Western and Delta Air Lines. The court, without any recorded dissent, let stand an order issued last Wednesday by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor that cleared the way for the merger.

LEAD: Jail Term for Corruption Richard L. Rubin, once a State Assembly aide and top Queens Democrat, was sentenced to five years in prison for payroll fraud. Page B1. Dow Average Over 2,400 The Dow Jones industrial average exceeded 2,400 for the first time, rising 15.20 points, to 2,405.54, after soaring nearly 70 points on Friday.

LEAD: President Reagan said today that he had ''agreed to consider'' a proposal by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney that Canada and the United States negotiate a ''bilateral accord'' controlling acid rain.

LEAD: South Korean dissidents have recently stepped up their lobbying campaign in the United States, urging American Congressmen to exert political pressure on President Chun Doo Hwan to accept a particular brand of democracy.

LEAD: Former Gov. Richard Snelling said today he does not plan to be a candidate for the United States Senate next year. He had indicated after his 1986 defeat that he might run again in 1988 if Senator Robert Stafford, a Republican, retired.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo announced today that he has vetoed legislation that would have restored the death penalty in New York. Mr. Cuomo, who vetoed the measure Friday, said that to bring back the electric chair would be to fight ''evil with evil.'' It is the 11th consecutive year that legislation to restore the death penalty in New York has been vetoed.

LEAD: James H. Webb Jr., the Reagan Administration's nominee to replace John F. Lehman Jr. as Navy Secretary, said today he still had doubts about the presence of women as midshipmen at the Naval Academy.

LEAD: THE first half-hour of trading on the Big Board is of growing significance, because it captures the impact of a growing volume of orders from Japan and Europe. Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average marched onto new high ground in the 30 minutes after its 9:30 A.M. opening.

LEAD: Reacting to scandals that have engulfed the Democratic Party in New York City, top state Democratic leaders yesterday recommended an unprecedented code of ethics for state, county, town and village party leaders.
LEAD: The Eaton Corporation said yesterday that it had named Charles E. Barron, a longtime executive with the General Electric Company, as president of its military electronics operations.

LEAD: About 400 prospective jurors reported to a basketball and livestock arena this morning for the second start of the trial of three Colombian nationals accused of the murder of a key Government drug witness.

LEAD: THE Pentagon is eyeing NASA's proposed space station for a bevy of projects and missions that would propel the Department of Defense into a new era of space operations in the 21st century. The military's vision, while offering a new source of political support for the embattled space agency, also promises to heat the simmering controversy over plans for a manned station in space.

LEAD: Showtime, the pay-cable television channel, has ordered 54 new episodes of its hit comedy series, ''It's Garry Shandling's Show,'' to be broadcast over the next three years. This order is the largest in Showtime's history and one of the largest orders for a series in the history of television.
LEAD: A man and a woman were seriously injured when they accidentally fell eight floors down a freight elevator shaft in a Times Square welfare hotel last night, the police said.

LEAD: Bruce Laingen, who spent 444 days as a hostage of Iranian revolutionaries in 1979-80, finds his first duty after retirement from the State Department curiously reminiscent of part of his diplomatic career. The former charge d'affaires in Teheran is spending much of his time at the department's career counseling center, which happens to be situated in Annex 20, the former Iranian Embassy on Massachusetts Avenue that was seized by the United States in retaliation for Iran's taking of the American Embassy.

LEAD: With no state budget in place six days after the deadline, the State Comptroller reported today that New York would not be able to meet on time $1.3 billion in payments to local school districts.
LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average surpassed 2,400 for the first time in early trading yesterday and finished the day up 15.20 points, at 2,405.54.

LEAD: While President Reagan is engaged in international trade negotiations with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada in Ottawa, members of Congress are approaching the same question on a more limited basis. For what is believed to be the first time, a dozen members of the Northeast-Midwest Congressional Coalition in the House will sit down this morning with a delegation from the Ontario Provincial Legislature to discuss trade on the state-to-province level.

LEAD: Gordon Johncock, a two-time Indianapolis 500 winner who retired in 1985, will attempt a comeback in this year's race, officials at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway announced yesterday. Johncock, 50 years old, will drive a March-Cosworth entered by Gold Racing of Lincoln, Neb., for the May 24 race. He last drove at Indy in 1984, when he finished 25th after a crash on the front straightaway.

LEAD: THE search for summer jobs has begun. The International Business Machines Corporation recently helped start Summer Jobs '87, the New York City area's seventh annual program, as this year's corporate sponsor.
LEAD: James G. Donovan, who was a United States Representative from Manhattan in the 1950's, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 88 years old.

LEAD: South Korea, seeking to avoid more trade friction with the United States, will reduce tariffs on 83 manufactured and farm products by 5 to 20 percentage points July 1, the Finance Ministry said today. The cuts average 6.6 points. The products include television sets, home appliances, beer, lemons, newsprint and automobiles - but not trucks or buses.
LEAD: Calm returned to the credit markets yesterday as bond prices rose modestly and short-term interest rates fell slightly.

LEAD: Wall Street showed a clear preference yesterday for a recapitalization plan proposed on Sunday by Caesars World Inc. over a $28-a-share offer made by Martin T. Sosnoff, the gambling concern's largest shareholder.

LEAD: Much like the most ardent of fans, a number of major league players collect baseball bubble-gum cards themselves. The cards are generally tacked or taped to the player's dressing stall, and each usually has a special meaning to the collector.

LEAD: Any day now, NBC could transmit a devastating signal to the City of New York: an announcement that it is moving out. The move might only be across the Hudson to northern New Jersey, thus inflicting no loss on the economy of the region. Nonetheless, NBC's departure would send a shiver through a city tied to communications, entertainment, financial services and tourism.

LEAD: Silicon atoms, the foundation of today's computer industry, have been captured on film for the first time by photographers and researchers at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. LEAD: SERVING freshly cooked warm or hot preparations on a bed of cold salad greens is a fairly recent practice in the United States, borrowed perhaps from Asian cuisines. Jim Bakker and a top Bakker aide, according to a spokeswoman, Juleen Turnage. Mr. Bakker and the Rev. Richard Dortch resigned from the Pentecostal denomination March 19 and Mr. Bakker also stepped down as president and chairman of PTL, acknowledging a 1980 sexual encounter and payment to ''blackmailers.

LEAD: CINCO DE MAYO, or the Fifth of May, is the day in 1862 when Mexico won a famous battle (but ultimately lost the war) against French invaders near the city of Puebla; closer to home, it is the name of a flamboyant SoHo restaurant that in 1983 unleashed the first salvo in the great guacamole invasion of Manhattan.

LEAD: For nearly three decades, Gershon Mamlak has been dodging the bulldozers of urban renewal. An upholsterer and furniture maker, Mr. Mamlak has been forced to move his business three times since 1958 -each time, stores he was renting were condemned to make way for progress.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, which became the corporate agency for the North American operation of the Sheraton Corporation when the HBM/Creamer, New York, agency was merged into it, has been awarded its first regional product advertising assignment, for the Western region as well as for the Hawaii

LEAD: STAMFORD, Conn., April 4 -Any company that undertakes ''Misalliance'' has to find a style to deal with the play's unbalanced design. The plot is close to invisible and what action there is - a plane crash, the appearance of a man with a gun - occurs in the second half. The first hour is devoted to what George Bernard Shaw called conversation, a brilliant airing of most of his favorite themes.
LEAD: IT makes for a rather expensive TV commercial if in the process two $48,000 BMW's are intentionally destroyed. But Ammirati & Puris knew what it was doing and, besides, the client didn't mind.
LEAD: Dick Vitale, the TV analyst, when drafted as a territorial pick by the Jersey Jammers of the United States Basketball League: ''I can't play a lick, but I can talk a good game.''

LEAD: In beating Marvelous Marvin Hagler last Monday night, Sugar Ray Leonard was added to this list, now 10 names long, of fighters who have won world titles in three different weight divisions. BOB FITZSIMMONS - middleweight, 1891-97; heavyweight, 1897-99; light heavyweight, 1903-5. TONY CANZONERI - featherweight, 1928; junior welterweight, 1931-32, 1933; lightweight, 1930-33, 1935-36.
LEAD: Max J. Etra, a lawyer and philanthropist, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: Just 15 months ago, policy makers in the industrial countries were scrounging for ways to let the air out of the high-flying dollar without provoking a crash. Against the odds, they've managed the soft landing they hoped for. The dollar, which sagged again yesterday, has now lost more than a third of its exchange value without inducing panic.

LEAD: The Golden Palominos, led by Anton Fier on drums and featuring Syd Straw and Michael Sweet on vocals, Bernie Worrell on keyboards and Jody Harris on guitar, will perform tomorrow at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). Rude Buddha will open at 11 P.M., followed by Richard Lloyd at midnight and the Golden Palominos about 1 A.M.
LEAD: Bess Myerson, accused in a specially commissioned mayoral report of ''serious misconduct,'' resigned yesterday as Mayor Koch's Cultural Affairs Commissioner.
LEAD: Israeli helicopter gunships attacked Palestinian positions today on the outskirts of the port of Sidon in southern Lebanon.

LEAD: The Bankers Trust Company is offering $100 million of 7 percent deposit notes due in 1989 at a price of par through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

LEAD: A scheme that used Avianca Airlines flight engineers and flight attendants to transport illegally $10 million or more in United States currency to Colombia over a 15-month period has been broken up with the indictment of 17 employees of the airline, Federal authorities announced yesterday.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The dollar plunged to new lows against the Japanese yen yesterday, just one day after the United States and its economic allies had pledged to stabilize currency rates.

LEAD: THE gangly young ginkgo trees are about to blossom along 46th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, marking two causes for celebration: The onset of spring and the fruition of a 12-year-old effort to rejuvenate one of the theater district's premier blocks, known as Restaurant Row.

LEAD: There are plenty of ways to lose the Kentucky Derby, but owners have naturally always cherished those that excuse defeat without diminishing their own opinion of their 3-year-olds: the supposedly hard and cuppy Churchill Downs track, the traffic problems caused by the huge fields, the distractions posed by 100,000 noisy spectators.

LEAD: John Silber, president of Boston University since 1971, will begin a six-month leave of absence on July 1, ''in order to read and study and to examine and address the wide range of public issues that will affect higher education and the society at large in the next decade,'' the university announced today.

LEAD: Three bullet holes and the aluminum jacket of a pistol bullet were found yesterday in the gas meter of a South Bronx grocery store where six people died in an explosion Wednesday, the police said.

LEAD: New York lawmakers, under pressure to respond to allegations of payroll abuses in the Legislature, today approved a resolution to prohibit legislative employees from working full time on political campaigns. However, the resolution confirmed the right of those employees to do political work on a part-time basis.
LEAD: Striking workers at the Ford Motor Company plant in Hermosillo said they would return to work Friday, ending a 40-day strike over wages that interrupted production of 1987 Mercury Tracers.

LEAD: Christine Lavin will perform her songs tonight and tomorrow at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street (598-9670), with O. J. Anderson opening. Shows are at 8:30 and 11 P.M.; there is a $6 cover and a two-drink minimum.

LEAD: TENNIS Lloyd Advances Easily: Chris Evert Lloyd advanced to the quarterfinals of the Family Circle Magazine Cup at Hilton Head Island, S.C., yesterday by defeating Debbie Spence, 6-3, 6-0. The match lasted only 54 minutes. The best third-round match was between Claudia Kohde-Kilsch, a 23-year-old West German, and Katerina Maleeva, 17, from Bulgaria.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3*FIRST BANK SYSTEM INC (NYSE) Qtr to March 31 1987 1986 Net inc 57,390,000 46,635,000 Per share .95 .80 The company said it placed $140 million of Brazilian loans and $9 million of Ecuadorian loans on nonaccrual status; it reduced first quarter net by $1.7 million and would reduce full year 1987 earnings by $6.9 million if those loans remain on nonaccrual.

LEAD: THIS season has seen shows of early and recent work by a number of the artists who have emerged under the ''New Image'' painting heading. The latest to be heard from is Lois Lane, whose exhibition at the Willard Gallery (29 East 72d Street) is one of her best. For this particular outing, on view through tomorrow, the artist is exhibiting three earlier paintings (two from 1977, one from 1981), alongside four canvases made this year, and the cumulative effect indicates that she has gone forward by going backward, returning to her earlier work in order to amplify certain devices and themes.
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived here today and walked among thousands of cheering Czechoslovaks who thronged streets that 19 years ago were cleared by invading Soviet tanks.

LEAD: Nicodemo Scarfo, the reputed boss of a Philadelphia-based organized-crime family, and an associate have been indicted for the 1978 killing of a municipal court judge in New Jersey, state officials said today.

LEAD: An anguished deputy sheriff was taken off duty and given psychological counseling after fatally shooting a teen-ager who was using a toy laser gun in mock combat with friends in a dark schoolyard.

LEAD: DURING the summer of 1816, while he was in residence in a villa on the Swiss shore of Lake Geneva, Lord Byron, then 28, was host to his fellow poet Percy Bysshe Shelley, 24; Mary Godwin, Shelley's 19-year-old mistress, whom he later married; Mary's stepsister, Claire Clairmont, 18, who was pregnant with Byron's child, and John William Polidori,
LEAD: Bernard King has spent many hours during the last several days reliving some of his greatest games on videotape in his home.
LEAD: The dollar continued to plunge in Tokyo this morning, hitting a low of 142.90 yen before rallying slightly to close morning trading at 143.15 yen.

LEAD: A major expansion of Medicare to cover the costs of catastrophic illnesses seems highly likely in the wake of a vote today by a key subcommittee of the House of Representatives, approving new health benefits for millions of elderly people.

LEAD: The Department of Transportation accused two airlines today of deceptive scheduling at the Atlanta airport and said it was expanding its investigation of airline scheduling practices to three other major airports.

LEAD: The price of UAL Inc. shares, which soared $6.25 Wednesday, climbed $1.25 yesterday, to $73.25, on reports that Coniston Partners of New York, a money manager, was a major buyer. Coniston would not comment.

LEAD: Lefty Driesell, the former University of Maryland basketball coach who stepped aside after the controversy over the death of Len Bias and took a post as assistant athletic director, has been put in charge of sports information by the school.

LEAD: One of the world's most extensive and valuable privately owned art collections, the Thyssen-Bornemisza collection, could end up permanently in Madrid's Museo del Prado.

LEAD: The First Interstate Bancorp said it would place $320 million in Brazilian loans and $14.5 million in Ecuadorean loans on nonaccrual status. The Brazilian action would cover all medium- and long-term loans on which interest payments have been suspended since February. The Ecuadorean step covers all loans to that country, aside from those guaranteed by the United States
LEAD: TWO LIVES AND A DREAM. By Marguerite Yourcenar. Translated by Walter Kaiser in collaboration with the author. 245 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.

LEAD: A Federal district judge, acting in a reopened case resulting from the original lawsuit that led to desegregation of American schools, ruled today that the Topeka school district did not discriminate against minorities.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 383 money market mutual funds increased $1.39 billion, to $236.77 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 93 institutional funds rose $481.8 million, to $65.65 billion; the 197 general purpose funds rose $625.5 million, to $63.80 billion, and the 93 broker-dealer funds rose $285.3 million, to $107.31 billion.

LEAD: ON Sept. 16, 1925, a very nervous Noel Coward made his Broadway debut in his play ''The Vortex,'' and despite his extreme anxiety, he knew ''to my lasting satisfaction, that I gave the best performance that night that I have ever given in my life.'' After the premiere, he said, ''I was hugged and kissed and crowned with glory, and that night is set apart in my memory, supreme and unspoiled, gratefully and forever.

LEAD: As a conservation measure, many fishing tournaments, especially those involving large saltwater species, are of the so-called catch-and-release variety. Bound more or less by the honor system, competitors radio the time of their catch, its measurement and other details to tourney officials and then throw the fish back.

LEAD: FINANCIAL markets have had their eyes trained all week on the meetings in Washington of the major industrial countries and the policy-making bodies of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in an effort to see what they mean for the future of the dollar, interest rates and security or insecurity of world debt.

LEAD: Most of the key Manhattan streets leading to and from the Brooklyn Bridge were reopened last night, two days after falling masonry from the top of the Municipal Building had forced their closing.

LEAD: Most discussions of the music of Ives bear down heavily on his prodigal use of quotation and it is true that in a work such as the Symphony No. 2 he seems to be trying to bring the ancient technique of pastiche to new levels of incongruity. However, listening last evening to the New York Philharmonic's superlative performance of the piece under Leonard Bernstein one was struck more forcibly by the artistic unity that Ives achieved than by the diversity of his materials.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.
LEAD: Al Campanis is an honorable man, so are all the white baseball club owners and executives, all honorable men.

LEAD: In past years, Lynbrook High School had always been knocked out in preliminary rounds of WLIW Channel 21's quiz show, ''Brainstormers.'' ''We never even made it to the televised rounds,'' said the coach, Mimi Butler, a guidance counselor.

LEAD: James H. Webb, who won Senate confirmation yesterday to succeed John L. Lehman Jr. as Secretary of the Navy, got the usual questions about who and what he is as he went through confirmation hearings. In the for-what-it's-worth department, Pravda, the Soviet newspaper, thinks it has some of the answers.
LEAD: A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted three senior Wall Street traders who had been arrested in February on charges of insider trading.

LEAD: Clearing the way for a compromise on the most contentious issue of this legislative session, Joseph A. Califano Jr. said today that he would be willing to step down as chairman of a commission appointed by the Governor to investigate possible unethical conduct in New York government.

LEAD: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel concluded three days of talks with Soviet officials here today, and he described the talks as ''the first serious and direct dialogue'' between the two nations.

LEAD: Jane Coop, a Canadian pianinst, will present a program of works by Mozart, Brahms, Chopin and Jean Coulthard, a Canadian composer, at the 92nd Street Y Sunday afternoon at 3. Admission is $7.50 to $10; information: 427-4410.

LEAD: FEAR not the 1987 Whitney Biennial. Instead of the rowdy installations of TODT and Group Material, we now have the Conceptual precision of Joseph Kosuth. Instead of the pop figures of Kenny Scharf - remember him? -running amok over telephone booths and restrooms, we now have a sober, earth-colored, abstract mural of Sol LeWitt in the basement.

LEAD: KEN RUSSELL'S ''Gothic'' (review on page C16) is a horror story with phantoms that might have sprung from the opium-clouded half-crazed minds of a group of 19th-century British writers, including two of England's greatest poets, Percy Bysshe Shelley and Lord Byron. Ken Russell, another English artist, has tried to re-create on film a stormy night in Lord Byron's mansion in Switzerland, in which a group of friends starts to tell one another ghost stories and then decides to create a ghost - each concentrating on bringing his worst fear to life.

LEAD: A member of a Chinatown gang whose sister was kidnapped and killed last year was shot on a crowded street in lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon, the police said. A 6-year-old girl was also wounded.

LEAD: ROBERT DE BELDER, a retired diamond dealer who lives near Antwerp, Belgium, assembled over 30 years one of the finest collections of botanical color-plate books in private hands -holdings that Sotheby's in London is to auction April 27 and 28. The 388 volumes include many of the monuments of botanical illustration, dating from 1600 to 1900, that document the evolution of botanical art.
LEAD: The Presidential campaigns of two House leaders, one Republican and one Democrat, have touched off campaigns to succeed them in their leadership posts.

LEAD: The Islanders, seeking the best strategy for beating the Capitals, looked no further than the first game of this series to plot a method for tying it up in the second.

LEAD: Sportswear, that typically American fashion form, dominated the fall openings yesterday and it was clear that sable and sequins are part of the casual scene. There are plenty of blazers, and at most houses it is still possible to find trousers. But the new formality that suffuses fashion means that fur hats, cashmere, elegant leather jackets and skirts, and plenty of glitter at night have become an integral part of the sportswear field.

''THE SECRET OF MY SUCCESS,'' directed with a lot of panache by Herbert Ross, is a comedy about the meteoric rise in the Manhattan business world of Brantley Foster (Michael J. Fox), who, when he leaves the Kansas farm, tells his worried mother, ''I want to have a meaningful experience with a beautiful woman.'' His mother remains uncertain. Did Brantley pack an iron? ''You don't want to walk around wrinkled in New York.'' Says Brantley, who manages to implicate everybody in his own schemes, ''I'm doing this for you, Mom, as much as for myself.''
LEAD: An appeals court in Manhattan ruled yesterday that a homosexual whose lover died of AIDS had no right to the rent-stabilized apartment the two men shared because his name was not on the lease.

LEAD: The premiere of ''Triptych,'' a new play by Howard Fast, will be performed at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, tonight at 7:30. The play will be performed only once. Mr. Fast is to introduce the play and read some of the poetry of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the Nobel Prize-winning author. The cathedral is at Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Cory Snyder hit a first-inning grand slam, and Steve Carlton recorded his first save since 1967 and the second of his career as the Cleveland Indians routted the Toronto Blue Jays, 14-3, today.
LEAD: An Afghan garrison town is rising here on bare, stony hills whose access roads are mainly the gullies of nearly waterless streams.

LEAD: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi resigned tonight, a move widely expected after Christian Democratic ministers withdrew from his Cabinet on Wednesday. Mr. Craxi handed his resignation to President Francesco Cossiga after a debate in the Chamber of Deputies. Mr. Cossiga is expected to appoint an interim government to administer affairs until early elections can be held, probably in June.
LEAD: Concern over high gasoline inventories continued for a second day yesterday, as prices of crude oil and petroleum products moved slightly lower in brisk trading.

LEAD: A Brooklyn man who was arrested after losing a shoe at the scene of an attempted robbery was sentenced yesterday to a year in jail by a judge who said a ''quirk of fate'' had brought the man to justice.

LEAD: President Miguel de la Madrid has promised that any dam built along the Mexican-Guatemalan border ''would have to preclude damage to our archeological sites and to ecological conditions on both sides of the frontier.''

LEAD: Music and Dance of the Fulani People of Senegal, the Triplex Theater, 199 Chambers Street (619-1980). Most of the Senegalese music that has reached the United States has been by Mandingo griots (historian-troubadours) and such Wolof rock musicians as the singer Youssou N'Dour. Now, four musicians from Senegal's third major tribal group, the Fulani, are making their first appearances in the United States, playing music that can be traced to the 11th century.

LEAD: Horst Dassler, chairman of the Adidas sporting goods company since 1984, died today in this Bavarian town, a company spokeswoman said. He was 51 years old.

LEAD: With high-level Soviet-American talks imminent, President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev gave speeches today expressing hope for agreement soon on eliminating medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe.

LEAD: Inflation in Mexico grew at a rate of 23.6 percent in the first three months of 1987, the Government's central bank said today. The rate exceeds the 19 percent reported for the first three months of 1986, a year in which inflation grew a record 105.7 percent for the entire year. The Bank of Mexico figures indicated that the consumer price index had gone up 114 percent during the last 12 months.
LEAD: An article on April 3 about new efforts to strengthen the New York City Department of Probation misidentified the handgun issued to officers. It is a .38-caliber revolver.

LEAD: Barbara Stanwyck managed to limp onto the stage to receive the 15th annual American Film Institute Life Achievement Award on Thursday night, having checked herself out of a hospital for a few hours.

LEAD: An arms dealer accused of plotting to ship military equipment to Iran and other countries was released yesterday on $1 million bail despite objections from a Federal prosecutor.

LEAD: AMONG my reflections on this 40th anniversary of Jackie Robinson's successful integration of organized baseball is a cherished memory of Jack and me as an effective working pair. LEAD: THE double-barreled title explains as well as identifies the show that it is conferred on but does so slowly, as if its readers were chronically inattentive. LEAD: The characters that the comedian and singer Sally-Jane Heit portrays in her one-woman show are mature urban women up to their necks in complications and generational contradictions. Her most fully realized character is a woman in her 40's who has finally earned her law degree. In a matter of minutes she learns that her daughter, who has just been accepted into Princeton University, is pregnant and would rather get married and work in a supermarket than go to college.

LEAD: I BEGAN LIFTING A few weeks before my 16th birthday, in May 1949. Frankie had dropped out of high school a month earlier and was bound for Parris Island and the Marine Corps at the end of September.

LEAD: James W. Baldwin Jr., a civil engineering professor at University of Missouri at Columbia, standing by a section of a bridge near Columbia. Mr. Baldwin puts the span under stress with weights and hydraulic devices in hopes of finding why bridges fail.

LEAD: Long ago, personal servants usually relieved well-to-do homeowners of the petty nuisances and inconveniences littering life. But now that service staffs are almost obsolete, the electronics industry has begun to manufacture a new type of product. Although perhaps not intended to fill this service void, these devices can do a noble job of freeing us from trivial details, usually at a much lower cost than servants - but without their human attributes.

LEAD: NOAA, the short title for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, is nearly the perfect acronym. ''This is NOAA Weather radio,'' the voice begins, and the listener envisions Noah himself, dispatching a dove to see if the Flood has abated.

LEAD: IT'S DIFFICULT FOR A TELEVISION dramatization to come to grips with the Holocaust. Documentaries are better equipped. A dramatization, no matter how thoughtfully done, is still make-believe. A documentary need only show us, say, a pile of children's shoes. We feel a terrible sorrow then; the unimaginable has been expressed.
LEAD: ''The press is not free,'' Michael G. Gartner, president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, told his colleagues here this week for their annual meeting.
LEAD: Soviet Economic Improvement Below Expectations - headline in The New York Times, March 24.

LEAD: An off-duty transit police officer last night shot and killed the former husband of a woman described by authorities as a friend of his. The woman was injured by a shot as the officer and the former husband struggled, the police said.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Francis A. L'Esperance Jr. of Englewood, N.J., and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Ann L'Esperance to Mark Richards Graham, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Graham of Tulsa, Okla. A September wedding is planned. The future bride expects to graduate next month from Tulane University.

LEAD: A conservative organization with tax-exempt status barring it from political work actively tried to influence Congressional campaigns last year with issue-oriented television commercials, according to people solicited for contributions and the group's internal documents.
LEAD: The Legislature's cherished practice of member-item grants, which Governor Cuomo has criticized and sought to curtail, survived the state budget process virtually unscathed.

LEAD: IN THE classroom and elsewhere, educational floppy disks are entitled to the same copyright protection as the more traditional textbooks. But while illegally duplicated books are easy to spot, the same is not true of software; Once tucked inside a personal computer, the disks are invisible. And many publishers say they fear their material is being copied by student hackers and teachers, for reasons ranging from the fun of breaking a manufacturer's copy-proof code to undersupplied courses that rely on software.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Adriaan Emile Walraven of Schenectady, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mariann Elizabeth Walraven, to James Howell Ramage, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert William Ramage of Williamsville, N.Y. The wedding is to be in October.

LEAD: IN an increasing number of Connecticut cemeteries, he who steals a historic gravestone steals a fake. Cemetery associations around the state are replacing old gravestones with concrete copies, saving the originals from thieves, vandals and the weather.

LEAD: The following multiple-choice questions are from the 1983 National Teachers Examination. The sampling is taken from the section dealing with professional knowledge. LEAD: A DYING old woman teaches a young girl the excitement, and painful necessity, of hope in ''A Star Ain't Nothin' but a Hole in Heaven'' by Judi Ann Mason. And the girl learns without instruction that the opportunities won for young blacks in the civil rights movement of the 1960's cost something of inestimable value in the loss of traditional cultural values.

LEAD: A picture caption March 8 with a Posting on a condominium project in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., misidentified it. It is Hunters Brook.

LEAD: IS Texaco Inc. - under siege by the Pennzoil Company for a legal judgment that could run to $11 billion - a bargain at $32? If not a bargain, is the stock a reasonable speculation? What about a wild shot in the dark? Investors have heard all those opinions in the last week, as Texaco's price slumped by $5 after a legal setback

LEAD: Take a wool blanket with a short nap and lay it over a dining room table. Then lift one end of the table and place a brick under each leg so the table tilts just slightly. Then put a golf ball on the high end and try to stop the ball before it goes over the edge.

LEAD: A motorist was slightly hurt and a section of Interstate 95 was closed for half an hour tonight after bullets hit a pickup truck and a car, the state police said. One shot shattered the truck's windshield near Exit 18 at about 5:30 P.M. The driver was cut by glass.

LEAD: NOTHING in my courses on Anglo-Saxon literature, or in pedagogy, or in my master's thesis on Chaucer had prepared me for this,'' Sylvia Barrett, the harried heroine of ''Up the Down Staircase,'' writes at the end of her first day of teaching.

LEAD: The Lovejoy of Jonathan Gash's MOONSPENDER (St. Martin's, $14.95) remains unchanged. Lovejoy, the scruffy antiques dealer who has figured in all the Gash novels, is still scrounging around to make an honest or (more likely) dishonest dollar. Perhaps he could do better if he did not spend so much time in bed.

LEAD: 'I do not bring forgiveness with me, nor forgetfulness. The only ones who can forgive are dead; the living have no right to forget. . . . The mourning of your deaths will be kept in eternal memory in our hearts - not to sustain an enduring enmity, not to maintain a sterile, debilitating hatred but to gain strength and steadfastness.

LEAD: I MET Edmund Wilson, I think, sometime in the early spring of 1946, after I had come back from Moscow to finish the job I was doing at the British Embassy in Washington. I had been in Washington during the war years, and my friend the Russian composer Nicolas Nabokov, who, like his cousin Vladimir, was a friend of Wilson's, thought that he might like to meet me (I had expressed my intense admiration for ''Axel's Castle'' and ''The Triple Thinkers'') and talk about Russian literature and other topics.

LEAD: While she is awaiting the outcome of her appeal, Mary Beth Whitehead will be allowed to visit the child she was hired to bear.

LEAD: A Federal jury has awarded $2.5 million to Carroll J. Moore Jr., who was severely scalded while showering at the Venice Inn and Motel in Hagerstown in November 1982. Mr. Moore, 40 years old, suffered extensive burns and respiratory injury in the 162-degree shower. The jury found April 2 that the Watts Regulator Company of North Andover, Mass., which makes a valve that the motel had installed to regulate water temperature, was liable for damages.

LEAD: THE disposal of Westchester's garbage, long a focus of debate, took on new complexity last week when private carters were temporarily barred from the resource-recovery plant in Peekskill, municipalities were asked to refrain from delivering bulk refuse and heavy rains created additional problems.
LEAD: CLYDE LOVETT of Boston recently took a day off to buy some things for his home.

LEAD: A TYPICAL ONE-PERSON BROAD-way show is a hyperbolic star turn in which a performer is escorted by an entourage onto a glitzed-up stage for an evening of self-congratulation. But Barbara Cook, who is opening her one-woman show Wednesday at the Ambassador Theater, will not be cavorting with a chorus or ducking in and out of a flashy set.

LEAD: Palm Sunday Salute April 12 - ''The Spiritual Heritage,'' a symphonic suite for orchestra, choir and soloists by Howard A. Roberts, will be conducted by the composer at Carnegie Hall in a Palm Sunday celebration of the black tradition in music. A 5:45 P.M. Champagne reception at Cafe Carnegie will precede the 8 P.M.

LEAD: In the last six months, studies cascading out of Government offices and private research centers have produced a new consensus on the need to overhaul the welfare system. This time around, work is perceived as the solution to dependency, and training and job placement as the way for long-term welfare recipients to break out of the cycle.

LEAD: Professional basketball should begin the playoff season the first week of April, immediately following the N.C.A.A. basketball championship tournament, when interest in basketball is at a fever pitch. The N.B.A. should also cut down on the number of teams eligible for the playoffs - preferably allowing only the top two in each division to compete - thus making the regular season meaningful again.
LEAD: A bill raising the speed limit to 65 miles per hour on nearly all of the Interstate highways in Vermont has been approved by the State House of Representatives.

LEAD: It has been evident for some time that electronic gadgetry is taking over the American home, but a less noted invasion is that of the house plant. Indoor plants have taken root in our houses and apartments as never before.

LEAD: Fifty-seven players began the baseball season assured of earning $1 million or more this year. Sixty-six players of the 663 who were on opening-day major league rosters or the disabled list will earn $62,500, the minimum salary.

LEAD: Behind the pre-Passover calm that traditionally envelops Israel this time of year some time bombs are ticking away beneath Israel's political establishment, and they have within them the power to change the face of Israeli politics.

LEAD: UNTIL fairly recently, beepers were primitive sorts of contraptions. They were conspicuous, too weighty to carry comfortably, and a pain to use. In fact, they did not even beep. To receive a message, you had to hold the beeper to your ear, press a button and listen to an operator reiterate a bunch of numerical codes.

LEAD: Ten armed, camouflage-painted military rockets were found in two wooden crates that sat unopened behind a supermarket for several weeks, the authorities said today.

LEAD: ON MY FIRST DAY as an exchange teacher at the Ipswich High School for Girls in Suffolk, England, I entered the classroom and 30 14-year-old girls, identically dressed in gray skirts and red sweaters, rose to their feet and stood in utter silence. I walked to the front of the room. I could barely suppress a giggle - what a far cry, both in distance and behavior, from my suburban Connecticut students.

LEAD: POLLUTION is no respecter of national frontiers. Fallout from Chernobyl was blown across a dozen countries. Toxic chemicals flushed down the Rhine in Basel wiped out river life in France, West Germany and Holland. And half the trees in the Black Forest were found damaged by sulfurous fumes, mostly from Eastern Europe.

LEAD: When John Warshow and Mathew Rubin met at a demonstration at the Vermont Yankee Nuclear Power Plant in Vernon nearly 10 years ago, they were bound together by their interest in alternative energy and by a chain locking them in protest to the power plant fence.

LEAD: Residents and officials of Montville, N.J. - a 19-square-mile residential township in Morris County - have a secret. ''People don't realize how beautiful it is here,'' said Harold Marine, the Town Administrator. ''There are rivers and forests and streams and mountains.''

LEAD: THE ORDER OF THE New Jersey Superior Court on Sept. 19, 1985, was explicit. Philip Andrew Taylor, 15 months old, would be in the custody of his deceased mother's sister and her husband from ''September 1 each year to June 30 of each following year.''

LEAD: Pine Tree Lane, the only filly in a field of seven outstanding sprinters, outran the boys at every call to score an impressive 1 1/2-length victory in the $172,800 Bold Ruler Stakes yesterday at Aqueduct.

LEAD: MY father worked at a news agency, so we often heard the big news before it was on the radio or in the papers. There were two calls in a single year that I remember most - the first on April 12, 1945, and my mother crying because F.D.R. was dead. How would we manage without him?
LEAD: Tonight was one of those nights when they couldn't get tomorrow off their minds. With both Washington goals essentially scored by Islanders, it was the kind of game they wanted to forget.

LEAD: THE Metropolitan Opera's current production of Francis Poulenc's ''Dialogues of the Carmelites'' is among the company's very finest, and I cannot imagine anybody interested in music, theater, history, theology or a half-dozen other disciplines allowing himself or herself to miss it. LEAD: While I appreciate Martin Bierbaum's perspective in his March 15 Opinion Page article, ''Making Rules to Unmake Rules,'' he errs in assuming that the ''regulatory czar'' bill that I recently introduced represents the only effort being made by the Legislature to grapple with the complex problem of excess bureaucracy.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Malcolm Levine of Old Westbury, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Stefanie Ruth Levine to Stephen Michael Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Cohen of Penn Valley, Pa. Miss Levine and her fiance are law students at New York University. She recieved a B.A.

LEAD: THE TALL, ATHLETIC-LOOKING executive drops into a wing chair in his elegant, antique-filled office at Capital Cities/ ABC headquarters on East 51st Street in Manhattan. Then, turning to a guest, Thomas S. Murphy, the 61-year-old chairman of the media conglomerate, eagerly begins to recite the previous night's ratings from memory.

LEAD: AS a student of Eastern philosophy and religion, I am familiar with the term karma, which, simply put, means that what we do to others will be done to us. I had always assumed that one had to die and return to life in another incarnation to replay karmic debts, but I've been proved wrong.

LEAD: The Pennzoil Company said today that it would not ease its demand for about $11 billion in security from Texaco Inc. The hard-line position puts even more pressure on Texaco to reach an agreement with Pennzoil or file for bankruptcy, a move that could come as early as Monday.

LEAD: Reading and rereading D. Gary Phelps's article ''Getting Honest'' (About Men, March 15), I found it uncannily like my own experience, for I, too, left a marriage and two children at midlife in order to live my life as a homosexual. Unfortunately, Mr. Phelps has yet to shed all the persistent prejudices about homosexuality that led him (and, I might add, myself) to hide in the ''closet'' for so many years.

LEAD: Although the third of five articles on litigation (March 29) dealt with alternatives to suing, it overlooked the Better Business Bureau's mediation-arbitration program to settle customer-business disputes, which has been offered to New Jersey consumers since 1976.

LEAD: CONCERTS in the county pretty well come to a halt for Easter, but the musical floodgates open wide again two weekends hence, and we also have at least half a dozen tonal enticements on the schedule today.
LEAD: Primo Levi, whose autobiographical writings drew on his experiences as an Auschwitz survivor and his training as a chemist, died today in Turin. He was 67 years old.

LEAD: In the highest-level shake-up since the resignation of the Communist Party leader three months ago, China today announced the replacement of its Public Security Minister, who directed the country's main police force during student demonstrations last year.

LEAD: LATE last week, the swift currents of Schoharie Creek receded enough to let the state police divers work. Under the concrete and twisted steel of the highway bridge that collapsed last Sunday, they found a crushed car; in it they found but could not identify a body, the fourth verified casualty of the disaster on the Gov.

LEAD: Gladys Randi Smith of Elmhurst, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Karen Randi Smith, to Richard Pavone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Pavone of New Hyde Park, L.I. The couple plan to marry on Oct. 22.

LEAD: More than three decades ago, Oliver Brown, a black railroad worker, sued the Topeka Board of Education and its ''separate but equal'' system, in which black and white children were required to attend different schools. He won the case in a landmark 1954 U.S. Supreme Court decision, Brown v. Board of Education, which set in motion the desegregation of the nation's public schools.
LEAD: THE ENGLISH A Social History, 1066-1945. By Christopher Hibbert. Illustrated. 785 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $32.95.

LEAD: Ben Crenshaw, an admitted sentimentalist seeking his second Masters title in three years, birdied four holes in a row and five of the last seven today to gain a tie for the lead with Roger Maltbie through three rounds of the 51st Masters.

LEAD: THE state's Casino Control Commission has approved a Holiday Corporation anti-takeover plan while assailing it as not in the best interests of Holiday shareholders.
LEAD: THE theme of the party was Connecticut agriculture, and there was nothing subtle about it.

LEAD: Florence in springtime puffs up its feathers and struts, like the million pigeons roosting on the city's cinnamon-colored cupolas. The hillsides are scattered with daffodils and red tulips, the almond and cherry trees are the first to blossom followed by yellow clouds of mimosa, while the irises, swathed at dusk in shimmering fireflies, grow along the cypress-lined avenues leading up to the Piazzale Michelangelo.
LEAD: THE BIRTHMARK By Dorothea Straus. 206 pp. New York: George Braziller. $14.95.

LEAD: THE Federal Department of the Interior has proposed adding 2,000 acres of land and water along the Connecticut shoreline to the Coastal Barrier Resource System, a national protective program along the East and Gulf Coasts.

LEAD: The Maine Supreme Court has censured District Judge John J. Benoit, one of the state's most popular judges, for improperly commenting on nine drunken driving cases pending in his court.

LEAD: NO eavesdropping equipment is required to detect what Soviet and American participants want from Secretary of State George P. Shultz's visit here. Both sides want to clear the way for a summit in Washingon, where President Reagan and Soviet Leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev can sign the arms control agreement that has eluded them so far.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz took a swipe at critics of his Moscow trip Saturday as he embarked on a search for progress on arms control and other elements of the Soviet-American relationship.

LEAD: He has yet to meet the genius requirements of, say, Earl Weaver, his old minor league manager. But the morning after a long and embarrassing night before, Lou Piniella, the manager of the Yankees, who had used the same lineup in the first four games of the season, wrestled with two alternatives.

LEAD: Arriving at Steensgaard Herregards Pension by bicycle feels a bit like drawing up to the Plaza Hotel in New York on a motor scooter; a horse-drawn carriage might be more appropriate for both. Yet at Steensgaard, and for that matter at all of the Danish inns we pedaled to, the guest who arrives by bicycle is no surprise.
LEAD: WTH a large budget and a host of elite American runners, the New Jersey Waterfront Marathon is quickly being established as one of the country's premier races of its kind.

LEAD: The engagement of Kristin Ann Chase to Donald Beales Taylor has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Weldon Alvah Chase of West Simsbury, Conn. A July 25 wedding is planned. Miss Chase, a graduate of Colby-Sawyer College and the University of Rhode Island, is an account executive for Adams, Rickard & Mason, an advertising and public relations firm in Glastonbury, Conn.
