LEAD: UPHEAVAL has been an unrelenting feature of Edward Koch's third term from its first days more than a year ago to as recently as last Thursday, when Bess Myerson became the latest city official to be pressured out of office.

LEAD: WHY are there crowds of diners at Louie's Shore Restaurant in Port Washington? It can't be the food. It was difficult to find even a small handful of dishes that I could recommend. It seems that for many Long Islanders, Louie's is not just another restaurant. It's a landmark. In fact, it has been so since it opened in 1905.

LEAD: Bruno and Loick Peyron, world-class multi-hull sailors from France, know what it is to compete against each other as brothers. But never has the rivalry been so intense as in their current duel. The two ocean racers are attempting to break the trans-Atlantic speed record, each in his own boat.
LEAD: Jari Kurri and Mark Messier scored two goals apiece to lead the Edmonton Oilers to a 6-5 victory over the Los Angeles Kings and a 2-1 lead in the Smythe Division semifinal series today.

LEAD: Following is a roundup of some of the notable recording releases of recent weeks. Cesar Franck: Les Beatitudes With Louise Lebrun, Jane Berbie, Nathalie Stutzmann, David Rendall, Marcel Vanaud, Francois Loup. The New Philharmonic Orchestra and Chorus of Radio France, conducted by Armin Jordan.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Hyman William Fein of Monsey, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Esther Beth Fein to David Jay Remnick, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Charles Remnick of Hillsdale, N.J.
LEAD: An article in the Arts and Leisure section on March 29 about three pianists misidentified the composer of ''Bagatelles.'' He is Peter Lieberson.
LEAD: The American public overwhelmingly supports the decision in the Baby M case to turn the child of a surrogate mother over to her father, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

LEAD: ''CONFUSION to the enemy'' seems to be the main theme of the International Business Machines' long-awaited announcement of a new line of personal computers. As it turned out, the machines, which were introduced two weeks ago, were not the clone killers they had been previously rumored to be. But their built-in graphics chips, their improved structure for transporting data within the computer and their monitors, which forsake the digital standard and function more like television sets, will certainly make the job of would-be duplicators more complicated.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: We all recognize the psychological importance of one's name to one's identity, but Halston chose to take the risk he did because he wanted lots of money and, indeed, benefited to the tune of millions of dollars.
LEAD: CHURCHES are prepared again to offer a cornucopia of sacred music, today through next Sunday.

LEAD: Golf Okamoto Leads by 3: Ayako Okamoto of Japan, making three straight birdies on the back nine, shot a three-under-par 69 yesterday to take a three-stroke lead entering the final round of the $200,000 L.P.G.A. Kyocera Golf Classic in San Diego. Okamoto, holding the lead for the third straight day, had a three-round total of 205, 11 under par on the par-72 course and three strokes ahead of Pat Bradley and Betsy King, who each shot 71.

LEAD: Cecile Lee Burleigh, the daughter of Mrs. Philip Hall McCaull of Greenwich, Conn., and Robert Cyril Burleigh Jr. of Memphis, is planning to marry Robert Harris Harper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Evans Harper Jr. of Indianola, Miss., on June 13.

LEAD: IN A STUDENT AREA OF Tokyo called Takadanobaba, behind a peculiar sculpture showing a nude Marilyn Monroe about to pounce on a sumo wrestler, lies the office of Kunio Suzuki, leader of a ''spiritual movement'' called the Issuikai.

LEAD: WHEN he heard last Sunday that a bridge had collapsed on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in upstate New York, Robert W. Gubala, the chief engineer of the Connecticut Transportation Department, was on the telephone to Albany offering any personnel, equipment or consultations that might be needed.

LEAD: A POPULAR television quiz show, ''Jeopardy,'' provides answers and leaves contestants groping for questions. Something of the same sort was happening at bridge tables throughout North America at the beginning of this month. Assume that the answer is: ''Four - double yesterday's number.'' What is the question?

LEAD: The good life, these days, generally carries a higher price tag than it once did. However, there is at least one exception to the mounting cost of good living, and that is the exuberantly expanding field of electronic home entertainment. In a dramatic reversal of the usual spiral, prices for stereo and video equipment have been going down, and shoppers are happily searching for these affordable luxuries.

LEAD: The wedding of Alison Anne Keating, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James William Keating of Wellesley Hills, Mass., to Robert Gustaf Hedlund 3d, a son of Mr. Hedlund Jr. of Chicago and Caroline Lamb of Berkeley, Calif., took place yesterday at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Wellesley, Mass. The Rev.

LEAD: PLANTING is the first thing to consider now. Soil has dried out from the deluge earlier this week and there will be a rush until the end of May to get things into the ground. First to be set out are container-grown plants, particularly those with woody stems and perennials; these plants will need special attention.

LEAD: The Senate Intelligence Committee will wait until after the Easter recess to vote on whether William H. Webster should be Director of Central Intelligence. But his promises over two days of hearings last week seemed tailored, if anything, to heighten the Congressional applause that greeted his nomination.

LEAD: One day, we may marvel that it took so long for the artifacts of daily life to be recognized as works of art. For years, we have been celebrating abstraction in modern art, the purity of form in design, the use of unadulterated materials in architecture. But in antiques, only the most sophisticated and ornate would do.

LEAD: State records indicate that a number of required procedures were ignored or circumvented during the most recent inspection of the bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway that collapsed last Sunday, apparently sending at least 10 motorists to their deaths. Two more bodies were recovered yesterday, bringing the total to six.

LEAD: Silence, light, space and a view are the earth, air, fire and water of homes - elements that are basic to building desirable environments. There are, however, few apartments or houses with them all, and none, it seems, with too much of them. Especially in apartments in crowded and expensive urban areas, they have often become luxuries.

The nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment as Ambassador to Rumania.

LEAD: Three rival political rallies competed for crowds here one recent humid night amid the smoke of frying squid and the tinkling bells of ice cream vendors. All three claimed the support of President Corazon C. Aquino.

LEAD: THE ''Little Big Band'' that the alto saxophonist Phil Woods introduced on Tuesday evening at Fat Tuesday's, Third Avenue at 17th Street, is a colorful extension and expansion of the quartet and, of late, the quintet that he has led for more than a decade.

LEAD: TO keep the new basketball coaching staff at Washington State straight, you don't need a program so much as a genealogy. Kelvin Sampson, a former Cougar assistant who was named head coach, is the son of a former high school coach in North Carolina. One of his assistants is Dave Harshman, a former high school and junior college coach, whose father is Marv Harshman, a long-time coach at both Washington and Washington State.

LEAD: Most American Jews say they believe the Jonathan Jay Pollard spy affair and Israel's involvement in the Iran arms scandal will increase anti-Semitism in the United States, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
LEAD: A PARADOX OF TODAY'S popular music is that those who love it the most, those who play and broadcast and support and contemplate it most intensely, often don't much like popular music at all.

LEAD: ONLY PRINCE COULD LAND ''Sign o' the Times,'' a song about AIDS, drugs, sudden death and nuclear war, in the Top 10. LEAD: New York's newest landmarks - the former New York Central Building on Park Avenue and the San Remo on Central Park West - have long been exuberant pinnacles on the city skyline. They have a contemporary distinction, too. Their owners have maintained them as if they were landmarks and did not oppose the official designation.

LEAD: A bank manager embezzled nearly $200,000 after considering, on paper, the prospect of travel, parties and women against the risk of running out of money, getting caught and going to jail, the Federal Bureau of Investigation says..

LEAD: CATHY HAEUSLER is a junior at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign who is studying to become a teacher but often feels as if she has been asked to repeat elementary school. ''Everything I do seems to revolve around cutting things out and hanging them on the wall,'' she said.

LEAD: IF you are still struggling with your tax return, but it is becoming clear that you will not meet the Wednesday filing deadline, there is a hope of reprieve. It is called Form 4868, and if you file it by April 15, the Internal Revenue Service will automatically grant you a four-month extension to get your tax return in.

LEAD: ''THE greatest delight which the fields and woods minister is the suggestion of an occult relation between man and the vegetable,'' Ralph Waldo Emerson said in an essay on nature. I would like to think I know what he means.

LEAD: A community organizer has been arrested and accused of pocketing public housing funds in a case of ''gross governmental mismanagement'' involving the wasting of up to $1 million, District Attorney Ron Castille said.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 15 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: One can empathize with Halston's loss of the right to his name. However, he did receive some compensation. There is no compensation for any person who buys a ''Halston'' fashion at J.C. Penney, thinking that the designer at least reviewed, if not actually designed, the garment. It borders on fraud to market under the name of someone who had no connection.

LEAD: For years, residents of Maine's economically depressed northern communities have watched as southern and coastal Maine cities savored development's boons. Now northern Maine residents say, it's their turn: They want the state to build a highway across Maine that would bring development and perhaps an end to hard times.

LEAD: NO QUESTION ABOUT IT, spring is a season that seems to unleash a certain carefree spirit-in designers as well as in customers. The former are apt to come up with merchandise and ideas on the romantic, whimsical, even saucy side. The latter, on the other hand, aremorelikely to spendmoney on something that is not needed but simply gives a boost to the morale.

LEAD: Cigarette vending-machine operators, who have been losing business steadily, may soon be offering the public a new product. Cigarette-sized packages of four condoms and an information booklet on AIDS could start appearing, next-door to packages of cigarettes, in cigarette vending machines in public washrooms nationwide as early as next month.

LEAD: FIFTEEN YEARS AFTER THE DE-mise of Life as a weekly magazine, photojournalism is reclaiming its former glamorous, legendary status. Pictures that were taken on assignments for magazines and newspapers now regularly reappear - in frames - on the walls of museums and galleries. The photojournalists of yesteryear are being enshrined in biographies and celebrated with retrospective exhibitions.
LEAD: CLOSE PURSUIT A Week in the Life of an NYPD Homicide Cop. By Carsten Stroud. 277 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $17.95.

LEAD: LIKE so many of the fruits and vegetables on the produce stands, asparagus can be found during most of the year. Nevertheless they are especially welcomed in spring. The green of asparagus adds a delectably bright note to seasonal menus.

LEAD: FOR the fifth time in as many years, opponents of the Suffolk County Legislature have filed a petition calling for a countywide referendum on replacing the Legislature with a board of supervisors composed of the 10 town supervisors in the county.

LEAD: The thawing brooks sounded almost like birdsong, flowing into gray creeks still cuffed with ice which debouched into rivers swelling green with the spring - where phoebes rode down the currents on little ice cakes to grab the first stoneflies. As the snow melted off the fields, skunks and coons snapped up voles and moles whose tunnels had been exposed; and crows did the same, when they weren't pairing off, stalking around chatting shoulder-to-shoulder, while courting killdeer wheeled in the air overhead as agile as terns.

LEAD: LATE last month, Daniel H. Kolber, executive vice president of Air Atlanta, shut his office door against the incessant ring of telephones to explain to a visitor the options left for the beleaguered airline.

LEAD: AT the final program of the Juilliard School's ''New Music Weekend'' last Sunday evening, it was impossible to evade the sense that a sea-change in contemporary music, long noted and debated, was being acknowledged. On the program were six all-instrumental chamber works composed between 1978 and last year.

LEAD: An article in The Times Magazine today - ''Legacy of a Mother's Murder'', by Peter Maas - tells of a lengthy child-custody battle between the child's paternal grandparents in Indiana and his maternal aunt and uncle in New York City.

LEAD: The kings and emperors who ruled France knew the phenomenon well. A hot summer's day in Paris laden with the prospect of thunderstorms. The unpleasant smells of the steets and the Seine wafted over the quays and into the windows of their palaces. They dreamed of green grass, trees and the quiet of nature.

LEAD: MORE and more, the demand for small cars is forcing Detroit to go beyond America's boundaries in search of less expensive labor. Ford is the latest automaker to do that, and the company's Lincoln-Mercury division has a new baby called the Tracer, a good idea that has started, shall we say, inauspiciously.

LEAD: A Japanese trade official denied today that Japan had ''dumped'' computer chips at prices below true value and reaffirmed that Tokyo would take countermeasures if Washington went ahead with its sanction plans.

LEAD: FOR two days last week, customers in a South Bronx grocery store smelled gas. On Wednesday, the second day, the distinctive odor was so strong the manager sprayed air freshener around the checkout counter in the afternoon and told a clerk to call Con Edison.

LEAD: American Jews remain one of the most Democratic groups in the American electorate and among the strongest critics of President Reagan, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.

LEAD: THE THREE-BUTTON suit, long perceived as an emblem of decorum, is quietly making a comeback. Spurring its revival are lean, uncluttered lines and a patrician appearance evocative of more gracious times. These days, fans of the style can choose from a wealth of interpretations, all of which, to some degree, retain a traditional look.

LEAD: JUST about everyone is dissatisfied with the wildly fluctuating currency values - euphemistically called ''floating'' or ''flexible'' exchange rates - that characterize today's international monetary system. Without a common monetary standard, under which exchange rates could be stabilized, the remarkable economic integration of Western Europe, North America and East Asia in both commodity trade and financial flows has become less efficient, and is becoming untenable.

LEAD: TERE O'CONNOR'S ''In and Around Your House,'' presented on Thursday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, starts out very promisingly. The visual imagery is exquisite as three young women and two young men cross and recross an eloquently lighted stage. The women wear loose white dresses and pale green pinafores, their hair tied back in buns, and the men are dressed in loose white shirts and green breeches.

LEAD: Little luxuries - colorful tassels to brighten a pair of curtains, a Chinese bowl filled with flowers or a few decorative pillows neatly plumped on the living-room sofa - can spruce up a studio apartment or a small cottage without costing a princely sum. As department stores and manufacturers have become more and more conscious of price, a dazzling array of affordable, well-designed objects for the home has become available.

LEAD: PUTTING down a floor of colorful vinyl tile has long been one of the most popular do-it-yourself projects, and this is truer now than ever before. The high-spirited Pena, who played 801 games for the Pirates and cried when he learned of his trade to the Cardinals, pranced round the bases before the game and received two thunderous ovations from the 52,119 fans.

LEAD: If design were judged by the square inch, some of today's tiny kitchens, bathrooms and closets would be near the top of the list. LEAD: Daniel Buren, a Frenchman, and Sol LeWitt, an American, are painters who have in common that they work on an environmental scale and in an idiom in which there is no trace of an individual hand. Buren works primarily with broad vertical stripes that can turn up anywhere, anytime. Though perfectly at home in museums and galleries, they also have a way of insinuating themselves into metropolitan landscapes the world over.

LEAD: In the wake of its Naumburg International Chamber Music Award last year, the Mannes Trio came to Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night. If this interesting program of Haydn, Schnabel and Brahms showed anything, it was the intelligence, ardor and technique of these three young women. They are also beautifully rehearsed, and each seems to know and sense what the others are going to do.

LEAD: THE United Nations War Crimes Commission, which was established during World War II, went out of business in 1948 without establishing clear guidelines for access to the 36,800 files it had compiled on alleged war criminals, suspects and witnesses. The files were shipped to the fledgling United Nations Secretariat, which consulted with former commission officials and ordered them closed, except for ''United Nations purposes.

Our standard of living is the highest in the country.

LEAD: PRAGUE, THAT ANCIENT, golden city where the beer is strong and the gravy thick, has long been a center of musical composition and performance. Two hundred years ago, Mozart's ''Clemenza di Tito'' and ''Don Giovanni'' had their first performances there. LEAD: Once upon a time, luxury meant one advantage above all others - space. Sure, a grander house had more elaborate architectural details, finer construction and more bathrooms, but the real plus it had to offer was room. Ceilings were higher, rooms were bigger and there were more of them. It's no news that this kind of luxury is rare today.

LEAD: Before Walter Hee, a graduate of the Bronx High School of Science in New York, walked into his first class at Columbia University last fall, his family had already invested more than $2,000 toward helping him make the ''right decision.'' LEAD: A rally today in support of the right to own guns drew only about 100 people to this city that requires its citizens to own a firearm. Organizers of the event, who had expected more than 1,000 people to show up, said it was important to focus attention this year on the constitutional right to bear arms because the nation is celebrating the bicentennial of the Constitution.

Neither poet was referring to dance. Nevertheless, recent programs by Dana Reitz, Risa Jaroslow and Stephen Petronio brought those paradoxical phrases to mind, for all three choreographers concerned themselves with juxtapositions of extravagance and decorum.

LEAD: A pregnant Bronx teen-ager, who was shot once in the head by her former boyfriend before he killed himself Friday, was listed in critical condition yesterday at Lincoln Hospital, the hospital and the police said.

LEAD: THE player who led the United States team in scoring when the Americans won the gold medal at the world championships in basketball last year will not try out for the United States Pan American team this summer. Charles Smith, the Pitt center, said he had declined the invitation to attend summer school.

LEAD: Chicagoans gave Mayor Harold Washington ''all the marbles,'' as he put it, in Tuesday's election. Not only was he re-elected by a comfortable margin, soundly defeating the alderman who had been a thorn in his side all through his first term; he also won a majority in the City Council.

LEAD: To the Editor: As a professional photographer, I always have my camera and film bag hand checked at airport security gates. At the Newark, St. Louis and Detroit International Airports the procedure varies widely. However, I was pleasantly surprised recently at the United Airlines security check at Los Angeles International Airport when the guard asked me to take the cameras and film out of my bag and put them on a tray on the counter.

LEAD: ALEXANDRINA MILCHEVA, a Bulgarian mezzo-soprano and a member of the Bulgarian National Opera in Sofia since 1969, made her Metropolitan Opera debut Wednesday night as Dalila in Saint-Saens's ''Samson et Dalila.''

LEAD: INSIDE the imposing new $100 million science center at Boston University is a black marble plaque the size of a wall. It commemorates the stewardship of the school's president, John R. Silber. ''Under his farseeing leadership and dedicated administration,'' it reads, ''the University has attained academic excellence and achieved distinction by every measure by which the greatness of a university may be judged.

LEAD: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said today that since the United States Government had failed in its attempt to ''assassinate'' him a year ago, ''they should think of other alternatives to meet us halfway.''

LEAD: SINGLES BY THE HUNDREDS IT was hard to tell who was getting more action, the exhibitors or the attendees at the New York Singles Expo and Convention, held last Sunday at the Holiday Inn in Plainview. While several hundred single men and women eyed the various displays, they were also busy eyeing one another.
LEAD: In the warm promise of another spring, the talk was mostly about how it was good to be home.

LEAD: Ever since the Pennzoil Company won a multibillion-dollar lawsuit in 1985 against Texaco Inc., the defendant has been struggling to avoid bankruptcy. With about $35 billion in assets, Texaco faces that prospect unless the judgment, which is now more than $10 billion with interest, is overturned on appeal.

LEAD: ONE ASPECT of academic life has little to do with finals or grades, professors or administrators. It is the province of campus chaplains and involves, as the Rev. William Sloane Coffin describes it, ''the education of the heart.''

LEAD: Every year on a Saturday in late May, the Dutch herald the new herring season with a festival. It's called Vlaggetjesdag, or Flag Day, and in the harbor at Scheveningen, a resort and seaport two miles from The Hague, ships large and small are festooned with rainbows of fluttering flags. Local people from nearby fishing villages don traditional costumes; there are folk-dancing exhibitions, and folk orchestras play favorite local tunes.

LEAD: Pay, shoot or talk. Those are the choices in Nicaragua. The United States can continue lavishing millions on the contras, the problematic rebel army. Or it could send in the Marines. Or it could negotiate with the Marxist Sandinistas.

LEAD: The photograph of Lauren Bacall is not from ''Applause,'' but ''Woman of the Year.'' The gown she is wearing was designed by Theoni Aldredge, who designed the entire wardrobe for the production. Ms. Bacall did eventually wear a red Halston suit as a replacement for a gray ensemble in ''Woman of the Year.

LEAD: WELCH HALL, once a stately stone administration building at the gateway to Eastern Michigan University in Ypsilanti, is now an eyesore. Four years ago, after its heating, ventilating and electrical systems failed, Welch Hall was closed. While trustees of the lesser-known public university wanted money to restore it, they were reluctant to ask the

LEAD: In the last six months, studies cascading out of Government offices and private research centers have produced a new consensus on the need to overhaul the welfare system. This time around, work is perceived as the solution to dependency, and training and job placement as the way for long-term welfare recipients to break out of the cycle.
LEAD: WHAT WAS THE PLAY-wright Joe Orton really like?

LEAD: MRESCA'S RISTORANTE in New Haven is something of a sleeper. It is in a quiet, tree-shaded residential area in the Italian section of town, where one expects to find a typical neighborhood eatery. Not so. Although the premises are storefront-tiny, the space is well-utilized, with four smartly napped tables in the ground-level bar and the main dining area up a few steps.
LEAD: LAST WINTER, after 25 years of being a class clown, Murray Rosenthal finally got what he deserved - a moment in the spotlight.

LEAD: Who would have thought that the sight of a walk-in closet would inspire sighs of envy? Or that a gardener's cottage, charming though it may be, would seem as precious as plover's eggs in a porcelain basket? Indeed, many aspects of the home that once were taken for granted now seem like life's greatest luxuries.

LEAD: THE slaying was done with ''a small-caliber projectile'' that tore through the neck and right lung, officials said. The body was found last Dec. 23 in the Heislerville Wildlife Management Area in Maurice River Township, Cumberland County, N.J. The victim: a young bald eagle. Since then pledges of rewards for information leading to conviction of the killer have grown to about $10,000, says Gregory Huljack, deputy chief of the Bureau of Law Enforcement in the New Jersey Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife.

LEAD: Taxpayers still puzzling over their 1986 returns might think twice before telephoning the Internal Revenue Service for help. A recent study by the General Accounting Office found that the agency gives wrong or incomplete answers to 37 percent of those calling its toll-free help lines.

LEAD: A 14,081-foot mountain peak in south-central Colorado should be named Challenger Point to honor the seven astronauts killed when the space shuttle Challenger exploded last year, the United States Board on Geographical Names has ruled. Donald Orth, executive secretary of the panel, said Friday that the panel voted unanimously on the name, but the action must be approved by Interior Secretary Donald P.
LEAD: An In Short review March 29 of ''Stories We Listened To'' by John Haines listed an outdated address for the publisher. Bench Press has moved to 1355 Raintree Drive, Columbia, S.C. 29212.

LEAD: Dena Wilson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Wilson of Havertown, Pa., was married last night to David Smallen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward L. Smallen of Bricktown, N.J. Rabbi Mindy Portnoy performed the ceremony at the Sheraton Grand Hotel in Washington.

LEAD: My litany of household luxuries is simpler than most - I don't really want to live with taffeta curtains that puddle on the floor, with walls tinted by layers of hand-rubbed lacquer or even with a roomful of 18th-century museum-quality antiques. Luxuries like these are too costly and too obvious for my tastes.

LEAD: AS THE BROADWAY MEGA-SPECTACLE ''Starlight Express'' moves toward its finale, the extravagant melange of flashing lights and moving trusses, bridges, ramps, platforms and turntables that is the show's set begins to shift and turn and rise and fall. The set's gyrations are at first puzzling, and then it becomes clear: a moment or two before the cast will take its final bows, the set is having its curtain call.

LEAD: A FASCINATION with the frozen reaches above the 60th parallel has played a central role in the development of the Canadian national consciousness. Although most Canadians have never been within a thousand miles of the region, an enthrallment with ''the Arctic sublime,'' as it has been described by Franklyn Griffiths, a University of

LEAD: SUBLET IN A CO-OP Question: I am a rent-stabilized tenant in a Manhattan building that has been converted to a co-op. In the next year I expect to be out of the country for six to eight months. I would like to sublet my apartment. How would I do this? . . . V. A., Manhattan Answer: Nonpurchasing tenants in buildings that have been converted to cooperative residences who have the right to remain in their apartments also have the right to sublet their apartments.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: I too am in much agreement with Elizabeth Hunter re ''Living on an Acre of L.I.'' [ Opinion Page, Feb. 22 ] . I am also in agreement with Gloria Acerra re ''Loving the Acres but Seeing the Flaws'' [ Letters to the Long Island Editor, March 22 ] .
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ABOUT a year from now, if all goes as planned, a huge Rockwell International hangar in the California desert will open its doors and the 100th and final B-1B bomber will roll off the production line into the nation's strategic arsenal.

LEAD: One year after American warplanes attacked Libya, American officials say that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi appears to have reduced his involvement in terrorism, but the reasons they cite seem to go beyond the shock of the bombings.

LEAD: THE much-anticipated Special Occasions stamp booklet will be issued by the United States Postal Service in Atlanta, Ga. The success of the Love stamps intensified a demand for stamps with messages and encouraged the Postal Service to issue the new booklet. Each booklet will contain one pane of 10 multi-colored 22-cent stamps carrying messages.

LEAD: Pedro Guerrero and Mike Scioscia hit bases-empty home runs in the second inning as the Los Angeles Dodgers ended a five-game losing streak with a 5-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants today. The defeat was the first for the Giants, who had won their first five games for the first time since 1962.
LEAD: Penn's varsity crew survived rough water and a spirited challenge by Princeton today to win by 1.5 seconds and complete a sweep of the 109th Childs Cup, America's oldest cup race.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Colleen Haggerty Butler, a widow with two children, and Edward F. Foley, a widower with five children, were married yesterday at St. Peter the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in River Edge, N.J., by the Rev. Leroy Smith. Mr. Foley, the director of security for the Delaware North Companies in New York, was formerly the special agent in charge of the criminal division of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York.

LEAD: Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva of Portugal arrived here today for an official visit during which he will sign an agreement giving control of the Portuguese colony Macao to China. On March 26, the two nations concluded nine months of talks on Macao, and on Monday, Mr. Cavaco and China's Prime Mnister, Zhao Ziyang, are scheduled to sign the accord.

LEAD: When new buildings complement their neighbors, planners praise them for being ''contextual.'' Housing Futures, which owns the site of the Olympia theater at Broadway and West 107th Street, is seeking such praise, and a lot more, in proposing an apartment house there that would be so contextual it would be a virtual twin of the 1928 building next door.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
LEAD: BY the end of his life, after pursuing a number of political, social and economic paths, Jackie Robinson had come to grips with some realities about baseball and America.
LEAD: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Committee on Natural Resources - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

LEAD: Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, who had not won a set from John McEnroe in two previous matches, beat him by 6-0, 3-6, 6-2, 6-2 today in the final match of the World Championship Tennis tournament.

LEAD: TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. today offered what it said was the equivalent of $4.3 billion, about $3.29 million in United States currency, for the assets of Dome Petroleum Ltd. Dome's chief executive immediately rejected the offer, contending that it violated a confidentiality agreement between Dome and potential buyers.
LEAD: The Government announced consumer price increases today that included a rise of up to 22 percent in the cost of meat.

LEAD: In Rome last week, on his way from the Soviet Union to the United States, 60-year-old Michael Arbitman worshiped in a synagogue for the first time, gratefully touching the pages of the Torah with his wizened hands.

LEAD: Martin T. Sosnoff, the New York investor who has offered about $735 million for Caesars World Inc., raised his bid yesterday from $28 a share, to $32 a share, in the hopes of edging out a management counter-offer valued by the market at around $31, according to a source close to Mr. Sosnoff.

LEAD: In the battle over the Neversink Gorge -which New York State has been losing for more than five years now - perhaps the only agreement is that the land is spectacularly scenic, home to deer and black bear and one of the finest trout streams in North America.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Bill Lee, the zany left-hander who hasn't played in the majors since Montreal dropped him in 1982 for staging a personal walkout to protest the release of Rodney Scott, a teammate, is making a new pitch for a big-time career. He has announced that he's running for President of the United States - on a
LEAD: Minutes after Atlanta embar-rassed the Nets by 115-88 today at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the Hawks learned that in Landover, Md., the Washington Bullets had beaten the Detroit Pistons.

LEAD: Hasn't Jerry Reuss stayed near a telephone since the Dodgers decided to send him away? Couldn't Tom Seaver cope with the I-95 construction delays on his way from Greenwich, Conn., to work at Yankee Stadium? Isn't Ed Whitson willing to consider trying again? Won't Dooley Womack return in his next life as a starting pitcher?
LEAD: South African church leaders said today that they were prepared to defy an official decree forbidding protests on behalf of political detainees.
LEAD: Texaco's Bankruptcy Filing
LEAD: The executive comittee of the New York State Bar Association recommended this weekend that Governor Cuomo veto a bill that is supposed to tighten ethics rules for state legislators.
LEAD: The Veterans Administration is raising its maximum interest rate on federally backed V.A. mortgages one percentage point, to 9 1/2 percent, the first increase in two years.
LEAD: At morning strategy sessions all over Wall Street, bond traders are asking, ''How's the dollar?''
LEAD: President Reagan's decision to back away from proposals that he made at the Reykjavik summit has both minuses and pluses for Moscow.

LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 13, 1987: Monday Eastern Utilities Assoc Pueblo Intl Inc PS Group Inc Zurn Indus TUESDAY Barry Wright Hillenbrand Indus Crompton & Knowles Procter & Gamble Diversified Energies Teco Energy Inc WEDNESDAY Alberto-Culver Dun & Bradstreet Bally Mfg Corp GTE Corp Bard Midwest Energy Clorox Co NCR Corp Columbia Gas System Texas Indus Conrac Corp Wisconsin Pwr & Lt Dow Jones & Co THURSDAY Archer-Daniels-Midland Gillette Co Black & Decker Lamaur Inc Bundy Corp P

LEAD: The Islanders play better when they are desperate, or so they tell themselves. Evidently, they weren't worried enough after falling behind the Capitals, two games to one, in their playoff series after Saturday night's game. Tonight, they left themselves one game from elimination as they were beaten, 4-1, by a team that performs like a machine.
LEAD: Billy Hatcher had two hits and drove in the winning run as the Houston Astros beat the Montreal Expos, 1-0, today for their sixth straight victory, the best start in their 26-year history.
LEAD: The Bloom Agency in New York, as a way of promoting the IQZoom camera for its client Pentax, has created ''Human Zooms,'' people who slide forward and backward trying to get pictures in focus.

LEAD: For most Yankee fans in New York this year, ''take me out to the ballgame'' doesn't celebrate the pleasures of live baseball so much as it laments a sad necessity: Going to the stadium will be the only way to see the team play.

LEAD: Driven by unemployment and war at home, hundreds of thousands of Salvadorans are estimated to have gone to live in the United States in recent years, according to American and Salvadoran officials.
LEAD: The Wood Memorial at Aqueduct Saturday is supposed to be a key prep race for the Kentucky Derby May 2, but D. Wayne Lukas says that the Wood could render the Derby almost anticlimactic.

LEAD: In its first response to a state report charging that Andy Warhol received inadequate medical care before his death, the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center said yesterday that its staff had provided ''entirely appropriate'' care to the artist.

LEAD: Churches stood empty in the city's East End on Palm Sunday morning and thick stacks of newspapers sat unsold in the rain as 16,000 people evacuated from their homes waited for workers to remove the deadly chemical cargo of a derailed tanker.

LEAD: City auditors accused the City University of New York yesterday of perpetrating ''a farce'' in its method of selecting collection agencies to obtain overdue bills from students, but the university denied the charge.
LEAD: The Russians are coming, this time at the invitation of the Center for Defense Information, a Washington group headed by retired admirals.

LEAD: THE J. G. Durand Compagnie of Arques, France, is making its debut as an advertiser on American television with a line of low-priced crystal and a line of all-purpose cookware. It is an account that the principals of an ad agency on the verge of death almost died for. This is the story: Stephen Penchina and Arthur Selkowitz founded Penchina Selkowitz in 1982, and it really flourished, thanks largely to one account: the Burroughs Corporation.

LEAD: Thirteen candidates, including the widow of Medgar Evers, the slain civil rights leader, will compete for a City Council seat Tuesday in an election that some political analysts say may have a bearing on Mayor Tom Bradley's political future.

LEAD: When President Miguel de la Madrid was elected five years ago, the Mexican Government owned 1,155 companies, including a restaurant and nightclub, several chains of movie theaters, a soft-drink manufacturer and a bicycle factory.

LEAD: West German and American politicians, business executives and economists have clashed sharply here on national policies for checking the fall of the dollar, reducing the American trade deficit and resolving the world debt crisis.

LEAD: Among the more notable accomplishments of David E. White is a ''driver of the year'' award he received last year for ''on-time deliveries, safe driving and compliance with Federal rules and regulations.''
LEAD: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone apparently suffered a political setback Sunday as his party's candidate lost a closely watched gubernatorial election.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has dearly wanted to make a trip to southern Africa before leaving office, and State Department officials were hoping to plan one for July. But East-West issues have so dominated the foreign policy agenda that even thinking about such a journey has been put off, at least until well after the Secretary returns from

LEAD: Kim Kashkashian's viola recital Thursday night at the Metropolitan Museum was pristine and deeply satisfying. The viola is too often played as if it were a slightly hoarser version of a violin; less often (and usually more grotesquely) it is treated like a surrogate cello. In fact, of course, at the risk of sounding obvious, it is itself - an instrument of patrician expressivity, with a burnished luster to its alto tone, its somewhat closeted sound made up of wonderfully variegated shades of gray.
LEAD: Good Vibes
LEAD: The Navy may be forced to take warships out of the fleet by the end of the decade because of a potential shortage of sailors, senior Navy officers contend.
LEAD: Inflation in Mexico hit 23.6 percent for the first three months of 1987, the central Bank of Mexico announced Friday.
LEAD: REGARDING the Hagler-Leonard middleweight title fight last Monday night, some who witnessed it and some who didn't still question whether the only thing square was the ring.

LEAD: Of all the violent, chaotic sights last night, the most curious and most significant was Bob Froese, the Rangers' goalkeeper, following Lindsay Carson of the Flyers down the ice, yelling at him and goading him.

LEAD: C. F. Louis DeWild, for many years a leading professional in the field of painting conservation and the restorer of great paintings that are now in the Metropolitan Museum, the National Gallery of Art, the Frick Collection and elsewhere, died at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center on April 2.

LEAD: On the eve of the traditional Buddhist New Year in Southeast Asia, both sides in Cambodia's unseen, unending war have been making urgent appeals for the trust and allegiance of the battle-weary Khmer people.

LEAD: The marriage of Nancy S. Winston and Paul Craig Lounsbury, both practicing psychotherapists in New York, took place yesterday at the Tavern on the Green in Manhattan. Rabbi Charles Lippmann and the Rev. David Lounsbury, an Episcopal priest and the bridegroom's brother, officiated.

LEAD: The Israeli Army bulldozed several rows of Arab-owned orange trees outside this village today, a day after an Israeli woman was burned to death by a firebomb tossed into her car from the edge of the citrus grove.

LEAD: The Libyan bombers appeared as silver flashes in the blue sky. Their falling bombs exploded nearby and sent plumes of sand, smoke and red-hot metal shards into the desert air. Chadian gunners fired hand-held antiaircraft missiles, but the circling planes flew too high to be hit.

LEAD: Soon after her appointment, a senior financial analyst at a top Westchester corporation was told by her boss to change certain figures on a Philippine company's financial statement to make it look good enough to acquire.

LEAD: Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State and the author of two best-selling books about his years in the White House, has signed with Simon & Schuster to write a book about the meaning of diplomacy. ''I will draw on my experiences,'' Mr. Kissinger said, ''but it will not be an account of my conduct of foreign policy.
LEAD: The idea has been around a long time.
LEAD: Dr. Nathan Smith, a former superintendent of Morrisania Hospital in the Bronx, died Saturday in Miami. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Japanese trade officials are fighting a crucial battle with their United States counterparts under the watchful eye of the military commander who defeated Japan in World War II. The Japanese delegation, led by Makoto Kuroda, vice minister for international affairs at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, is trying to get the United

LEAD: Between innings, the fans are entertained by taped highlights from last season, played to the tune of ''We Are the Champions.'' Bill Buckner still cannot pick up Mookie Wilson's grounder and Jesse Orosco's glove has yet to come down after his celebratory toss following the final out of the World Series.

LEAD: Turning the theory of how to fight the drug trade upside down, police departments around the country are increasingly blanketing drug-plagued neighborhoods with officers and arresting large numbers of small-time dealers and buyers.

LEAD: South Korea's prospects for constitutional changes were shattered this morning when President Chun Doo Hwan ordered a halt to all debate on the pivotal issue until after the 1988 Summer Olympics are held in Seoul.

LEAD: Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau's widening probe of hiring abuses by state legislators prompts emulation by prosecutors in the other boroughs. That's all to the good - except in the case of Queens. There, District Attorney John Santucci would pursue a probe that appears to involve his own son.
LEAD: Franklin D. Schurz Sr., the longtime editor and publisher of The South Bend Tribune and chairman of Schurz Communications Inc., died at his home here today. He was 89 years old.

LEAD: Reports that the wife of former State Senator Julian Bond confidentially told the police her estranged husband was a habitual cocaine abuser and then later publicly retracted the allegation have become the focus of broad controversy here.

LEAD: Bobby Smith's goal tied the game for Montreal midway through the second period and Mike McPhee put the team ahead 30 seconds later as the Canadiens beat the Boston Bruins, 4-2, tonight to sweep their Adams Division first-round series.

LEAD: Dr. Barry Bloom is a television star. Every week he sits in a straight-backed chair near an arrangement of flowers and looks directly into a single, sometimes shaky, camera. Viewers call with questions about their dental work and Dr. Bloom gives advice, always stressing the importance of a second opinion.
LEAD: AN urge to simplify, to choose a few dozen artificial flies that will enable him to catch trout under all conditions, lurks in the heart of many a fly fisherman.
LEAD: From the Flyers' point of view, their mission was accomplished in New York during their series against the Rangers despite last night's loss.

LEAD: THE eulogy rang through the great vaulted Riverside Church in Manhattan. ''The phrase for Jackie Robinson went from 'black bastard' to 'black knight,' '' intoned the Rev. Jesse Jackson. ''We are all better because a man with a mission passed our way.''
LEAD: ''He has to do this,'' Jackie Robinson said to us that fall of 1960. ''He has to call Martin right now, today. I have the number of the jail.''

LEAD: The National Gallery of Art has announced that it will mount a show in the summer of 1988 of the watercolors, paintings and etchings of John Marin, an American artist who died in 1953. The gallery has a large collection of Marin works, donated last year by the artist's son, John C. Jr. J. Carter Brown, director of the gallery, said yesterday that Mr.

LEAD: Horace Adali Sawyer, a former president and chairman of the Lone Star Cement Company, now Lone Star Industries, based in Greenwich, Conn., died last Wednesday in New Orleans, where he had moved after his retirement. Mr. Sawyer was 92 years old and formerly lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

LEAD: Marty Seiden peered out into the smoke-filled room and spoke about The Day. ''You've heard what's going to happen May 7,'' he said to the 31 Smokenders students seated before him in a Manhattan hotel room. Ashtrays at the ready, they listened to him in silence, save for the occasional cough.

LEAD: Improved job security will be the top goal when the United Automobile Workers open negotiations this summer for a new contract with the nation's two largest automobile companies, the union's president said today.

LEAD: MARIA CHENG began with some talk on the business and art of dance today, in a program presented by the Maria Cheng Dance Company on Friday evening at the Triplex Theater. That talk, part of a piece called ''Antecedents,'' proved that Ms. Cheng is a smart and funny observer of the world of dance. But the rest of the evening was disappointing, though Ms.

LEAD: A woman who has spent five years building an ark in the center of the city might be allowed to continue her work if a judge stops the city from banishing her from the site, her attorney said yesterday.

LEAD: SHEARSON LEHMAN BROTHERS seems to have chosen an ideal time for its initial public offering - the largest of stock in a brokerage house. The stock market is booming and bond prices and the dollar have been gyrating, producing the kind of volatility traders thrive on, and corporations are issuing record amounts of securities.
LEAD: Nine people died and six were hospitalized after a family reunion at which they reportedly ate poisonous fish, the national news agency Bernama said today.
LEAD: B. J. Surhoff's two-run single in the 12th inning today gave the unbeaten Milwaukee Brewers their sixth victory of the season, a 7-5 triumph over the Texas Rangers.
LEAD: Unwilling to raise taxes for new social programs, Congress is moving to require employers to provide many additional health and welfare benefits to employees and their families.
LEAD: HOW I GREW. By Mary McCarthy. Illustrated. 278 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.

LEAD: QUESTION: A Red Sox left-hander named Billy Rohr just missed a no-hitter against the Yankees on opening day in his major league debut about 20 years ago. Has anyone ever pitched a no-hitter in his first appearance in the majors? What ever became of Rohr?

LEAD: The Devil is not only responsible for the fall of the Rev. Jim Bakker and the troubles facing the nation's television ministry; he is an active, negative force at work in the universe who is constantly tempting human beings, many followers of the television evangelists believe.

LEAD: CYDNEY WILKES, Nelson Zayas and Linda Mancini examined lovers' problems on Saturday night at the Kitchen. ''One Man's Drink. . .,'' directed by Mr. Zayas and choreographed and performed by Ms. Mancini and him, to a sound score by Lisa Love, was a lighthearted courtship that began with the dancers seated side by side like moviegoers.

LEAD: Rose Robbins, an administrative assistant to the board of trustees and president of Bergen Community College in Paramus, N.J., was married yesterday to Alan Buxton, who recently retired as the college's dean of faculty. Rabbi Andre Ungar performed the ceremony at the home of the bride in Fort Lee, N.J.

LEAD: After Joaquin Romero succeeded in getting himself from El Salvador to a Latin American neighborhood of Los Angeles, one of his first acts was to pay a smuggler to bring his wife and two young daughters here.

LEAD: The near hysteria over espionage these days has produced a thriller atmosphere without the sober reasoning of the best spy thrillers. The preposterous Senate vote recommending that Secretary of State George Shultz cancel his trip to Moscow was an impulse of thoughtless indignation without concern for policy.
LEAD: * Maggie Perkins has joined William Esty Company as senior vice president/creative director.

LEAD: Merrill Lynch Capital Partners has signed an agreement to buy the Borg-Warner Corporation of Chicago for $48.50 a share, or $4.23 billion, and convert the huge industrial organization into a private company, the two said jointly yesterday.
LEAD: A mood of accommodation has swept the Chilean political scene in the week since the Pope's visit, with all sides publicly expressing a desire to end the polarization.

LEAD: Jan. 3, 1984: Pennzoil board endorses a Memorandum of Agreement to buy 43 percent of Getty Oil, including one billion barrels of crude oil reserves, for $5.3 billion. Jan. 4: News release about merger is issued by Getty and Pennzoil. Texaco's president, Alfred C. DeCrane Jr., asks a Getty investment banker if the formal papers have been signed.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Responding to strong criticism, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has begun a major renovation of its Manhattan detention center and is revising the system it uses to keep aliens with criminal backgrounds from entering New York City.
LEAD: * Country Home magazine will raise its circulation rate base 10 percent, to 880,000, and advertising rates 10 percent with the August issue.

LEAD: Experimental music and downtown showmanship have rarely been blended more delightfully than in the early solo performances of the debonair young percussionist and composer David Van Tieghem. In ''A Man and His Toys,'' the show Mr. Van Tieghem toured around Europe and the United States, he played a cheerfully eccentric scientist of sound effects, eliciting an extraordinary range of amplified thuds and squeaks from a laboratory of household objects.

LEAD: D. Edward Ricchiuto, vice chairman and chief executive officer of the Hicks & Greist Advertising Agency in Manhattan, died of cancer Friday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 57 years old and lived in Ridgefield, N.J.

LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge in Dallas is expected to rule Tuesday on whether to allow the Placid Oil Company, one of the Hunt brothers' major holdings, to proceed with a major deep-water drilling effort in the Gulf of Mexico that is known as the Green Canyon project.

LEAD: Col. George Leonidovich Artamonoff, 84 years old, the first president of Sears International Inc. and later director of the Tokyo office of the Marshall Plan, died Saturday of pneumonia in the Potomac Valley Nursing Home in Rockville, Md.
LEAD: The long-running Guinness scandal is again a focus of national attention, as new details, charges and countercharges in the case were revealed last week in a London high court.
LEAD: The three men who want to buy the Hospital Corporation of America for $3.8 billion are meeting with skepticism over their ability to finance the deal.

LEAD: A portion of a two-lane bridge plunged into the Schoharie Creek Saturday night, three miles from where parts of a bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway collapsed April 5, officials said yesterday.
LEAD: ''Hell is the impossibility of reason.'' Oliver Stone in ''Platoon.''
LEAD: The Mellon Bank Corporation, for years one of America's most revered financial institutions, is rapidly losing some of its luster.

LEAD: Southern Methodist University's decision the other day to scrap its football team for a second season in 1988 is only the latest piece of continuing fallout from the ignominy that shook the school this winter.
LEAD: Almaden Vineyards is being reassigned to McCann-Erickson, according to a person who knows. The ad budget is in the area of $13 million.

LEAD: New York City, which owns Yankee Stadium, is in an unusual position for a landlord. For each of the last five seasons, it has paid the Yankees more to maintain the stadium than the team has paid the city in rent.

LEAD: Auto Racing Prost Takes Opener: Alain Prost of France, the two-time world champion, drove a McLaren to victory in the Brazilian Grand Prix yesterday, the first race of the 1987 Formula One season. Brazil's Nelson Piquet was second in a Williams, and Prost's teammate, Stefan Johansson of Sweden, was third.

LEAD: AS Bill Irwin demonstrates in ''The Regard of Flight'' at the Vivian Beaumont, it is not the size of the theater that matters but the size of the talent. Mr. Irwin has performed versions of this signature show in the studio space at the Dance Theater Workshop, on the compact open stage at the American Place Theater (in 1982) and on ''Great Performances'' on public television.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WHEN asked about the chances of repeating his theatrical Masters victory of last year, Jack Nicklaus joked, ''I'm going out to look for some lightning; maybe I can catch it again.'' And the lightning was out there again yesterday in the clear blue sky above the Augusta National pines, as Greg Norman discovered to his dismay.

LEAD: The New York Pops, under the direction of Skitch Henderson, played a mildly diverting concert at Carnegie Hall Saturday afternoon - a concert that could, however, been much more satisfactory than it was. Mr. Henderson is a jaunty, energetic maestro who knows his way around an orchestra; moreover, Robert
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''Pennzoil has placed its own greed above any consideration of fundamental fairness or the public welfare.'' - James W. Kinnear, chief executive officer of Texaco. ''It shows in my judgment an arrogance and disregard for the whole judicial process and an attempt to use the bankruptcy laws improperly.

LEAD: In a move that has puzzled and alarmed some foreign companies, China's central Government has virtually halted imports of materials for special projects, according to business executives and diplomats who follow Chinese trade.

LEAD: Many African countries will need dramatic increases in foreign aid to continue what development experts are calling historic economic reforms, according to State Department, World Bank and United Nations officials.

LEAD: * Apache Corp. is offering $90 million of Ba-3/BB- rated 7 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2012 at 100 through Smith Barney, Harris Upham. Noncallable for two years, the debentures are convertible into the company's common stock at $13.875 a share.
LEAD: Zimbabwe, in a challenge to neighboring white-ruled South Africa, has secretly bought 12 MIG-29 interceptor aircraft, the Soviet Union's most advanced warplane, the Sunday Telegraph reported.

LEAD: The American Embassy in Moscow is an island under constant assault. Laser beams probe the windows for echoes of conversations. But what the Knicks also missed was the respect he commanded, an aura that benefited the entire team.

LEAD: Two years ago, with talk of a need to foster a ''spirit of altruism'' in the young, Mayor Koch boldly launched New York's City Volunteer Corps. It was to be a three-year experiment and a potential model for a system of national youth service. Now, just into the third year, the Mayor seems ready to declare the experiment a failure and cut its funding from $10 million to $6 million.

LEAD: The City of London is a dense web of classicism, a tightly knit mass of low, masonry buildings that in its intricacy feels something like Venice with automobiles. LEAD: For four months now a prominent black South African editor, Zwelakhe Sisulu, has been held alone in a cell in Sandton, near Johannesburg. The state has not charged him with any crime or told him why he is being detained. There is no way of knowing when or whether he may be released.

LEAD: NOTHING quite satisfies in the same way as a program of German song offered by artists of true understanding and skill to a knowledgeable and receptive audience. LEAD: The GTE Corporation and United Telecommunications Inc., which are the parent companies of the troubled U S Sprint Communications Company, both reported lower first-quarter earnings yesterday.

LEAD: President Chun Doo Hwan has radically simplified South Korea's political choices. For a time, it looked as though the issue was how much democracy he would allow to succeed him. Now the contest seems to be between him and democracy - and he is winning. By suspending national debate over how to choose his successor, he contradicts the spirit, if not the letter, of his own promises.

LEAD: A cool, damp day in early April could not diminish the warmth Willie Randolph feels on these occasions. After 12 years, he said that the first home game of the season is still preceded by a restless night before, the anticipation building for the annual reunion of a ballplayer and the fans.

LEAD: Although the Pittsburgh Penguins doubled their attendance and almost doubled their points in the last three years, they still failed to make the National Hockey League playoffs. LEAD: AMBLING along on Showtime for the past couple of seasons, ''It's Garry Shandling's Show'' has become the pay cable crowd's ''Late Night With David Letterman.'' Like NBC's Mr. Letterman, Mr. Shandling is low-keyed and kind of goofy, given to noticing the smaller absurdities of life. He is a well-meaning, rational soul buffeted by a world overdosing on silliness.

LEAD: Paris by day and Paris by night are undergoing a subtle metamorphosis.

LEAD: I'VE rehearsed my acceptance speech a thousand times. It's a mix of humility, awe and gratitude, laced with professionalism and childish innocence. It's still your basic ''I'd like to thank the members of the Academy who voted for me, my producer, my director, and my mother'' - with a focus on the film I was privileged to star in, the cast, the crew and, of course, the caterer.

LEAD: On a night that will haunt their memories, the Mets blew a five-run lead in the fourth inning and a pair of one-run leads in the ninth and 10th innings tonight. And then they blew the entire evening when Tommy Herr of the St. Louis Cardinals whaled a grand slam off Jesse Orosco that buried the Mets once and for all, 12-8.
LEAD: LEGAL fallout from the Watergate scandal continued to flutter down last month, nearly 15 years after the affair began.

It is true that earlier, Japanese dancers who had been influenced by Butoh had performed as individuals in New York. But significantly, their work was not seen in the context of the still-unfamiliar fusion of German dance expressionism and Japanese experimentation that became

LEAD: ''LIKE every high school, we've been affected by such concerns as suicide and divorce, and our student-newspaper reporters have written about them from their viewpoint,'' said Sharon Miken, the journalism teacher at Triton Regional High School here.

LEAD: IT ISN'T OFTEN THAT THE COSMETICS industry thinks in purely practical terms. But with the proliferation of makeup, hair-care and skin-treatment products that are small, lightweight and ideal for travel, it seems that common sense has at last pervaded the business.

LEAD: I read, with great interest, your article ''Gibbs Sets Out on His Last Career'' (March 29). Like many others who have worked with Mr. [ Edward M. ] Gibbs, I regret that the deputy county executive has decided to retire. Mr. Gibbs was a good deputy and before that he was a dedicated legislator.

LEAD: THE road back to the major leagues begins in Miami for the former Baltimore Oriole and Montreal Expo pitcher, Dennis Martinez. A free agent who had a 3-6 record and a 4.59 earned-run average with the Expos last year, Martinez has signed a two-week contract with the Class A Miami Marlins in an attempt to get in shape for a possible comeback with the Expos when he becomes eligible to rejoin them May 1.

LEAD: Mike Schmidt following through on game-winning blast in the ninth inning against Pirates. The home run, his fifth of the season, made him the 14th major-league player to hit 500 career home runs. Section 5. (AP)

LEAD: DEPENDING on your point of view, it is either an architectural mishmash or a masterful example of scientific eclecticism. But the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew on the Upper West Side, everyone agrees, has become one of New York's enduring real-estate controversies. After landmark designation in 1981 stalled a plan to demolish most of the church at West 86th Street and West End

Erving, playing his last regular-season home game, got 2 more points than he needed in the game against the Indiana Pacers, bringing his career total to 30,002 and putting him in the company of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who has 36,374, and Wilt

LEAD: GLENN GOULD WOULD probably have loved the compact disk. He was nearly as interested in new methods of recording as he was in the piano; for him, recordings were not merely an appendix to concerts, but a satisfactory replacement for them.
LEAD: IN Italy, Mario Schimberni is something of a management legend.
LEAD: AT 3:55 P.M. on April 9, a southbound J train left the Chambers Street station in Manhattan with one door open.

LEAD: In theory, the Knicks' miserable season ended a while ago - sometime after the inevitable dismissal of Hubie Brown as coach last December and before the incessant string of injuries made each contest an unpredictable adventure. And yet, in truth, the misery didn't end until tonight, when the Knicks lost to the Cleveland

LEAD: AS COMPACT DISKS BE-come plentiful enough so that record companies have to compete for buyer attention, an illuminating insight into CD marketing is provided by the first installment of reissues from the Vanguard Recording Society.

LEAD: MORE THAN 250 PEO-ple traveled from throughout Europe and the United States to Lausanne, Switzerland, two years ago to celebrate the 70th birthday of Count Antonio Giansanti Coluzzi - and to play with his model trains.
LEAD: The undefeated Milwaukee Brewers tied an American League record for quick getaways by winning their 11th in a row, 4-3, today over the Texas Rangers.

LEAD: World Airlines has been traversing the globe for 40 years, and should be ''flying over the North Atlantic for a good many more.'' So, given rising rents in Nassau County, L.I., and a 15-year lease that was on the verge of expiring, Mr. Roney, systems and budget manager for Sabena, thought it would make sense for the company to build its North American corporate headquarters.

LEAD: The engagement of Dorothy Caeser Chanock to Robert Owen McCabe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aloysius B. McCabe of Washington and Wellfleet, Mass., has been announced by Martha Johnson Caeser of New Haven, mother of the bride-to-be. A June 20 wedding is planned.
LEAD: Manicured lawns offer a regal entry to the Metropolitan State Hospital for the mentally ill and a stark contrast to conditions inside.

LEAD: LAST JUDGMENT by Richard Hugo (Stein & Day, $16.95) is a very fine book. Its prologue goes back to the German invasion of Poland in 1939 and the theft of an unknown da Vinci painting. Switch to the present, and the apparently unrelated mass murder of a family in London. ''I am the incubus of pure terror,'' says the killer as he pulls the trigger.

LEAD: As a representative of an organization called Victims of Police Crime who has long been uneasy with the amount of publicity intentionally generated by police unions, I would like to respond to Arthur Cliff's letter to the editor on March 22 [ ''Police Association's View on State Inquiry'' ] .

LEAD: To the Editor: To what purpose did Nicholas D. Kristof write ''Dealing with the Laws of the Land''? I was surprised that someone who lives abroad would come to such an immature view of respect for the law (and therefore culture) of another country while traveling. The gist of the article seemed to be that the victim of a crime should have remorse for having a thief proseuted under the legal system under which he (the thief) lives.

LEAD: THE QUEEN OF ENGLAND MAY rely on a retinue to carry her impedimenta, but the rest of the world's women must tote the works themselves. For many women, the tote bag is an office away from the desk, a portable dressing table, a locker room, lunch pail, library, shopping cart, travel bag or an amalgam of all these.
LEAD: A plan by Baruch College to expand its campus near Gramercy Park has generated a bitter neighborhood battle over that most precious and volatile of Manhattan commodities: space.

LEAD: The engagement of Susan Andrea Locke to Nicholas Daland Peirson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Peirson of Corning, N.Y., has been announced by Jean Locke of Gilford, N.H., and Kent Locke of Sanborton, N.H., parents of the bride-to-be. A June 20 wedding is planned.

LEAD: Alex Ramirez being kept by his mother, Alma, from tweaking the nose of the large white rabbit handing out baskets yesterday at the Easter egg hunt in Weehawken, N.J. Showing their concern at the 2-year-old youngster's irreverence were Sandy Lemus, left, 3, and Mary Dulack, 4. (NYT/Edward Hausner)
LEAD: FROM REMOVING FIG LEAVES on Italian masterpieces to censoring films in Hong Kong to protecting antiquities in Israel, culture the world over provokes heated debate.

LEAD: UP to now, everybody has been making a big fuss over the doctor and the physical therapist who helped Bernard King return from knee surgery. But nobody has praised the drama coach who gave King back his game face.

LEAD: To the Editor: Reading ''Dealing With the Laws of the Land'' served to remind me why Americans are viewed as they are around the world and particularly in Central and South America and the Middle East. Mr. Kristof's Victim as Apologist must seem hysterical to local authorities, reinforcing the arrogant but essentially spineless stereotype that their governments and media tout.
LEAD: AN unprecedented number of mixed-use buildings are opening in Manhattan, prompting debate over whether apartments on upper floors will cast a discouraging shadow over office space below.

LEAD: In the elevators and upper floors of 1295 Fifth Avenue, a smoky smell lingers and the ceilings remain blackened. On the 33d and 34th floors, the doors leading to the apartments of the seven people who died in a fire there last month stand burned beyond use. A bouquet of dried, shriveled flowers is taped beside each door.

LEAD: An article in today's New York Times Magazine discusses the political activism of Palestinian students at Bir Zeit University on the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

LEAD: BY midweek, politicians were streaming out of the capital for Britain's protracted ''Easter hols,'' and that may be the best news the Labor Party and its leader, Neil Kinnock, have received all year. Recent polls showed Labor 10 to 13 points behind the Conservatives, but barely holding onto second place over the Alliance of Liberals and Social Democrats, which hopes to displace Labor as one of the two major parties.

LEAD: WALL Street had mercilessly beaten down the stock prices of companies throughout the oil industry by the end of 1983, a consequence of slipping energy demand and rising production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

LEAD: Slot machines will soon be permitted on Maryland's Eastern Shore, but legal casino nights that recently inspired gambling fever around Baltimore are out under legislation passed by the State General Assembly.
LEAD: THOSE familiar with compulsive gambling say that the common reference to it as a disease, like alcoholism and other addictions, is not merely metaphoric but technically accurate.

LEAD: Two decades after colleges and universities began opening their doors to substantial numbers of minority students, the effort to diversify American higher education appears to have stagnated.

LEAD: 'PAPA' AND THE BABY BOAS HERBERT D. HERMSDORF recently became a father. Well, not technically, the Longwood High School earth science teacher admits. ''But everyone's calling me 'papa,' '' he said.

LEAD: A South Korean court imposed jail sentences on two opposition legislators today amid published reports that prosecutors planned to step up criminal proceedings against 15 or more anti-Government politicians.
