LEAD: PERCHED on a rock in Red Rocks Park, Colo., last Monday, Gary Hart became the third official candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination. ''I make this race because I love my country and I want America to do better and move forward,'' the former Senator from Colorado said. He promised a campaign of ideas.
LEAD: Afghan guerrillas attacked an outpost of Soviet border guards last week and killed two of them, the official press agency Tass said today.

LEAD: Some people collect restaurant menus on their travels; others keep Kaopectate bottles labeled in French, in German, in Spanish, in Hindi: a record of successive and sudden onslaughts of bodily distress. Still other travelers clutter their living rooms with Indian brasses or Provencal pottery or Fijian tapa cloths.

LEAD: MANY RECORDINGS of pre-Classical music used to be sold in what amounted to plain brown wrappers with such plain brown titles as ''Monody, ca. 1600 - Research Period VII'' (and many, though by no means all, of the performances were monochromatic, too). If this left little doubt about the high-mindedness attached to the whole operation, it also probably discouraged casual purchases, limiting the audience to those already in the know.

LEAD: President Reagan, sounding an optimistic note on the possibility of reducing medium-range nuclear weapons, said today that American negotiators would ''intensify'' efforts to resolve any remaining differences with the Soviet Union on the issue in Geneva later this month.

LEAD: For the individual confined to a wheelchair who fights a never-ending battle against architectural and other barriers on home turf, the prospect of international travel looms as the impossible dream.

LEAD: WHEN Allen Lord ties one on, he creates quite a stir. That is because while he wears ordinary trousers, shirts and jackets, his silky-looking ties are not made of silk, or cotton, rayon or Dacron.
LEAD: WELL, WE HAD the usual big April to-do this week at our house. The worst moment came when Clemmie, 14 months old, got lost in the file cabinets.

LEAD: William Safire incorrectly asserts that the letter sent recently to The Wall Street Journal over my signature was in fact written by former President Nixon. Though much of the factual material was drawn from Mr. Nixon's excellent memoirs, every word of the letter was mine. But, while I don't imagine Mr.
LEAD: Cecil King, chairman of what was believed to be the biggest publishing empire in the world in the 1960's, died at his Dublin home on Friday. He was 86 years old.

LEAD: THEOLOGY AND AMITY The College of New Rochelle has scheduled four weekly discussions beginning at 7 P.M. Wednesday, exploring the ''Theology of the Jewish-Christian Reality.'' Sister Nancy Malone, editor of Religion and Intellectual Life, published at the college, will lead the discussions.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Woodfin Keesee Jr. of Mount Kisco, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Hartford Keesee, to Thomas Michael Niemann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Oscar Niemann of St. Louis.
LEAD: NEW magazines usually emerge hard on the heels of a shift in life styles, despite oft-repeated warnings about the high failure rate of such publications.

LEAD: WESTCHESTER is in danger of providing nothing but emergency housing for the homeless instead of building permanent, moderate-priced housing for them, the Rev. John P. Duffell, pastor of St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in Yonkers, has warned the County Commission on the Homeless.

LEAD: MORNINGS, I am not good. But sometimes you do have to get up to meet a worthy adversary, in this case the dentist. So I growled and grumbled in my empty house, and then I went out to the car, which nearly spoiled the whole day. The car said, ''Good morning.''
LEAD: Learn 'n' Play: Voyage to Mermaid Island Scholastic Lorimar Reading Vol. 2 30 minutes. $14.95.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. David Tysen Nutt of Scotch Plains, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Katharine Nutt to Patrick John Barry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Barry of Lake Forest, Ill. The wedding is planned for July.

LEAD: THERE WERE PEOPLE who told me ''Les Miserables'' was going to be wonderful and people who told me it was going to be terrible. The truth - or my reactions, at least - turned out to lie somewhere in the middle. If the lyrics were often little more than doggerel, and if the score often seemed the musical equivalent of doggerel, there were compensations in Colm Wilkinson's rightly acclaimed Jean Valjean, in a few of the supporting performances, in the scenery and lighting, and, every now and then, in a genuinely striking dramatic effect.
LEAD: A British engineer, imprisoned by the Libyan Government for six years, has been moved from his cell in preparation for ''imminent release,'' the British Consul said here today.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Porter Jr. of Washington of the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Alexanderson Porter to Vincent John Dowling Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dowling of West Hartford, Conn., and Vero Beach, Fla. A May 30 wedding is planned.

LEAD: Al Campanis only voiced what many others in decision-making positions in sports believe and practice. The ''old boy'' network that can always find another assignment for a white manager with a less-than-outstanding record has historically had nothing but a deaf ear to the entreaties of the aspiring black manager.
LEAD: AN INSULAR POSSESSION By Timothy Mo. 593 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

LEAD: FOR just about the whole first week, everything around here was in apple-pie order. The three of us all get up at different times to go to work and, like Dagwood Bumstead, at top speed, washing-shaving-toothbrushing-dres-sing zap!!, out the door, but nobody was ever late because clean clothes and toiletries were in good supply and easy to find.

LEAD: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 17 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $4.95.) A plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 24 BREAK IN, by Dick Francis. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Mystery, melodrama and bitter family rivalry in the world of British steeplechase racing.

LEAD: Twice a week, on Wednesday and Friday, Ike Williams leaves his job in Delaware and drives 21 miles to Jayco Liquors in this border town. A teetotaler, he ignores the rows of bottles. Instead, like thousands of other Delaware residents hoping to strike it rich, he comes here to buy Maryland lottery tickets.
LEAD: MICKEY ROONEY stars in ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,'' which is making a fast stop at the Westbury Music Fair during its current national tour.

LEAD: Willi Smith, one of the fashion industry's most successful young designers, known for spirited and trendy clothes, died of pneumonia Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 39 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: The New York Times Magazine recently published two articles that inaccurately and unfairly report about my role on the staff of the National Security Council.
LEAD: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response from readers. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of those letters.

LEAD: When I first saw the view from my office in London, I felt as if I had inherited a great painting, and in a sense, I had. For when I look south across a sweeping bend of the Thames, I can see the New Palace of Westminister, home of the Houses of Parliament - a filigreed Gothic ramble marked at one end by soaring Victoria Tower and at the other by the familiar Clock Tower of Big Ben.
LEAD: History may, as so many cynics have said, be merely a record of the crimes, follies and misfortunes of mankind, but it also has its miracles.

LEAD: TOWARD the end of 1985, the United States Sentencing Commission took up the task of making punishment for Federal crimes more uniform, effective and fair. Last week it recommended ranges of sentencing for 43 categories of crimes, based on a statistical analysis of present sentences. Convicts would no longer be paroled, more time would be served for drug-related offenses and prison would be prescribed for many white-collar crimes under guidelines that become binding on Federal judges Nov.

LEAD: RESPONDING to increases in the incidence of compulsive gambling, an ad hoc committee of the New Jersey Council on Compulsive Gambling last week urged state certification of gambling counselors and proposed specific criteria to be used.
LEAD: FROM REMOVING FIG LEAVES on Italian masterpieces to censoring films in Hong Kong to protecting antiquities in Israel, culture the world over provokes heated debate.
LEAD: EIGHT years have passed since a developer succeeded in getting a plan for a 210-unit town-house development in the Arlington section of Staten Island through the city's reviewing agencies.

LEAD: For the past seven years Raymond W. Zrike went out of his way to fly Trans World Airlines, and last month it was about to pay off: he passed the 90,000-mile mark, enough to get two free first-class round-trip tickets to Europe.

LEAD: I have a confession to make, and this seems as fitting a place and as good a time to make it as any. I cannot change a tire. Nor can I differentiate between the carburetor, if cars still have such things, and the radiator, air filter, gear box or condenser. LEAD: NASSAU COUNTY is enjoying one of the strongest economic periods in its history. Jobs are plentiful, salaries are among the highest in the nation and business is booming. But the flourishing growth may dry up for lack of a simple necessity: water.

LEAD: The article headed ''Zoning Is Vital to Quality of Life'' [ Opinion Page, March 15 ] , written in answer to Bishop John McGann's fine pastoral letter, is typical of the sophistry commonly offered in opposition to affordable housing. Density is fast becoming a code word for justifying exclusionary zoning practices.

LEAD: IN an art that has come to equate importance with size, Joseph Smith is an attractively reticent pianist. Playing at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night, Mr. Smith made Beethoven's early F minor Sonata a model of Classical grammar, managing to be expressive without ever inflating a relatively contained format beyond its natural boundaries.

LEAD: Europe by Ship Question:Do you have information on the Polish liner Batory which sails from Montreal to Poland? - J. N., Hudson, Fla. Answer:Passengers who want to cross the Atlantic on the Stefan Batory had better do so this year. A spokesman for Polish Ocean Lines said that it had been decided to discontinue the vessel's trans-Atlantic schedule after its four crossings in 1987.

LEAD: To non-weavers, the term interlacing sounds a bit cryptic. The noted textile designer Jack Lenor Larsen and the writer Betty Freudenheim unravel it in INTERLACING: The Elemental Fabric (Kodansha International, $60), a richly illustrated volume that, in contrast to so many books on design, has a distinctly anthropological bent.
LEAD: HOW I GREW By Mary McCarthy. Illustrated. 278 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.

LEAD: New York seems to be winning its war against graffiti in the subways, but many of the graffiti writers are using their spray cans and brushes on alternate targets: bridges, buildings, playgrounds and, particularly, the equipment of the Department of Sanitation.

LEAD: To the Editor: Mr. Kristof's piece on criminal justice in foreign lands claims foreign visitors bring with them their ''mental baggage'' of justice standards to be appplied to the host country, to the point where it may justify intervention in the enforcement of a Draconian sanction. He raises a host of issues that all people traveling abroad, especially to countries with considerably different cultural and/or economic circumstances from his own, should contemplate.

LEAD: Twenty years ago a ward boss on this city's West Side laid down the first rule of Chicago politics. ''Don't make no waves - don't back no losers,'' the ward chief, Bernie Neistein, advised.

LEAD: WHEN world championships are instituted, American selection procedures tend to be haphazard. In 1937 Ely Culbertson selected his own team to play in Budapest, and the United States women's team arrived with just three players. In 1960 the first American women's team in a Team Olympiad included a player who had never before played with any of her teammates.

LEAD: ''Costa Rica chose butter over guns a long time ago. In Central America it would be much better to spend money on economic development or education instead of guns. It is so clear, but nobody does it.'' - President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica. [ 16:6. ]

LEAD: TWO years ago, a data base management program called Reflex was released, and I was rather taken by it. First of all, it was easy to use, and I'm certain that far more software is bought than is ever used, quite simply because learning how to run it is an overwhelming task. But I also liked the program because it surpassed the usual data base manager in its ability to manipulate and analyze the information that it stored.
LEAD: Argentina's civilian Government today delayed moves to crush a mutiny by infantry officers who are demanding amnesty for members of the security forces accused of human-rights abuses.

LEAD: MODERN dance is not a purely American form, having strong roots in Central Europe. Nonetheless, Europe failed to sustain a strong modern-dance tradition after the 1930's, and it is only since the 1970's that dance as a form of individual expression has gained popularity there.

LEAD: PRESIDENT REAGAN retaliated last week against Japanese trading practices that, the Administration said, violated a 1986 computer chip agreement. He imposed tariffs that may double the price of some color television sets, computers and power tools. Retailers said consumers should feel little effect, except for those who buy laptop computers.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Clayton Wesley Frye Jr. of New York and New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carolyn Ann Frye to Michael John Halloran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo A. Halloran of New Canaan.

LEAD: The 106-year-old St. Mary's Seminary, a Roman Catholic high school, will close after graduation on June 13. The Very Rev. Edward Gilbert, provincial of the Baltimore Province of the Redempterist Fathers, which operates the school, said this week that declining enrollment was a major factor.

LEAD: Israeli troops and South Lebanon Army soldiers killed 18 guerrillas early today while driving back an attack by the pro-Iranian Party of God on an outpost in southern Lebanon, a military spokesman said.
LEAD: Following is a selection of hotels, restaurants, pubs and general information. Major credit cards are accepted in hotels and restaurants unless otherwise stated.

LEAD: On the grounds of the rambling suburban estates that burgeoned around the turn-of-the century, the outbuildings were, more often than not, designed in styles similar to the grander main house. As a growing number of these estates are now being subdivided into more managable packages of land, many of the utilitarian structures - like barns, grain houses, stables and chicken coops - have been renovated to become main houses themselves.

LEAD: It's not easy running a ghost town. Just ask Bill and Rex Ivey, who own this crumbling abandoned mercury-mining town near the Mexican border in the dusty reaches of Texas' biggest and loneliest county.

LEAD: ''WHEN you step on it, it screams!'' say advertisements for the Isuzu Turbo Impulse. You don't have to drive it 132 miles per hour, but it is nice to know that you could, Saab says about its new 9000 model. A Chevrolet Beretta lurks like a killer shark under the water in television commercials before exploding to the surface, ready for trouble.
LEAD: New York's oldest family welfare organization, the Community Service Society, is searching for neighborhood groups to help spend $2.7 million for ''the poorest of the poor.''

LEAD: Because of a production error, some copies of the Real Estate section today omitted the continuation from the first page of an article about comparing rents with incomes, and carried the Northeast Notebook twice. LEAD: A bag lady doll being sold at an exclusive Boston store has stirred a protest by advocates for the homeless who say the doll is cruelly exploiting the disadvantaged for profits.

LEAD: The Speaker of the House of Representatives, Jim Wright of Texas, said on Soviet television today that the United States and the Soviet Union ''have a common purpose, and the common purpose is peace.''

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. James T. Jensen of Weston, Mass., and Moultonboro, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Jensen, to Randolph Harrison Barker, a son of Prof. and Mrs. Randolph Barker of Ithaca, N.Y.

LEAD: Rebel soldiers outside a military school they held near Buenos Aires being taunted by civilians. The Government delayed plans to crush the uprising in an effort to avoid bloodshed. Page 17. (AP)

LEAD: IN South America, Argentina and Brazil are to be the proud new owners of ballistic missiles. On the subcontinent, India leads Pakistan in the race to obtain powerful missiles. Asian nations that rim the Pacific - the Koreas, Taiwan, Indonesia - are climbing the technical ladder toward mastery of missile technology.

LEAD: Officials of the Indianapolis Pan American Games organizing committee ended three days of discussions with Cuban sports and Government authorities late Friday night with a 75-minute meeting with President Fidel Castro. The Cuban leader told them he was optimistic that any problems involving the Cuban delegation to the games could be worked out.
LEAD: A little-publicized provision of Federal law that took effect today requires states to plan for the evacuation and medical treatment of people at risk from toxic leaks at chemical plants.

LEAD: The engagement of Amy Weinfeld Schulman to David Eli Nachman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey B. Nachman of Santurce, P.R., has been announced by Alvin H. Schulman of Princeton, N.J., and Ann Schulman of New York, parents of the future bride. The wedding is to be Aug. 16.

LEAD: A 29-year-old Queens woman died when she lay on the tracks in front of an uptown IRT subway train as it pulled into the Union Square-14th Street Station, the transit police said yesterday. The victim was identified as Pamela Dalton, of 141-36 84th Road inFloral Park. The incident occurred at 8:30 P.M.

LEAD: When his son is a teen-ager, Richard Taylor will be in his 80's. The chances of his being at his son's graduation from high school, not to mention college, are minimal. No service was done to little Aristotle Eli when he was born to a man close to 70 and a woman in her early 20's. Rather than being a loving, nurturing event, the birth of Aristotle is another example, albeit a subtle one, of the narcissism of our time.

LEAD: When a 100-year-old farmhouse caught fire recently on a secluded hill over Lake Louise, the siren in this township's fire hall wailed its melancholy summons. But the five men who responded were too little and too late. By the time reinforcements from nearby departments arrived, flames had consumed the house, leaving little more than charred beams and rubble.
LEAD: THE student press here was set back earlier this month when an out-of-court settlement ended a libel suit being heard by a jury and Superior Court Judge Marianne Spinosa Murphy in Morristown.

LEAD: IT is 8 o'clock in the morning, and the assignment editors and the producers of Cable News Network troop into the conference room for their regular morning meeting. There are no pretensions here. The table is too small, so some of the people grab outlying chairs and a few stand. Those who want coffee bring their own - if they can find clean mugs.
LEAD: WHEN a massive glacier trudged north several million years ago, it left behind an interesting piece of geography to the east of the mainland now known as Long Island.

LEAD: The Soviet Union, eager for an agreement to eliminate medium-range missiles in Europe, appears willing to compromise further to get one, according to Congressional Democrats who completed meetings with Soviet leaders today.

LEAD: Here is how Governor Cuomo has attacked, and legislators have defended, the ethics bill approved overwhelmingly by both houses but vetoed last week by the Governor. The bill would have restricted the activities of legislators, legislative employees and all state employees in policy-making positions.

LEAD: Le Mans is an old and honored name for Pontiac cars, and a new model bearing that designation is due for introduction in a few weeks. But the car will be unlike anything Pontiac has ever sold, and its origins illustrate how radically the automobile business has changed in the laste few years.
LEAD: THE State Department of Health Services is setting up a program to advise residents of how to deal with radon after recent tests showed high levels of the gas in some towns.

LEAD: Bo Jackson, baseball's latest early-season phenom, could not have cooled off any faster if he had locked himself in the freezer of a Lower East Side butcher shop or jumped into the Hudson River in January.

LEAD: THE United States has been blessed with a more than adequate food supply, the best and purest food supply in the world. In America, the lowest number of hours in the entire world go into securing food for a family -and therein lies the problem.

LEAD: WHEN John W. Hinckley Jr. was found not guilty by reason of insanity in the shooting of President Reagan, prosecutors and most Americans expected it would be years before he would be allowed even to leave the grounds of St. Elizabeths hospital here.

LEAD: The article in your March 22, 1987, issue, ''Expense Rising for Education of Disabled,'' leaves the reader with the impression that Westchester County provides an abundance of expensive services to the preschool, handicapped population. I am a parent of an 18-month-old boy with Down's Syndrome and was astounded to find that I was unable to secure county-funded services for him until he was 12 months old.

LEAD: THE ''Planctus Mariae,'' as offered at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine Good Friday afternoon, re-enacts the lamentations of the three Marys at the foot of Jesus's cross. This modern version of a 14th-century church drama has been realized by W. L. Smolden and uses four players - the Virgin, Mary Jacobi, Mary Magdalen and John.

LEAD: ONE of Haydn's most fully characteristic works - therefore unique, original and lacking ostentation - is the series of slow instrumental ''sonatas'' on the seven last words of Christ. The cycle was composed about 1786, and later published in arrangements, including one for string quartet that the Juilliard Quartet has often performed.

LEAD: As Australia rises in popularity as a place for Americans to visit, the land Down Under has become -coincidentally - a better and cheaper place for shopping. The attractive prices on Australian-made goods, which until a few years ago were not particulary valued, is a result of the Australian Labor Government's devaluation of the Australian dollar.
LEAD: The Philippine military took a tough new approach today as it quickly put down a small mutiny here led by renegade soldiers apparently loyal to former President Ferdinand E. Marcos.
LEAD: As graduation season approaches, the roar of the stock market is being heard at the nation's top graduate business schools.

LEAD: Howard Stern, the radio morning-show host, had agreed not to say any of the seven words banned from the airwaves for the last decade. But still the complaints came, about Mr. Stern and about other sexually explicit programs and telephone services. And so the Federal Communications Commission decided that seven words were not enough.

LEAD: The Iranians have taken some wild gambles in their war with Iraq. But even they might think twice before attacking a ship belonging to a superpower. That is the reason why Kuwait, which supports Iraq, might hire three Soviet tankers to transport its oil through the Persian Gulf.

LEAD: IF you are a self-employed professional, or a homemaker or salaried worker with a sideline business, a Keogh plan is one of the most attractive ways to accumulate money for retirement. Similar in concept to a corporate retirement or profit-sharing plan, a Keogh plan allows you to make tax-deductible annual contributions to it, and the earnings accumulate tax-free until they are withdrawn at retirement.

But once the new piece began, the space became a cage full of exotic birds, peculiar yet instantly recognizable as they picked their way along the knotty bypaths of modern-day human mating rituals.

LEAD: As a poet and native North American, I read Francisco Goldman's article ''Poetry and Power in Nicaragua'' (March 29) with a blend of relief and wistfulness: relief that I live where I have little to fear because of what I write, and wistfulness that I do not live where what I write commands political or social impact.

LEAD: BILLYBALL. By Billy Martin with Phil Pepe. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Given the stormy reputation of its author, a former manager of the New York Yankees, this book is surprisingly mild in tone and substance. The stated purpose of the volume is to present Billy Martin's views on managerial strategy and tactics.

LEAD: PROPONENTS of a 5-cent increase in the state gasoline tax to finance a renewal of the Transportation Trust Fund are stepping up their efforts to get the tax passed before the present trust fund goes dry in July. As could be expected, they are drawing criticism from tax opponents.

His name wasn't generally known either when he became a major league manager last September. Now, though, his team is making him known.

LEAD: IN ''Past Tense,'' the first volume of his diaries, Jean Cocteau says that ''Gide has never experienced the discomfort of infinity.'' It's a rather catty remark, but it rings true. It reminds me of a photograph I saw of Gide: he was at the opera in Paris, sitting in the orchestra, and over his beautifully domed bald head he had draped a silk scarf.

LEAD: THE nation's fusion-energy program began in 1951 at Princeton University, but fusion-generated power may not be available commerically until 2051. However, every long journey begins with a first step, and Congress appears ready to take it.

LEAD: NOT too long ago, shopping along Greenwich Avenue in stately old Greenwich, Conn., was a strictly local affair. The merchants were familiar figures in the town of 60,000, and the only businesses owned by outsiders were Woolworth's and the telephone company.

LEAD: WHILE the fate of Stratford's beleaguered American Shakespeare Theater remains a matter of mystery and speculation, a student-audience season - the 28th and the shortest in the theater's 32-year history - is scheduled to run from April 27 through May 16.

LEAD: It seemed so simple a year ago: a party to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the opening of the Golden Gate Bridge, the best-known Western gateway to the nation. It would be a $21.9 million civic party, community leaders promised, rivaling the centennial of the Statue of Liberty.

LEAD: DESPITE the Commerce Department's stunning report that the trade deficit remained above $15 billion in February, there is increasing evidence that the country's underlying trade position has begun to improve.

LEAD: STORIES abound about the ways American companies have messed up when they advertised to foreign audiences. ''Finger lickin' good,'' Kentucky Fried Chicken's slogan, once came out as ''eat your fingers off'' in Chinese. And many Asians interpreted Pepsi's ''come alive generation'' as a call to bring back the dead.

LEAD: SOMETHING CURIOUS and paradoxical has happened in the New York museum scene.
LEAD: LORNA Altemus was shopping for a new Jeep when she came upon a magazine article comparing the Suzuki Samurai with several other four-wheel-drive vehicles.

LEAD: Despite protests over the United States decision to impose tariffs on some Japanese electronic products, there is little fear here that the tariffs will touch off a trade war or fundamentally harm the close relations between the two nations.

LEAD: The new president of the American University of Beirut, Dr. Frederic P. Herter, says that despite continued troubles in Lebanon, the independent private university still has ''a major role to play in forming leaders of the Middle East.''

LEAD: THE ''Dynamic Duos'' that were featured in the ''Highlights in Jazz'' program on Thursday evening at the N.Y.U. Loeb Student Center were, in the words of Jack Kleinsinger, host of the series, ''cooking on a low flame.''

LEAD: When an Argentine Army officer refused last week to be questioned in court about allegations of human rights abuses, he precipitated a serious challenge to the three-year-old civilian Government of President Raul Alfonsin.
LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d tried unsuccessfully last week to help find a home for a 67-year-old Long Island land surveyor accused of Nazi war crimes.
LEAD: To the Editor
LEAD: In Italy, mornings are for cappuccino, but in northern Italy, they're also for a tiny cup of syrupy espresso with a shot of fiery grappa, the most Italian of spirits.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Mulry of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Mary Mulry to Douglas Dane Morgan, a son of Jeanette Philipp Morgan of Scottsdale, Ariz., and the late Lacy L. Morgan. The wedding is to be in June.
LEAD: ''S EEK AND LISTEN,'' said the pianist Hilton Ruiz. ''That's what Rahsaan Roland Kirk would always say to me, seek and listen. And that involved a lot of research.''
LEAD: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response from readers. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of those letters.

LEAD: As Central America undergoes the most rapid military buildup in its history, with forceful American participation, civilian government leaders and diplomats are concerned about prospects for weak governments that must deal with the vastly strengthened armies in their countries.

LEAD: TRIXIE IS NOT THE FIRST dog I had after I became an adult, or even the second. I got the first one almost 15 years ago, and named her Mary. She was a gray-furred, blue-eyed Weimaraner. She fell asleep by sucking my thumb until she nodded off. From the day my girlfriend and I carried her from San Francisco to Santa Cruz in a napkin, Mary lived with me - for 10 years.
LEAD: ''WHAT'S making it exciting,'' said Carole Hochman of Manhattan and Quogue, ''are the new things we're doing that are sexy.''

LEAD: The Seaside Heights Borough Council has enacted an ordinance forbidding motorists from driving past certain points three or more times within an hour or six or more times within any three-hour period between 9 P.M. and 4 A.M.

LEAD: You'll hear plenty about the dearth of black managers and executives, but let's not forget that there is also still bias in fielding teams. If many black athletes are superstars, then many must also be excellent or good journeyman players. But at the journeyman level, blacks are often not well represented, as they should be if skill were all that mattered.

LEAD: SHIFTING GEARS Technology, Literature, Culture in Modernist America. By Cecelia Tichi. Illustrated. 310 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $35. Paper, $14.95. A SPEAKER at the elaborate ceremonies marking the opening of the Brooklyn Bridge on May 24, 1883, hailed the span as a great victory in the ''never ending struggle .

LEAD: EVAN EISENBERG'S ''THE Recording Angel: Explorations in Phonography'' (McGraw-Hill) seems to be the first full-length book on the implications and effects of recording on music. It's bursting with ideas, taking up topics from the ties between ritual and music to the compression that 78-rpm records brought to the classic blues.
LEAD: THERE'S something for everyone on this week's music calendar, but if your tastes run to vocal and piano performances, the choices are especially abundant.
LEAD: MANHATTAN '45 By Jan Morris. Illustrated. 273 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $17.95.

LEAD: Testimony in the trial lasted a rancorous nine weeks, with four black journalists accusing the management of The Daily News of racism and The News accusing them of incompetence. Last week the jury agreed with the journalists.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Ackerman of Oceanside, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Joyce Ina Ackerman to Kenneth Ian Siegel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Siegel of Stamford, Conn.

LEAD: THERE'S nothing like taking a close look at the books to give some previously eager baseball investors cold feet. That, anyway, is apparently what happened to Don Drysdale and some fellow plungers who announced a week or so ago that they would buy the Seattle Mariners. Now, however, after studying potential purchase, the group has called the whole thing off.

LEAD: I write to express my full enjoyment of the Long Island Opinion Page Article ''Great Moments (Well, Almost) in L.I. History'' [ March 22 ] . It was a delightful spoof of the Constitution, history and Long Islanders, with special emphasis on their high opinion of themselves - not fully deserved in many cases.

LEAD: Japanese Calm Over Tariffs Japanese are voicing little fear that the American tariffs will touch off a trade war or fundamentally harm the countries' close relations. Page 11.

LEAD: MY workshop is a special place. It is removed from the rest of the house in a corner of the basement away from casual traffic. It is comfortable and familiar. It is my place. It has all kinds of things that are used in home and car repair - wrenches, screwdrivers, saws, hammers, tape rules, assorted nails, screws, nuts and bolts, pliers and some power tools.
LEAD: Sinhalese groups called on the Government today to take a tougher line against Tamil terrorism, a day after 126 people were killed in a guerrilla attack.

LEAD: CONTRACT FOR REPAIRS Question: I recently purchased a studio in a cooperative building. There had been previous water damage to the bathroom ceiling, but the repair job was so poor that the walls are still bumpy and crooked. Before the closing the sponsor's selling agent signed an agreement stating that the sponsor would repair and paint the wall and ceiling by last Jan.

LEAD: The engagement of Beatrice Weeks Bast to Leighton B. Welch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Overman Welch Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Bast of Ambler, Pa., parents of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: The Adirondacks are sometimes called the ''lungs of New York,'' by Manhattanites fleeing city pollution. LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Ronald H. Spiro of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rebecca Elizabeth Spiro, to Robert Jeffrey Shore, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Shore of London, Ontario. The wedding is to be June 7.

LEAD: In his article ''A Fulfillment'' (About Men, March 29), Richard Taylor states, ''My thoughts are free to focus entirely on my wife and baby,'' now that he is an older father and no longer burdened with career, status, income and the many other necessities that take up our ''normal'' child-rearing years.

LEAD: It's hard to find anyone these days who opposes the teaching of values in the public schools. Politicians from President Reagan to Governor Cuomo have made an issue of it, while many educators have repudiated ''values clarification,'' a theory fashionable in the 1960's and 70's that held that teachers should not tell children the difference between right and wrong.

LEAD: REVOLUTION AS ILLICIT LOVE Sometimes a writer exhilarates us with the sheer voluptuousness of his imagination. Ronald Paulson sees the female figure of Liberty in the art of the French Revolution as combining Venus, a virgin state, a charitable woman, a sentimental love object and the mother of the new order.
LEAD: IN a nutshell, the problem in Kennebunkport, Me., was that anyone planning to be buried in the town's last open cemetery had to get in line and wait. Even Vice President Bush.

LEAD: EVER SINCE ITS PREMIERE IN St. Petersburg in 1890, ''The Sleeping Beauty'' has been admired for its sumptuous music by Tchaikovsky and dazzling choreography by Marius Petipa. Yet, if Russia is that ballet's birthplace, Great Britain may be its second home; many important productions of the ballet have taken place in Britain, and others have been staged elsewhere by
LEAD: While some of his rivals for the Presidency are declaring their candidacies in highly publicized events designed for maximum attention on television, Vice President Bush is waiting.
LEAD: FROM REMOVING FIG LEAVES on Italian masterpieces to censoring films in Hong Kong to protecting antiquities in Israel, culture the world over provokes heated debate.

LEAD: The Bronx, whose political leadership has lately hinged more on the ballots cast by grand jurors than on those of ordinary voters, got a new Borough President last week. City Council members from the borough chose Fernando Ferrer for the post, which was vacated last month when Stanley Simon resigned from the office as he was about to be indicted various charges.

LEAD: THE FIRST WORD I HAD OF the plan to create a new space for Japanese art at the Metropolitan Museum came three years ago from a Buddhist priest I met at the Miidera (also known as Onjoji), the imposing temple complex that overlooks Lake Biwa, east of Kyoto. I had gone there, as I had long intended, to pay my respects at the grave of Ernest Fenollosa (1853-1908), the American scholar who did so much not only to introduce Japanese art to the West but to persuade the Japanese, then in the throes of modernization, to preserve their traditional arts.
LEAD: ''RONALD REAGAN,'' THE MOVIE And Other Episodes in Political Demonology. By Michael Paul Rogin. Illustrated. 366 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $25.

LEAD: A LIFE IN MOVIES: An Autobiography. By Michael Powell. (Knopf, $24.95.) The author of this intelligent and superbly written autobiography, the British film director Michael Powell, is known in this country chiefly for the cult ballet movie ''The Red Shoes'' (1948), though some consider the subtly erotic tale of Anglican nuns in the Himalayas, ''Black Narcissus'' (1947), and the benignly decadent, self-reflexive ''Peeping Tom'' (1960) even better.

LEAD: During the last two weeks members of the New York news media have shown me their true colors. While reading the various headlines, I wasn't sure if Gooden was a mass murderer, a key witness in the Iran-Contra affair, or a celebrated AIDS patient. Whatever the case, the Big Apple's journalists have turned their pens on the Doctor: spewing venom rather than ink.

LEAD: AS usual, April has brought its share of rainy, windy days. But the gloom of the weather has been offset by the fresh array of voluminous, richly colored raincoats that women are wearing, most of them every bit as breezy as the elements.

LEAD: If Ronald Reagan is the ''Great Communicator,'' then William Safire is certainly the ''Great Apologist.'' Rather than write what he knows to be true about the President's blundering, Mr. Safire attacks William Casey, Donald Regan, Edwin Meese, even Nancy Reagan - anyone, in fact, but the man who is presumably in command.

LEAD: Ana Maria Allessi and Keith Talbot plan to be married June 21, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Allessi of Cincinnati, have announced. The future bride is an account manager at Marke Communications, a New York retail advertising company. Her fiance, the son of Paul Talbot of New York and Ruth Talbot of Richmond, is producer of ''Kids America'' on WNYC radio.
LEAD: As scientists become increasingly adept at manipulating the molecules of life, the line between the animate and the inanimate becomes ever more indistinct.
LEAD: SLEEK and sassy or sturdy and comfortable, slow to start or quick to stop - whatever the style, many people who've gone on to bigger and better things cling to memories of their first cars.

LEAD: MIND TOOLS: The Five Levels of Mathematical Reality. By Rudy Rucker. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) For those who gave up college mathematics for what seemed more liberal arts, Rudy Rucker's new book, ''Mind Tools,'' is a dazzling refresher course. As in past works, like ''The Fourth Dimension,'' he rekindles the wonder that can come from contemplating logarithms, exponential curves and transcendental numbers.

LEAD: Investigators are seeking the cause of the crash of a small plane that killed all four people aboard. The plane, a Piper Cherokee from Charleston, W.Va., crashed Friday night just off the York-Thomasville Airport's single paved runway, officials said.
LEAD: OF all the hard problems occupying the world's supercomputers, one heads the list: calculating the flow of fluids.
LEAD: Gibson Jazz Concert Phil Woods, Urbie Green, Clark Terry, Dave McKenna, Buddy DeFranco, George Duvivier, Shelly Manne, Johnny Smith and Budd Johnson. Sony Video Software. 53 minutes. $29.95.

LEAD: SONO, as the renovated area of South Norwalk is called, is developing a SoHo look, reminiscent of the rejuvenated art neighborhood south of Houston Street in Manhattan, and so are its new restaurants.

LEAD: Holy Week: the week of Easter, and also of Passover, a week to think of renewal and freedom, as good a week as there is to believe anew that faith can move mountains. In a cathedral in Cape Town and in a mansion in Moscow, people gathered for religious services seemed to believe it.
LEAD: To the Editor

LEAD: A few thoughts concerning Dwight Gooden. 1. The Mets' organization should be rebuked for letting a gem become tarnished. 2. Davey Johnson, the manager, should be dismissed - or at least given a stern reprimand - for being blind to the plight of his star pitcher. It's impossible to believe that he was looking when Gooden was having pitching problems.

LEAD: A GOOD PORTION OF THE PRINCETON HISTORY department usually turns up on Friday mornings in the seminar room deep in the bowels of the Firestone Library. But one Friday last October, the place was jammed and the air was alive with anticipation. Jean-Christophe Agnew, a Yale professor, had ventured into the weekly Shelby Cullom Davis Seminar, a lion's den in which many a historian has been torn apart, to question the very concept that has made the

LEAD: STRIPPING paint or varnish from a valued piece of wood furniture is a time-consuming, tedious job no matter what method is used. However, in many cases it is the only way to restore the original beauty of the natural wood, and it is an essential preparatory step before you can stain or bleach the wood.

LEAD: MORE AND MORE these days, machines are taking over the tasks that some people aren't smart enough to do themselves. If you don't know how to add, all you need is a pocket calculator; and if you don't know how to spell, a modern typewriter can help you out with some computerized orthography. That kind of handy automation has lately come to audio in the form of self-regulating equalizers.

LEAD: NATURE is impressive this time of year. Brown patches in the backyard take on a greenish hue, and trees that only months before were barren, angular silhouettes against the gray horizon suddenly explode into patchworks of colors and shapes. Beautiful shapes that emit beautiful sounds.
LEAD: IT'S just the sort of thing that might make a serious enophile quake with trepidation: a wall-hung vertical rack from which cantilevered wine bottles protrude. But it only looks precarious.

LEAD: THE MOST VISCERALLY EXCITING, mind-expanding movies being made today - the kind that provide windows on worlds previously undreamed of, or that discover the spectacular mysteries within something as commonplace as bird-flight - aren't to be found in conventional theaters, and aren't likely to turn up in theaters soon.

LEAD: Within the marble colonnades of the Academy here, girt by worthy tomes, there is a man who has thought much on Greece and its language. And he has decided that here, in the land of the classics, a heritage is being denied.
LEAD: FROM REMOVING FIG LEAVES on Italian masterpieces to censoring films in Hong Kong to protecting antiquities in Israel, culture the world over provokes heated debate.

LEAD: ROBERT HITCHENS, until recently a salesman for the Spanish International Network in New York, used to find selling advertising on Spanish-language programs a thankless task. ''We kidded about the orders we got: Get out, stay out, don't come back,'' he recalled.
LEAD: A NEW clause in labor contracts was announced in Worcester, Mass.: the dry workday.

LEAD: A chart in Travel Advisory on April 5 misstated room rates for Holiday Inn hotels in London because of incorrect information supplied by the hotel chain. The usual Holiday Inn-Mayfair rates are $:91 to $:110 ($147.60 to $178.40) a night for a room for two; the usual Holiday Inn-Marble Arch rates are $:85 to $:120 ($147.60 to $194.65).
LEAD: TWO LIVES AND A DREAM By Marguerite Yourcenar. Translated by Walter Kaiser in collaboration with the author. 245 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.

LEAD: Roman Celebration April 20 - The American Academy in Rome, in a magnificent Italian Renaissance mansion, has fostered some of the most illustrious talents in American arts and letters since its founding in 1894 as a center for advanced studies. Three composers who spent some of their formative years at the academy - Aaron Copland, Elliott Carter and Lukas Foss - will be honored at a black-tie benefit for the institution at the Equitable Center.
LEAD: Richard Gerson Rosenthal, a New York investment banker, was killed in the crash of a small plane in Westchester County Friday at the age of 45. He was a resident of Briarcliff, N.Y.
LEAD: BOLET IN MONTCLAIR The pianist Jorge Bolet, known for his affinity for Liszt (he has recorded many Liszt works for London/ Decca), will be presented by Unity Concerts in Montclair next Sunday.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Peter Pellegrino of North Andover and Osterville, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carla Anne Pellegrino, to Carlton Penavera-Cabot, a son of Mrs. Louis Wellington Cabot of Boston and Osterville and Jaime Penavera of New York. A July wedding is planned.
LEAD: IN a performance heightened by controversy, Joe Dial soared 19 feet 4 3/4 inches yesterday at the Kansas Relays in Lawrence, Kan., to break his American pole-vault record.

LEAD: STANLEY GULKIN, A TRIM, FIERCELY energetic man in his late 40's, is a tax and corporate lawyer who has, he says, ''worked very hard and done very well.'' At his office in Livingston, N.J., he gets 50 phone calls a day. ''You get pulled in all directions - this is success! It makes me feel important.
LEAD: ON A SMALL scale, but with a success largely unheralded outside of diplomatic circles, American crafts are finding a role as cultural ambassadors to countries with their own craft traditions.
LEAD: The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation of New York has awarded $25,000 grants to 90 young scientists in chemistry, mathematics, economics and neuroscience.
LEAD: Perhaps, since so many of Long Island's business leaders are forecasting gloom and doom, the time has come to review the basic equation for success.

LEAD: To the Editor: In the article on Sanibel Island (Travel, March 8) the author states that Cross Creek, the settlement Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings made famous in her writings, is ''nearby'' the Everglades. That's roughly equivalent to saying, in terms of mileage, that Washington, D.C., is nearby to New York.

LEAD: THE decade was the 1970's and inflation had so warped the economy that some Americans actually hoarded pennies, because soaring copper prices had pushed the value of the copper in each coin above one cent.

LEAD: The Government has named Border Patrol agents, investigators, deportation officers and other enforcement personnel to review applications from illegal aliens seeking legal status under the new immigration law.

LEAD: There was a time when Trinity Place in lower Manhattan was so serene and empty on weekends that ''you could bowl down it,'' said Kenneth A. Ellis, a spokesman for Trinity Church, a city landmark on Broadway at the head of Wall Street. But traffic has mounted along this narrow street that separates the rear of the church from its parish office tower.
LEAD: MY DINNER WITH ANDRE Directed by Louis Malle. Screenplay by Wallace Shawn and Andre Gregory. Produced by George W. George and Beverly Karp. Pacific Arts Video. Color. 1981. 110 minutes. $79.95.
LEAD: We need more courageous people like Branch Rickey, people who aren't afraid to take risks. Al Campanis showed that we as a people have much growing up to do. KEVIN C. LEWIS Staten Island

LEAD: Despite repeated warnings from Federal environmental officials, New York State's system for testing car emissions remains one of the most ineffective in the nation and in some cases is hampered by fraud, according to Government documents and interviews with Federal and state officials.

LEAD: The Rev. Jim Bakker and his wife, Tammy, received nearly $1.6 million in pay and bonuses from the PTL television ministry last year and $640,000 more the last three months, The Charlotte Observer reported today.
LEAD: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response from readers. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of those letters.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Heath of Bannockburn, Ill., of the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Anne Heath to Steven G. Fauntleroy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence G. Fauntleroy of New Canaan, Conn., and Vero Beach, Fla. A Sept. 12 wedding is planned.

LEAD: To hear Amy Carter and her 13 co-defendants tell it, their campus protest trial ended last week with a guilty verdict against the Central Intelligence Agency. Miss Carter, the daughter of former President Jimmy Carter, and the others, including Abbie Hoffman, were acquitted of trespassing and disorderly conduct in connection with a demonstration against C.I.A.

LEAD: ' After spending my life in the city, including 20 years in police, I say what the hell good is jail? It costs too much and we get almost nothing for it, except they don't do a crime while they're in the box. And that's all we get. ' - Richard J. Koehler, New York City Correction Commissioner, discussing the city's overcrowded prisons.
LEAD: SERENISSIMA A Novel of Venice. By Erica Jong. 225 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

LEAD: A barge laden with 3,100 tons of industrial waste from Islip, L.I., will be moved from Louisiana waters because liquid oozing from the bales is seeping into the Gulf of Mexico, a state environmental official said.

LEAD: UNDER the law Congress passed nearly seven years ago to protect the public and the environment from the dangers of abandoned toxic waste dumps, a grand total of 13 sites have been completely cleaned up. Considering that there are tens of thousands of such dumps around the country, perhaps 20,000 of them seriously contaminated, the record can hardly be called impressive.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Oliver J. Thrall 2d of Windsor, Conn., have annnounced the engagement of their daughter Laura Elizabeth Thrall to Kenneth William Kaufman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Kaufman of Armonk, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: I have been asked to verify for those to whom it is not immediately apparent that since the following is a work of fiction (inspired by the recent suit against the movie based on Sylvia Plath's ''Bell Jar'') ''written by'' a person who never existed, the events referred to in it could not have taken place.

LEAD: AFTER a highly publicized meeting with Muammar el-Qaddafi in Crete two years ago, President Francois Mitterrand of France received some of the most intense criticism of his long career. Conservative critics said Mr. Mitterrand had been duped by Colonel Qaddafi while the Libyan leader was in the process of reneging on an agreement by both countries to remove their troops from Chad.

LEAD: Contrary to official assertions, the United States Embassy in Manila knew that President Ferdinand E. Marcos was about to declare martial law in 1972 and did not act to stop him, according to a new book by Raymond Bonner.
LEAD: The Winston Cup stock-car racers have this weekend off, giving them time to think about one thing: how to catch Dale Earnhardt.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Rankin M. Smith of Atlanta have announced the engagement of Mrs. Smith's daughter, Leigh Topping, to Nicholas Frederick Brady Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brady of Far Hills, N.J. A May 30 wedding is planned.

LEAD: A Brooklyn-born bowler who has earned $1,207,707 since joining the Professional Bowlers Association tour in 1970, will be inducted tomorrow into the P.B.A. Hall of Fame in Akron, Ohio. Mark Roth, who is second in career earnings by less than $60,000 to Earl Anthony, will be honored for performances that include winning 32 tour events, leading the tour in average score for five years, most recently in 1981, and being selected as P.B.A.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Becker of Long Island City, Queens, and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Jane Leslie Becker, to Jason Kintzer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Kintzer of Long Beach, L.I. Dr. Becker is a first-year resident in internal medicine at the Montefiore Medical Center.

LEAD: ROY and Cathy Lloyd's three-level town house in Alexandria, Va., was shown on Washington's Channel 7 one chilly Sunday morning in January. That afternoon, 24 people trekked through the Lloyds' two-bedroom home during an open house that had been promoted on the television program that morning. On Monday, more prospective buyers came to look and on Tuesday, a few more trickled in.

LEAD: WENDY PERRON is a quietly arresting performer who moves through a dance with a look of in-turned concentration and great physical delicacy and adroitness. Her dances are like that, too, with a sure, sometimes fierce intelligence driving them along. They curl into space like flowering vines, but a closer look reveals that the vines and tendrils are steely sinew.

LEAD: WESTERN EUROPE, like the United States, is using far more than words in its trade disputes with Japan. Europe, in fact, seized the weapon of duties against Japan well before Washington decided to impose high tariffs, which went into effect Friday, on some Japanese electronic goods in retaliation for the purported ''dumping'' of computer chips at unfairly low prices.

LEAD: THE REV. ALLAN BOESAK, the anti-apartheid leader, spoke out on an issue that is causing increasing concern to South Africans. ''When I think of what this Government is doing to our children,'' he said last week, ''I get so angry that I also feel like saying: I hope there is a God in heaven that can forgive you, for I do not think that I can.

LEAD: ''Three by Three,'' which will be shown on Friday night at 9 on Channel 13, is the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at its most eclectic. Mr. Ailey's ''Blues Suite'' and Donald McKayle's ''Rainbow 'Round My Shoulder'' are fine old repertory works - and American modern dance classics - in the company's distinctive dance-theater style.

LEAD: In his article ''Ten Myths About the Reagan Debacle'' (March 22), I found William Safire's observations to be shrewd and surprisingly objective, as I confess to anticipating an impassioned apologia for the Reagan Administration's indefensible operational blunders.

LEAD: MORE towns than ever are encouraging their residents to dispose of hazardous household waste, such as pesticides, spot removers and disinfectants, through organized collections and supervision by the Department of Environmental Protection.

LEAD: FAYRUZ, a singer whose music has become a symbol of Lebanese unity, performed to an adoring reception Wednesday at Avery Fisher Hall. In the Middle East, where she has been performing for three decades, Fayruz is a superstar, appealing to Christian and Moslem audiences alike; she even appeared on a Lebanese postage stamp.

Dave Anderson, in writing about drugs in other teams in his column of April 2, ended on the prophetic statement ''it was never just one player.'' That day and next, Joseph Durso quoted a number of Gooden's

LEAD: CONSPICUOUS CONSUMPTION is nothing new at the Metropolitan Opera, which was founded, after all, as an amusement of New York's leisure class and until well into this century was almost entirely funded by a handful of bankers and other barons of business. In that dim past, the show of wealth was most evident not onstage, but in a select sector of the audience where the instinct to display fine feathers was as strong as any peacock's.

LEAD: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea had a simple solution to the conflict over how to select a leader to replace him: He suspended the debate over constitutional changes that would decide the issue. But there were some signs last week that his move might only deepen resistance to his rule.

LEAD: The Rev. Charles E. Curran has taken another job, it was announced last week, but that doesn't mean he has quit fighting for his old one. Father Curran, who was suspended as a professor of theology from the Catholic University of America because of his dissent from Vatican doctrine on sexual issues, will be teaching at Cornell University during the next academic year.

LEAD: The marriage of Constance Casari, a copy editor on the cultural news desk of The New York Times, and Steven Reddicliffe, editor of the Part II feature section of New York Newsday, took place yesterday in Lincoln, Neb. The Rev. Dr. Otis Young performed the ceremony at the First Plymouth Congregational

LEAD: THE 1987 New York International Automobile Show opened yesterday at its new home at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, where it is commemorating the 100th anniversary of the first motorcar, patented by Carl Benz in 1886.

LEAD: BOXING Honeyghan Keeps Titles: Lloyd Honeyghan of Britain won a unanimous 12-round decision over Maurice Blocker of the United States in London yesterday to retain his World Boxing Council and International Boxing Federation welterweight championships. The victory, in his second title defense, lifted Honeyghan's record to 30-0.

LEAD: CANADA is giving greater recognition to the economic role played by its Atlantic salmon sport fishery, a development that delights the Atlantic Salmon Federation, a nonprofit conservation organization with branches in that country and the United States.

LEAD: Minna Towbin, research editor of Elle magazine in New York, and Edward B. Pinger, a shipping broker at New England Tanker Chartering in Rowayton, Conn., plan to be married Aug. 1.

LEAD: DISNEY'S EPCOT CENTER in Orlando, Fla., is a technological tour de force and a conceptual desert. In this permanent World's Fair, American industrial giants have built their versions of an unblemished future. These masterful entertainments convey but one message, brilliantly packaged and relentlessly expressed: progress through technology is the solution to all human problems.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL 3-17 U.S. negotiators will 'intensify' their efforts in Geneva to resolve remaining differences with the Soviet Union on the possibility of reducing medium-range nuclear missiles, President Reagan said. Page 1 Military buildups in Central America have civilian leaders worried about long-term prospects as weak governments deal with increasingly strong armies in their countries.
LEAD: To the Editor: Your Feb. 22 article on crafts in New Hampshire's Monadnock region named a few lodging and dining places but neglected to describe bed & breakfast guest homes.
LEAD: WHITE bunnies, real or fluffy velour. Painted hard-boiled eggs, or tiny chocolate ones wrapped in colored foil. They always remind me of this special holiday time.
LEAD: I wish to correct a factual error in remarks attributed to me in the March 29 article titled ''Davids I. Debate Crosses City Borders.''

LEAD: Texaco filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization in a move intended to keep Pennzoil from seizing any assets. Facing a court decision that it must post a $12 billion bond as it appeals a jury award to Pennzoil for interfering with Pennzoil's deal to buy Getty, Texaco said it had no choice after Pennzoil rejected a $2 billion settlement offer.

LEAD: BLONDELL CUMMINGS was charming, witty and poignant last Sunday afternoon when Blondell Cummings and Performers appeared at the Triplex of Manhattan Community College. The troupe was the final attraction in a series of concerts by young choreographers associated with the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival last year.

LEAD: TWO watchdog agencies created by the Republican- controlled General Assembly in 1985 to monitor the workings of the state government have been targeted for extinction by the Democratic majorities in this year's legislature.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 55 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: I am writing to protest some of Dave Anderson's remarks in his column on Dwight Gooden (''Now Mets Know About Gooden,'' The New York Times, April 2). Mr. Anderson asks, ''Has cocaine forever changed his body chemistry that created that spectacular 24-4 season?'' and then engages in a good deal of speculation on that question.
LEAD: The Justice Department has decided not to prosecute Senator Mark O. Hatfield in connection with his relationship with a Greek businessman who paid $55,000 in real estate fees to his wife.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: EVERYONE'S talking about automatic focusing these days, and quite a few photographers think it is the greatest invention since flexible film. But I suspect that few purchasers of auto-focus cameras know how it works, or recognize that there are several kinds of auto focusing, depending on the type and brand of camera.
LEAD: Millions of Americans grew up in houses that looked like this one, and many of those people are still around to remember what living in them was like.
LEAD: FOR the first time since the idea began being bandied about in the early 1970's, there is a good chance Congress will seriously consider a proposal to make the District of Columbia a state.
LEAD: SPRING has made its annual appearance and it's time to put a little air in the bike tires.

LEAD: Mrs. Robert Dessoffy of Alexandria, Va., and Representative Sherwood L. Boehlert of New Hartford, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Tracy A. Boehlert to Palmer G. Suk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Suk of Charlotte, N.C. A May 23 wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S municipally based system of land-use control has badly failed our people. The sorry evidence of that failure is apparent in the congestion on our roadways, the outrageous cost of decent housing, the disappearance of our farms and natural areas and the blight of our cities.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: IF the grass is about three inches tall, start the mowing ritual; be sure cutting blades are sharp and the motor is in good condition. Forsythia in bloom signals application of pre-emergent weed controls to prevent crabgrass and other aggressive lawn weeds from sprouting; also use this form of weed control on service areas and flower borders to prevent nuisance weeds from growing this summer.
LEAD: It's a good week for new music in New York, with many and variegated events taking place all over town.

LEAD: A tractor-trailer overturned after colliding with a car on an eastbound lane of the George Washington Bridge early yesterday, trapping the truck's driver beneath the cab and blocking traffic for more than five hours, the Port Authority said.

LEAD: Forty years ago, Jackie Robinson became the first black man to play major league baseball. However, the struggle for racial equality and equal opportunity in professional sports is obviously far from being complete. The lack of administrative and managerial opportunities for racial minorities is indeed a sad commentary on our nation's commitment to equality and opportunity for all.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ''WE are lonely,'' says Letty Cottin Pogrebin in her new book, ''Among Friends,'' ''but we fear intimacy.''
LEAD: National Guardsmen helped patrol the city's streets today and huge pumps that drain the James River were sandbagged to protect them as the swollen river threatened Richmond.

LEAD: ONE of New York's most delightful experimental singers, Shelley Hirsch brings an impressive stylistic versatility to her explorations of the human voice. Ms. Hirsch, who performed three pieces at Roulette on Thursday evening, portrays all vocal styles - from pure operatic warbling to hard, twangy country singing - as related colors on a continuous vocal spectrum.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Morton Peterson of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Peterson, to Seth Jacobs, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Jacobs of Teaneck, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Thousands of dollars raised by a tax-exempt organization for the Nicaraguan rebels and for conservative causes was paid to a friend of the organization's president and to a concern headed by a friend of the group's executive director, records show.
LEAD: IN a world where few drivers can remember life before cruise control, automakers are scrambling to develop new amenities to win over well-off buyers who are used to being pampered.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Culbertson Hulen of Potomac, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Natalie Spencer Hulen to James Carmen Diana, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph N. Diana of Syracuse. An August wedding is planned. Miss Hulen, who graduated cum laude from Dartmouth College, expects to receive a J.D.

LEAD: WHEN John H. Foster was a boy, growing up in Quincy, Mass., his passion was racing small sailboats in Boston Harbor. ''You always hoped you wouldn't capsize,'' he recalled. ''The water was so full of sewage and when the wind blew from a certain quarter the air was equally foul. What I didn't know then is that the invisible pollutants in the water were even more deadly than the apparent filth.

LEAD: Linda Joyce Rudd, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Rudd of Wellesley, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Joseph Beatty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Beatty of South Yarmouth, Mass. The Rev. Douglas Showalter performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Falmouth, Mass.

LEAD: The family of a 34-year-old exercise physiologist, hospitalized at the Westchester County Medical Center in a vegetative state, has asked a state appeals court for permission to remove a feeding tube - an act that his family said he had indicated he would favor.

LEAD: Oliver Jones did not undertake a full-time jazz career until 1980, when he was 46 years old. By then he had spent the better part of two decades as accompanist and musical director for a Jamaican singer, Kenny Hamilton. However, he was born and grew up in Montreal, three blocks away from the great jazz pianist Oscar Peterson.

LEAD: On paper, the National Cancer Institute appears to be making progress. The survival rate for bladder cancer was 53 percent in 1950 compared with 77 percent in 1982. Improvements also have been reported for patients with breast cancer, lung cancer, colon and rectal cancer and other malignancies.
LEAD: TEXASVILLE By Larry McMurtry. 542 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

LEAD: It seemed like it would take forever to decide which team would face the Philadelphia Flyers for the division championship, and in what would definitely be the longest game in either team's history, the Islanders and Capitals went into the third overtime tonight tied, 2-2.

LEAD: THE jail-population problem in Nassau County, which has bounced in and out of the Federal courts as well as political arenas since 1981, came to the fore again last week when it was learned that 16 prisoners, convicted of felony charges, were inadvertently freed as part of a Federal court-mandated early release program.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH no one seems to mind that the first Swedish settlers in New Jersey did not arrive 350 years ago, the state will participate in New Sweden 88, a celebration of 350 years of Swedish settlement in Delaware and New Jersey.

LEAD: THE decline of rail lines in Connecticut could mean miles of new recreation trails for hikers, bikers, horseback riders and others, under a new program of the State Environmental Protection Department.

LEAD: Dick Shawn, the comic actor who played Hitler in the Mel Brooks movie ''The Producers,'' died Friday night after collapsing in front of an audience that at first thought the fall was a joke. He was 63 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

LEAD: FOR nearly 30 years, Seattle has been trying to build a downtown public square and, later, a shopping mall. Critics say that the effort has become a textbook example of the problems that are inherent in urban planning.

LEAD: Mrs. Eustis Walcott of Boston and David S. Dickenson of Cleveland have announced the engagement of their daughter Martha Stuart Dickenson to Timothy Edward Heath, a son of Ann O. Heath of Newport, R.I., and Richard O. Heath of New Canaan, Conn. An October wedding is planned. Miss Dickenson, a licensing technician for the New England life insurance company in Boston, attended Boston University, of which her fiance is a graduate.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Emmet M. Showalter 3d of Albuquerque, N.M., of the engagement of their daughter Sarah Joan Showalter to Morgan J. Murray Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray of Morristown, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: IT'S been almost a year since Mark Matthews played 724 holes of golf in a hectic 24 hours at the Rockwood Golf Course in Fort Worth, Tex., a feat that raised $10,000 for charity last June. Now the 25-year-old Matthews has gotten his reward. He has been notified that his effort has been certified and accepted as a world record by the Guinness Book of World Records.

LEAD: Polo is seductive: galloping speed and hazard, enthusiasm and thundering horses are alluring everywhere, and on the north coast of Oahu, where shadowy green mountains form a backdrop, the game is wrapped up in sunlight on a field framed by coco and ironwood trees. In Hawaii the sport becomes an island vacation as well, with matches and tournaments to watch every Sunday, and all the requisites of luxury living in the country.

LEAD: LAST year the state legislature allocated $13 million to help communities start programs to recycle garbage. Last week the Environment Committee of the legislature unanimously recommended a compulsory recycling measure to put the law where the money is.

LEAD: Jean S. Harris, who is serving a 15-year sentence at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility for the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower, has won the nonfiction award of the Westchester Library Association with her book, ''Stranger in Two Worlds.''

LEAD: The question is really ''How big a problem is racism in the nation?'' Sports mirrors the larger society. The presence of the Abdul-Jabbars, Robinsons and Strawberrys in sports, as well as black superstars in other fields, may give one the impression that racism is a dying monster, but it is not. The monster changes form but does not die.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: There is a glutted file in this department where copies of travelers' letters of complaint accumulate. Some are heartrending, some are amazing; all are angry. The opposite of the little black box that emits applause sounds when the lid is lifted, this file drawer seems to give off steam and sounds of fury when opened.

LEAD: IT would be difficult enough for the Soviet Union and the United States to agree on reducing nuclear arms if their negotiators could simply lock themselves in a windowless room and deal dispassionately in the intricate calculus of complex weaponry. But the outside world intrudes; political emotion, theatrics and imagery also have seats at the bargaining table.
LEAD: A COUPLE of years ago a young man was given what he considers a major gift: a friend introduced him to the Conservatory Garden, a quiet, symmetrical oasis in the upper reaches of Central Park.

LEAD: A bright pile of yellow flowers, fresh cut from this nation's spring treasure of blossoming fields, was all that punctuated the Good Friday hush when Jesus was pronounced dead once more in the church of Berne Abbey.

LEAD: To the Editor: In ''Dealing With the Law of the Land'' (Travel, Feb. 15), Nicholas D. Kristof writes, ''Imposing our values on a foreign culture is less of a sin than participating in such excesses as amputation or execution by flogging.'' This kind of arrogance makes the blood of many believing Muslims boil.

LEAD: OFFICIALS of this Union County city, where industrial and commercial properties take up 50 percent of the developed land, would like to see the municipally owned, 188-acre airport put to better use.
LEAD: During the last week I was in Poland as a correspondent, three people tried separately to entrap me - a doctor, a writer, an architect.

LEAD: IN April and May asparagus is cheap and plentiful. It comes in many sizes, from thin as a pencil to almost as thick as sugar cane. All sizes are good - whether you like your asparagus served hot with melted butter and lemon juice or cold with a vinaigrette. But after awhile, I like to be more adventurous, and serve asparagus with a puree of red peppers sprinkled with fresh tarragon or, as the Italians do, with Parmesan cheese and baked in a hot oven.

LEAD: FABIO'S features food with a bossa nova beat. This Brazilian restaurant is one of Huntington's newest and most visually arresting eating places. A pink exterior highlighted by an aqua blue awning and painted palm trees previews the interior decor and the Latin American food featured here.
LEAD: A state appeals court has ordered a new trial for a black man convicted of a weapons charge, finding that a Brooklyn prosecutor's repeated references to race could have prejudiced the jury.

LEAD: IT is perhaps the most famous car never sold. The first commercial Saturn, General Motors's high-technology gamble designed to compete with Japanese manufacturers, will not roll off an assembly line until the 1990's. Yet, for more than two years, the car has been the subject of more speculation, hype and hope than almost any other product in the

LEAD: WHAT do you do on a day when you have an awful premonition that things are going to go wrong? Don't play. Yes, that's right - don't play. Because a feeling like that is invariably a valid foreboding, no matter whether it originates in unsynchronized biorhythms or any other way of being out of sorts.

LEAD: THIS is the period known as ''the invisible primary,'' the stage of the Presidential campaign when candidates run almost no television commercials and receive no votes. It is the time for battling for staff, struggling for campaign money and skirmishing for the hearts and hands of the party activists who do the unheralded work of democracy.

LEAD: IRANIANS in Southern California rarely stay up to watch Johnny Carson these days. Instead, they get up to catch Parvis Afshar, the Iranian version of America's late-night comedian. Each weekday morning at 7 a.m., KSCI in San Bernadino broadcasts Mr. Afshar's ''Sima-E-Ashena,'' an hour-long Persian-language show of news, commentary and interviews.

LEAD: Dr. Martha Cortes, a clinical instructor of dentistry at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine of the City University of New York, plans to be married June 20 to Dr. David Gaudino, a surgical resident at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

LEAD: Fog shrouded the Charles River today, causing difficulties in the opening races of this morning's regatta. But it lifted for the varsity race, allowing spectators to witness Harvard's heavyweight varsity draw away to victory over Princeton and capture the Compton Cup.
LEAD: ANYONE who has searched for an affordable apartment in New York probably has heard about rich people who live in rent-regulated buildings and pay rents that look like grocery bills.

LEAD: COMPANIES Dome Petroleum said it had accepted a bid by Amoco, prompting a political storm in Canada over how such a move would increase the already dominant position of U.S. companies in the Canadian oil and gas industry. [ Page D1. ] NASA's renewal of a Morton Thiokol contract was criticized by Congress and rival rocket manufacturers.
LEAD: The Exxon Corporation's petrochemicals business is enjoying good times. Profits are rising, demand is brisk and most of its plants are operating nearly flat out.

LEAD: About 8,000 employees of Safeway Stores Inc. in northern Texas will join the ranks of the unemployed on Friday. The chain is selling or closing 131 of its Dallas division stores, along with processing and distribution systems in the Dallas suburb of Garland. Safeway announced the action April 3, saying it was part of the company's restructuring in order to become more competitive.

LEAD: Three years after the Supreme Court struck down the legal underpinnings of gains that female collegians had made under Title IX, women's athletic organizations foresee a brighter day for themselves this summer. That's when Congress seems likely to pass the Civil Rights Restoration Act, which among other things would reverse the Court's Grove

LEAD: Although the owners of a barge loaded with 3,100 tons of industrial waste from Islip, L.I., have agreed to move it from an oil rig where it was moored, the vessel will be a hazard as long as it's in the Gulf of Mexico, the Mayor of a barrier island said yesterday.

LEAD: In Florida the State Senate and House of Representatives passed bills last week authorizing a new tax package that would include a 5 percent sales tax on advertising in all media. Today a conference committee will try to iron out differences between the two versions.
