LEAD: Diving into a trough west of the Marianas Islands, in the western Pacific, the submersible Alvin has discovered pits resembling ''woks completely full of writhing snails, shrimps and crabs'' according to an account radioed from the mother ship Atlantis II.

LEAD: Sales of Government securities this week include today's $13.2 billion auction of new Treasury bills equally divided between the three- and six-months maturities. On Wednesday dealer attention will turn to a $10 billion issue of new 2-year bills, which are auctioned by the Treasury on a monthly basis.

LEAD: Antony Tudor, one of the foremost choreographers of the century and widely considered the master of the psychological ballet, died last night of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 78 years old. Mr. Tudor, choreographer emeritus of the American Ballet Theater at his death, revolutionized ballet with his introduction of strong psychological motivation in choreography, reflecting the influence of Freudian thought.
LEAD: The crowd wore fake grass and bunny ears, purple eggs and lots of lace.
LEAD: A girl whose arm was bitten off by a shark remained hospitalized in serious condition today, but officials said they would not close beaches to the thousands of Easter weekend visitors.

LEAD: Two Israeli soldiers and three Palestinian guerrillas were killed today in a shootout after the Palestinians cut through a Lebanon border fence and crossed into northern Israel, an Israeli Army spokesman said.

LEAD: The C.S.S. Georgia, a 10-gun ironclad that helped guard Savannah from the Union Navy during the Civil War, has been added to the National Register of Historic Places even though the vessel lies 30 feet underwater. She was scuttled in the Savannah River in 1864 when Gen. William T. Sherman's troops captured Savannah.

LEAD: Gustav Oswald Lienhard, who guided the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation as it became the country's richest source of grants in the field of health care, died of cancer Friday at his home. He was 81 years old and lived in Edison, N.J.

LEAD: Grey Advertising, Los Angeles, which until recently had the $15 million Vons Grocery Company account, has been named agency for both the Northern Food and Southern Food divisions of California's Lucky Stores Inc. The account should bill around $30 million, the agency said.

LEAD: After four years of secret talks, the United States and six allies have put a new obstacle in the path of proliferating nuclear capabilities. They agreed to strong controls on the export of missiles and missile technologies that can be used to deliver nuclear weapons. This is a real arms control achievement at a critical time.
LEAD: Schering-Plough, which already uses the Della Femina, Travisano & Partners ad agency, has given it another assignment: Feen-a-Mint, a product of the Personal Care Group.

LEAD: WALL STREET analysts are predicting continued growth for the second quarter and second half of 1987 for the leading computer manufacturers, some of which reported strong results last week. Despite the generally bullish tone, though, many of the stocks closed off a few points Thursday, the last day of trading in a holiday-shortened week, as wary investors sold on the good news.

LEAD: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, attended Easter Sunday services at a Presybterian church here, taking hundreds of congregants by surprise. A white cloth with the words ''Christ is Risen'' greeted the Reagans as they shook hands with the Rev. Robert Pryor, the church's pastor. Because of security concerns, little advance notice was given to the First Presbyterian Church, and the Reagans traveled to the church in a car without a police escort.

LEAD: SOME ''alternative'' broadcasting entities talk confidently about producing sitcoms that are not likely to be found on the presumably more conservative or timid commercial networks. The pay-cable service has already delivered innovative series such as ''Brothers'' and ''It's Garry Shandling's Show.

LEAD: IT often happens that musical works requiring unusually large (or simply unusual) performing forces must be scaled down in order to circulate beyond the big institutions and special occasions for which they are made. Wagner's music dramas are given all the time with reduced orchestrations; big Parisian operas were routinely cut to workable lengths for other audiences.

LEAD: TENNIS Graf Sweeps Mandlikova: Top-seeded Steffi Graf defeated second-seeded Hana Mandlikova, 6-3, 6-4, yesterday to win the Women's International Tennis Association Championships at Amelia Island Plantation in Florida. Graf, a 17-year-old ranked second in the world, has won 22 consecutive matches.

LEAD: Scientists have succeeded for the first time in photographing the individual atoms in a newly discovered superconducting material, revealing a surprising host of tiny flaws that may be a key to its extraordinary electrical properties.
LEAD: An average of 1.2 million robberies occurred annually in the United States from 1973 to 1984, according to a Justice Department report released today.

LEAD: Maybe getting away from Washington had something to do with it. Or maybe it was just the passage of time. Or perhaps it was the new approach to running the White House that began earlier, back in the capital, with a new management team in place.
LEAD: * Affiliated Bankshares of Colorado Inc., Boulder, Colo., said Kent O. Olin, president and chief operating officer, had been named to the additional post of chief executive officer.

LEAD: It wasn't as momentous as the splitting of the atom, but the world should note that a contest to acclaim the best chicken soup was held the other day. No lives were lost. No governments fell. The sun also rose the next morning.

LEAD: Glenn Hubbard's fielding error at second base with two out in the ninth inning enabled Chris Brown to score from third and give the San Francisco Giants a 4-3 victory over the Atlanta Braves today.

LEAD: THE closing within the last two years of Jimmy Ryan's, Eddie Condon's, Hanratty's and the Red Blazer Too wiped out almost every venue in town where traditional jazz could be heard regularly. But things are now looking up for jazz traditionalists with the reopening of the Red Blazer Too at 349 West 46th Street, instead of its previous Upper East

LEAD: IT was hockey, but as the skaters skimmed slowly into quadruple overtime, the scene resembled the gradual disintegration of a marathon dance contest. The pace slowed, and the progression up and down the ice toward goals that suddenly loomed imposing as brick walls looked almost surreal. Even the ice seemed to respire, as if in weariness, and long glaring puddles formed at random on its surface.

LEAD: Dith Pran, the Cambodian journalist whose four-year ordeal under the Khmer Rouge and escape in 1979 was portrayed in a film, ''The Killing Fields,'' urged the Cambodian Government yesterday to let his ailing mother come to the United States for medical treatment.

LEAD: Heavy trucks, harsh weather and time are chipping away at bridges, highways and roads in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, turning a transportation network once worthy of envy into a continuing financial burden.

LEAD: Cynthia Beck is a recent arrival at Young & Rubicam, where she is a vice president and associate creative director. She is also the writer half of a team whose art direction comes from John Triolo, senior vice president and also an associate creative director.

LEAD: At offices and taverns around the country during the next two weeks, people who usually pay no attention to horse racing will be asked to cough up a dollar or two and pick from a hat the name of one of this year's Kentucky Derby entrants.
LEAD: Mickey Mantle was at Yankee Stadium yesterday, performing his cable-television broadcasting assignment and looking healthy one week after a heart-attack scare during a flight to Dallas.

LEAD: In a shattering display of raw force, South Korean combat policemen broke up a street demonstration today almost before it could begin, rounding up scores of anti-Government students and punching and kicking many of them.
LEAD: Two giant pandas arrived safely in New York City this weekend after a flight of more than 20 hours from China.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Representatives of National Football League players and owners are scheduled to meet here Monday to begin what could be long and arduous negotiations leading to a new collective bargaining agreement.

LEAD: It's back to basics for Tom Petty, the Florida-born, Los Angeles-based rocker who has been making best-selling albums for a decade. The last album by Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, ''Southern Accents,'' took two years to record; ''Let Me Up (I've Had Enough)'' (MCA Records), which will be released today, took a month of basic sessions and another of polishing.

LEAD: The trouble, it seems, is that the canine nose just isn't good enough. The United States Customs Service, alarmed at the large amounts of cocaine and heroin that slip into this country undetected, has awarded a preliminary $90,000 contract to a Massachusetts biotechnology company to develop a device that, if it works, would be 1,000 times more sensitive to the presence of drugs than trained dogs are.

LEAD: Proposals for social action and challenges by powerful institutional investors to anti-takeover plans are on a record number of annual meeting agendas this year, according to organizations that monitor shareholder resolutions.
LEAD: Two teen-age boys from Virginia died of carbon monoxide poisoning in a double suicide this weekend in rural south-central Pennsylvania, the authorities said.
LEAD: ALTHOUGH fly fishermen represent only a small percentage of the millions of anglers in this country, they do not suffer for lack of attention by the manufacturers of their equipage.
LEAD: A new study by the Environmental Protection Agency has found that chlordane, a pesticide used in millions of homes to control termites, can pose a high risk of cancer even when properly used.

LEAD: Merrill Lynch Capital Partners Inc. said yesterday that it had received commitments from three major banks for $3.4 billion in financing for its previously announced acquisition of the Borg-Warner Corporation.
LEAD: * James A. Voss-Grumish, executive director/broadcast production, elected to senior vice president at Campbell-Mithun, Minneapolis.

LEAD: On its most immediate level, Robert Penn Warren's novel ''All the King's Men'' follows the rise and fall of the populist demagogue Willie Stark, the fictional equivalent of Huey Long. At the same time, the book tells the story of Jack Burden, the reporter as historian, a character whom the author has described as ''intelligent enough to understand everything except himself.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: After seven days of talking and listening to hundreds of constituents in 15 towns across western New York State, Daniel Patrick Moynihan might have shown a trace of flagging energy or interest.

LEAD: A comprehensive global family planning strategy is needed to keep accelerating world population growth from outpacing available resources, according to a report made public today by the Population Institute.
LEAD: A human-rights group has protested the barring from the United Nations building of a woman who is seeking compensation for families of the victims of a 1972 massacre in Burundi.

LEAD: Guy Kawasaki joined Apple Computer Inc. in 1983, when the Macintosh personal computer was still perceived by software developers as innovative, but too slow and lacking in power to appeal to business users. His job as self-described ''software evangelist'' was to ''use fervor and zeal to convince developers'' to write programs for the new machine.

LEAD: As President Reagan awaits new Government recommendations on altering counterespionage policy, present and former intelligence officials said that the problems were already well known but that the Government apparently lacked the resolve to solve them.
LEAD: President Raul Alfonsin went to an army base this afternoon and persuaded rebellious officers there to surrender, ending a four-day mutiny.

LEAD: HIGH above the main auditorium of the Brooklyn Academy of Music is a handsome loft called the Lepercq Space. It was here that Tania Leon led members of the Brooklyn Philharmonic in a program of music by Hispanic-American composers Saturday afternoon, as part of the orchestra's series of family and community concerts.

LEAD: * Avnet Inc. is offering $100 million of A-2/A+ rated 6 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2012 at a price of 100 through Dillon, Read. Noncallable for 2 years, the debentures are convertible into the company's common stock at $43 a share.
LEAD: A legal battle is being waged that could have a major impact on how community facilities - schools, churches and doctors' offices - are built in New York City's residential neighborhoods.

LEAD: A gunman opened fire last night in a crowded plaza just inside the main gate of the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park in Jackson, N.J., wounding a 23-year-old man and sending dozens of other people running for safety, the police and Great Adventure officials said.

LEAD: A Hare Krishna follower who is serving a life prison term for the murder of another member of the sect has sued state prison officials, asserting that they have denied him the right to worship according to his religion.

LEAD: A new Justice Department booklet, ''Enforcing the Law,'' was written as a benign report to inform members of Congress, journalists and high school and college students about what the department does and how it does it.

LEAD: Before a reactor exploded at the Chernobyl nuclear power station in the Ukraine a year ago, officials at the Bilibino atomic energy station had not thought of how they might evacuate residents from this industrialized island in the tundra of northeast Siberia.
LEAD: The body of a 36-year-old minister, apparently the victim of a burglary, was found yesterday afternoon in his living quarters behind a storefront church in Brooklyn, the police said.
LEAD: Mike Gartner, like almost all the members of the Capitals, was planning a trip to Philadelphia even before the deciding game of the playoff series against the Islanders.

LEAD: John Tudor was sitting in the St. Louis Cardinals' dugout, minding his own business today when Barry Lyons, the rookie catcher for the Mets, came running over, chasing a foul pop fly. That led to a bizarre accident that disabled Tudor for three months or more. It was the kind of accident that sometimes alters careers and championships.
LEAD: Columbia University has filed suit against two attorneys, charging that they abused the judicial process in their attempt to overturn the eviction of a woman from a university-owned building.
LEAD: It's not the ordinary home-court advantage. That's why it was so important that Atlanta get it.

LEAD: Whether shipbuilder or baseball club owner, George Steinbrenner has obviously been involved in the wrong line of work all these years. The efforts of the Yankees' starting pitchers in yesterday's doubleheader attest to the idea that Steinbrenner should be a baseball scout.
LEAD: The mood in the locker room reflected a collective relief, the release of an emotion held inside for months. Finally, there were no more games, no more nights for the Knicks to endure defeat.

LEAD: For some time, a feeling has been growing in the Reagan Administration that West Germany will probably not allow the extradition of a Lebanese, Mohammed Ali Hamadei, to this country to face charges of air piracy and murder in connection with the hijacking of an airliner to Beirut in 1985 and the death of a United States Navy diver who was among the passengers.
LEAD: Henry E. Kates, the new president of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, has added a touch of culture to the business of the old-line Newark-based insurer.
LEAD: President Reagan will be urged to consolidate some of the Administration's covert operations overseas and to end others that are considered outdated, a White House official said today.

LEAD: Elizabeth Dole, the Secretary of Transportation, came to town last week to address a conference celebrating the centennial of the International Herald Tribune. She was vigorous, charming, Reaganesque in her hearty advocacy of taking government out of business, deregulating, letting money talk. She sounded superconfident.

LEAD: If there's a heaven on earth for football coaches, Roger (Dutch) Ouderkirk may have found it not far from the Arctic Circle. Ouderkirk, a 62-year-old assistant in charge of running backs at St. John's, enjoys relaxed summertime employment, a certain local acclaim and the life of Riley, all in the town of Hyvinkaa, Finland.

LEAD: Instead of celebrating this 200th year of the United States Constitution, scholars and legal experts are ''cerebrating.'' Meanwhile, the New York State Constitution, which is older and longer - at times unfathomably longer - doesn't even warrant a public seminar on its 210th birthday, which happens to be today.
LEAD: After a harrowing plunge in bond prices early last week, the market in long-term fixed-income securities came roaring back to close essentially unchanged from the previous Friday.
LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's second-largest bank holding company, has asked stockholders to increase its authorized number of common shares to 300 million, from 200 million.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: QUESTION: Bo Jackson's sensational start this season revived memories of another running back from a college in the South who had to choose between baseball and football, Charley Trippi. How much success did Trippi have in pro football? Did he ever play in the major leagues in baseball? Trippi never played in the majors after he chose football over baseball and he never regretted it because he made it to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1968, 13 years after he retired.

LEAD: Annette Strauss, a City Councilwoman, on Saturday became the first woman elected Mayor here, capping a year of extraordinary ferment in Dallas with a decisive runoff election victory over Fred Meyer, a businessman.

LEAD: Tom Grundner survived. He pulled a hamstring, he ached all over without respite, and fatigue was a loyal companion, but he got through all four weeks of drills with Eastern Michigan University's football team.
LEAD: The Houston Astros have reinstated Dickie Thon and assigned the shortstop to their Class AAA Tucson team in the Pacific Coast League.

LEAD: The medium-range missile treaty is all but wrapped up; short-range missile reduction is a sweetener just tossed in the deal; a space exploration treaty awaits signing at a summit; the old ABM treaty will be saved in the next year when a new treaty is agreed on to permit space-shield testing.

LEAD: As part of an effort to update its stockpile of strategic metals, the Government said it planned to buy up to 2,000 kilograms of germanium, a grayish-white metallic element of the carbon family that occurs in trace quantities in the mining of other minerals and in coal.

LEAD: FAMILY relationships are getting more attention in the treatment of anorexia nervosa, an eating disorder that primarily affects teen-age girls and young women. Mental health experts say that families can help alleviate conditions that contribute to the disease.

LEAD: A little over half a century ago, Ely Culbertson's considerable talent for terminology for once failed him. LEAD: The number of refugees fleeing Cuba to Florida by water in makeshift rafts has picked up in recent weeks, leading to speculation that pressure for another major exodus may be building up on the island.

LEAD: THREE years ago, Wendy Yuni Hoffman began to have memories of having been molested as a child by members of her family. Out of those memories came ''Incest,'' a theater-dance piece performed on Saturday at Eden's Expressway in SoHo.

LEAD: Charles Hudson of Yankees, top, pitching shutout against Royals. Dale Sveum, left, celebrating Brewers' 12th straight victory. Cardinals' John Tudor being helped after suffering knee injury in a dugout collision with Mets' Barry Lyons. (AP)
LEAD: Talk about the unthinkable: The Mets, who arrived here this weekend in first place with a three-game winning streak, left today in second place with a three-game losing streak.

LEAD: If all goes as planned, at midnight tonight the 14 members of the 1987 Whiffenpoofs will assemble at Harkness Tower for ''Tap Night.'' With crowds of observers in pursuit they will run through the Yale University campus, stopping at the rooms of the students who have been selected to be next year's Whiffenpoofs, the fabled a capella group.

LEAD: Boss Tweed had an enduring ring to his name, but mention Tammany protege Robert Van Wyck nowadays and what comes to mind is the Queens expressway dedicated to his distant relative, Abraham Van Wyck.

LEAD: After two weeks of mind-warping triumph and tragedy, with clocks ticking at elbows like timebombs and dozens of world-class egos on the line, one of the nation's richest and most prestigious chess tournaments ended yesterday with fireworks and a fizzle.
LEAD: A plan by the space agency to greatly increase the amount it pays Morton Thiokol Inc. to build the space shuttle's booster rockets has drawn criticism in Congress and from rival manufacturers.
LEAD: TRUST ME. Short Stories. By John Updike. 302 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

LEAD: Big season openings have a special magic, and American Ballet Theater's eight-week spring engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House is one of the biggest of the dance year. Glamorous types will mill about the Met lobby tonight for Ballet Theater's opening. Last-minute worries and triumphs will preoccupy those who put the ballet on the stage.
LEAD: What V. B. Jayasuriya remembers most clearly was the cool, businesslike way the massacre happened.

LEAD: Abused and other vulnerable children and the chronically ill elderly have been illegally denied services by the Reagan Administration, which has withheld millions of dollars in congressionally approved aid, according to a report made public today by a House panel.

LEAD: The Talking Deals column in Business Day on Thursday misstated a bankruptcy judge's ruling on salaries of Texaco Inc.'s officers. Judge Howard Schwartzberg ruled that the salaries of Texaco's top 20 officers were not to exceed $2,000 each for the 11 days before Texaco's bankruptcy filing April 12 but that there would be no restrictions during bankruptcy.

LEAD: TWO masses at Carnegie Hall Saturday evening commemorated perhaps the darkest moment of the Christian year - the night before Christ's Resurrection. As sung and played by the Gachinger Kantorei of Stuttgart and the National Arts Center Orchestra of Canada, Haydn's ''Lord Nelson'' and the Mozart ''Requiem'' offered - at least superficially - two very similar faces.

LEAD: These are the times that swell the hearts and fill the pockets of gold bugs, that hardy band of investors in precious metals who thrive on economic misery. While Wall Street may mock gold as a ''sterile investment'' or ''barbaric relic,'' the recent sharp rise in gold and silver prices has given investors in stocks and bonds much to worry about.
LEAD: The Dayton Marriott Hotel closed most of its kitchens for the weekend to try to stop an outbreak of food poisoning.

LEAD: For a cultural institution, the Terra Museum of American Art has had a meteoric career. The latest entry in what seems to be an increasing trend toward private museums, it started out seven years ago with a highly personal selection of paintings - dating mainly from 1850 to 1900 - installed in a former florist's shop in nearby Evanston.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Fear has gripped this sylvan duck-pond paradise on the New York border. The gentry are troubled that their town of stately mansions and Mercedes-Benzes soon might become home to a truck weigh station.

LEAD: More than 200 years ago, Columbia College proclaimed its independence from England, putting an end to the problems of crown and gown. This month, as it celebrates the bicentennial of its charter, Columbia finds itself once again in an uneasy relationship - brought about this time by problems of town and gown.

LEAD: A catamaran sailed by Bruno Peyron, the French ocean racer, limped across the finish line on the Southwest coast of England yesterday to set a trans-Atlantic record, despite crashing into rocks three hours earlier.

LEAD: Five of the nation's largest investment banking firms have joined forces in an effort to persuade the Government to bar the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, from the newest and one of the most lucrative mortgage underwriting markets.

LEAD: What's a cut in a Federal program? What's an increase? If you put these two questions to the average person, they probably would tell you that a cut is when some program is to get less money this year than it got last year. Or, in the case of an increase, more money this year than last year. If you pressed the person, he or she might adjust these numbers for inflation - that is, a cut or an increase in real terms compared to last year.

LEAD: John Paul on Fifth Avenue yesterday giving out balloons to passers-by as Christians around the world celebrated the most holy and joyous day of the church year. Pages B1 and B7. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)
LEAD: The newsstand at the busy Lewites Market in Managua offers a limited selection of periodicals, and even the proprietor, Ramon Ramirez, says he cannot find much that he wants to read.

LEAD: It's been a decade since the Fordham Rams had a real live ram to call a mascot of their own. Now Frank McLaughlin, who took over as athletic director a year and a half ago, is determined to revive the tradition, although so far he's been butting his head against the wall.

LEAD: Rob Deer hit a three-run home run to tie the score and Dale Sveum won the game with a two-run shot as the Milwaukee Brewers rallied for five runs in the ninth inning today to beat the Texas Rangers, 6-4, and set an American League record with their 12th straight victory to start the season.

LEAD: Davis Love 3d won the Heritage Classic today when Steve Jones drove out of bounds and scored a double-bogey 6 on the 18thhole.

LEAD: Each spring, just as the crocuses wilt, the Pentagon's printing presses churn out a tulip-red broadsheet entitled ''Soviet Military Power.'' LEAD: IN two weeks, Xi-Qing Gao, a 33-year-old associate at a large New York firm, is scheduled to be sworn before a judge to practice law in the United States. Last summer he became the first citizen of China to pass the New York Bar examination.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The Supreme Court upheld a state curb on hostile takeovers for companies incorporated in that state. The 6-to-3 ruling, which sustained an Indiana law, was an important victory for companies seeking takeover protection. Under the law, a company could deny voting rights to those making tender offers or to any investors who increase their holdings above a certain level.

LEAD: FORGET the image of the male grocery shopper of the 1950's: sent to the store for a can of peaches, he came home with a sheepish look and a jar of chocolate-covered ants. Working women and job-sharing at home have changed all that. LEAD: IN an America rocked by inside traders on Wall Street, ethically blind managers in the space program and shredded documents in the National Security Council, no one can doubt the continued pertinence of ''All My Sons.'' Though four decades old, Arthur Miller's first Broadway success tells a story that really can be found in today's newspapers: The protagonist, a businessman named Joe Keller, stands accused of having covered up his role in manufacturing defective parts that doomed 21 Air Force planes in World War II.

LEAD: ''THE BOMB FACTORIES'' persuades us that nuclear-weapons plants have safety problems. It leaves us unclear, though, about the size, shape and nature of the risk. Some technical information in the ABC News documentary is difficult to absorb; some of its targets seem too easy. The documentary, on Channel 7 at 10 o'clock tomorrow night, is ambitious and smartly done, but occasionally its reporting grows confusing.

LEAD: When Arnold Scaasi walks into a charity ball in New York - which he might do several times a week - he greets the chairwoman and tells her how beautiful she looks in her Scaasi dress. The 37-year-old Spencer is awaiting trial on charges arising from the kidnapping and fatal shooting of 29-year-old Michael Dalfo.

LEAD: A protest strike by residents of Soweto, Johannesburg's sprawling black satellite city, appeared to gain momentum today as tensions remained high after six black workers were killed by the police.

LEAD: Larry Bethea, a former defensive lineman for the Dallas Cowboys, died today of an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound within hours of being identified as a suspect in two armed robberies, the police said. He was 30 years old.

LEAD: Nana Vasconcelos and Arto Tuncboyaci, Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street (242-3374). If an instrument can be tapped, scraped, shaken, hit or rung, it's likely that one of the two master percussionists at this concert can make music with it. Nana Vasconcelos, a Brazilian, is well known to fans of jazz and new music around New York; along with his arsenal of percussion instruments, he uses his own body - clapping hands, tapping cheeks, singing in an open-toned tenor and a sweet falsetto - for even more sounds.

LEAD: Hockey First Victory for U.S.: The United States gained its first victory at the world ice hockey championships in Vienna yesterday, winning by 6-4 from a West German team that was stripped of two earlier victories. The International Hockey Federation, the sport's governing body, overturned West Germany's upset victories over Finland and Canada after ruling that a Polish-born defenseman, Miloslav Sikora, was ineligible to play for his adopted country because he had played in a junior tournament for Poland.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The economy expanded at a 4.3 percent rate in the first quarter, the best performance in three years. However, analysts said the economy was still growing very modestly. They noted that the improvement reflected an unexpectedly large rise in inventories, mainly of cars and trucks, and they predicted that the buildup would hurt the economy in the present quarter as manufacturers cut production to reduce their stocks.

LEAD: ONE of the most successful new tickets offered by airlines is the ''maxsaver,'' an extremely low fare with an unusual catch: it is nonrefundable. The Philadelphia Inquirer yesterday quoted John Spagnola, a tight end, and Ron Baker, a guard, as saying they had heard about the party.

Moldea, was a guest on the show. Mr. Kwitny said the book was in some ways a ''disservice'' because without firm evidence it linked President Reagan, the Music Corporation of America and gangsters.

LEAD: WITH three New Jersey artists honored for their contributions to the craft field, a first-time event designed to establish a new level of ''peak experience'' in craft shows will open in New York City Thursday night with a benefit preview and continue through next Sunday.

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 8 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $4.95.) Mystery, melodrama and bitter family rivalry in the world of British steeplechase racing.

LEAD: A LULL set in several weeks ago in the news about the Reagan Administration's dealings with Iran and the rebel forces in Nicaragua. But the White House and the Capitol are gripped by the sense that this period of calm is an illusion. On May 5, a week from Tuesday, the special Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair will begin public, televised hearings.

LEAD: Historically, many American foundations began small and were nurtured by their benefactors until they grew into sturdy institutions. But that ''acorn theory of philanthropy'' may no longer hold, according to a new study that sees worrisome implications for the future.
LEAD: Temperate Sil and Talinum, two of the early favorites for the Kentucky Derby next Saturday, will miss the race because of physical problems, their trainers said today.

LEAD: TRUST ME By John Updike. 302 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95. I ONCE read that if the universe, having come to the end of its explosion, collapses on itself, time will run backward. On no good grounds I imagine this as meaning that suburbs will grow new, then raw, and will then recede; that surgeons and scientists will daily master the use of cruder instruments; that every life will be shadowed by the inevitable onset of callowness, childhood and dreaded infancy.

LEAD: ROCK-AND-ROLL IS MORE than 30 years old as a popular phenomenon, and it's astonishing how little we really know about where it came from and how it grew. Book-length histories continue to proliferate, but most are content to restate the same tales and myths. Meanwhile, in England and Europe, the recent flood of reissued recordings from rock's early years shows no signs of abating.
LEAD: THEY say charity begins at home, and I believe it because of the clothing drive.

LEAD: The Justice Department announced Friday that it had approved a consent decree with the City of Jacksonville, N.C., and its Fire Department in a discrimination suit.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: COACH Larry McElreavy of Columbia, which has no victories in its last 34 football games and has suffered 31 straight losses, surveyed 92 candidates yesterday during the one day of spring practice allowed Ivy League teams. ''In some ways I'm glad we didn't win a game last year because we didn't work hard enough to deserve it,'' said McElreavy, whose Lions were 0-10 last season.
LEAD: A Federal judge has scheduled two hearings on plans to carry out the $200 million settlement of the Agent Orange suit.

LEAD: The Soviet Union this week remembered the world's worst civil nuclear disaster with press reports and news conferences designed to make the anniversary a celebration of heroism, candor and resourcefulness.

LEAD: THE first day of May means different celebrations to different people. In some places, they have a parade of dancers around the Maypole. In the Soviet Union, they stage a parade of military might. On the first day of May this year, major league baseball will add a new celebration to the world's calendar of May 1 events: the return of chastened free agents to their former teams.

LEAD: President Reagan is fond of saying that the Russians are tough bargainers. They are, and thus they must see what's happening to Star Wars, his key bargaining chip in the strategic arms talks. He's on the verge of losing it. Mr. Reagan's vision of a Strategic Defense Initiative may never be achievable in space but it has packed a powerful diplomatic punch.
LEAD: A left-wing Greek terrorist group said today that it was responsible for a bomb attack on a bus here Friday that wounded 16 American military personnel and dependents and two Greeks.

LEAD: The Macquarie Dictionary (of the Australian language) defines de facto: '' [ 3 ] a woman who lives with a man as his wife, but is not married to him; [ 4 ] a man who lives with a woman as her husband, but is not married to her.''

LEAD: ALTHOUGH THE AMERICAN SYMPHONY OR-chestra as an institution is nearly 150 years old, it has produced remarkably few conductors of the first rank. A reminder of that deficiency came recently when two of those few, Leonard Bernstein and James Levine, happened to appear on successive evenings at the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera.

LEAD: ACCORDING to an old colonial axiom, the British maintained their power in the Asian subcontinent by a clever policy of ''divide and rule,'' playing religious and ethnic groups off against one another. But after 40 years of independence, the region still is riven by ethnic and religious conflict.

LEAD: Two important measures of the economic condition reported hefty increases last week. One, a 4.3 percent expansion in the nation's output of goods in services for the first three months of the year, was quickly discounted by most analysts. The other, a four-tenths of 1 percent increase in consumer prices in March, was more heavily weighed.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York yesterday, Noel Brown, a daughter of Patricia Mulhern Brown of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Sheldon Herbert Brown Jr., was married to Stephen Joseph Lieb, the son of Joseph P. Lieb of New York and Marianne Evans of Great Neck, L.I. The Rev.

LEAD: COLLEGES are asking alumni, the public and corporate supporters to dig deeper into their pockets than ever before, and their enthusiastic response is resulting in an academic fund-raising boom in Connecticut.

LEAD: WHEN Karl Linnas stepped onto the airport runway in Tallinn in his native Estonia Tuesday, he completed his passage from the hands of the American judicial system to the Soviet Union. Mr. Linnas, a 67-year-old Long Island resident, was sentenced in absentia to death by the Russians 25 years ago for war crimes, although Soviet officials said his case would be reviewed.

LEAD: Standing in the back of a three-wheel pickup in Piazza Garraffello, a young curly-haired vendor adds his shrill cries to the din that has given Palermo's bustling outdoor market its nickname, 'A Vucciria (The Voices). The young man is knee-deep in gray-green bundles of fresh artichokes, which he tosses about freely and, in the process, reveals a strange series of brightly colored decorations hand-painted along the inside of the back of his pickup.

LEAD: IN HIS QUIET WAY, JOEL FISHER HAS been trying to reinvent sculpture. His two current shows include standing, seated and walking figures. There are still lifes, reliefs and objects that seem to have been cast from everyday life. His sculptures suggest numbers, letters and signs. The works glide effortlessly between ancient and modern, figurative and abstract, art and nature.

LEAD: LA TAVERNETTA in Woodmere bubbles with crowds and excitement. There's a party mood, and the diners all seem to be regulars. There are extravagant greetings and bear hugs. Later in the evening, waiters are slapped on the back by doggie-bag-carting customers as they depart.

LEAD: High on a promontory, overlooking the Firth of Forth as it runs into the North Sea, sits the ruin of Tantallon Castle, the 14th-century home of the Earl of Douglas. Below the castle, the currents swirl among rocky islets where puffins, gannets and guillemots build their nests, and the wind pounds stiffly against the cliffs.

LEAD: THE topic was campaign strategies. In a second-floor dining room at Harvard University's Institute of Politics, Julie D. Belaga was entertaining four political scholars with tales of Connecticut's gubernatorial races.

LEAD: President Oscar Arias Sanchez, author of a much-praised initiative intended to bring peace to Central America, said this week that his plan might be in trouble. Foreign diplomats agreed with his assessment.

LEAD: A WEEK IN SOUTH DAKOTA By Gary Gildner. 180 pp. North Carolina: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $14.95. THE SECOND BRIDGE By Gary Gildner. 188 pp. North Carolina: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $15.95.

LEAD: AT the heart of Boston's plan to transform the Charlestown Navy Yard into a mixed-use waterfront neighborhood is Building 106, a cavernous turn-of-the-century warehouse the Navy built to house a metal-working shop.

LEAD: Jocelyn I. Javits, the daughter of Stephanie L. Javits of Key Biscayne, Fla., and Eric M. Javits of New York, Southampton, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Timothy D. Williamson, a son of Rhea Williamson of Murphysboro, Ill., and the late Russell M. Williamson. The Rev. Elwood Graves, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Javits home in Palm

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: OPPONENTS of the death penalty had viewed McCleskey v. Kemp as their best hope since the Supreme Court allowed states to resume executions a decade ago. For Warren McCleskey of Georgia's death row, and in effect for hundreds of others, the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund argued that the sentencing process was infected with racism and therefore unconstitutional.

LEAD: When the International Business Machines Corporation unveiled its new generation of PC's on April 2, the new machines were pronounced impressive, but scarcely the clone killers that had been anticipated. That day, I.B.M.'s stock fell $3.125 to $148, while the stocks of most other personal computer makers rose.

LEAD: For the first time, the Supreme Court last week approved state restrictions on hostile takeovers, upholding an Indiana law that limits the voting rights of those seeking to gain control of companies incorporated in the state.

LEAD: The engagement of Michele Fortune, senior vice president of merchandising for Lord & Taylor in New York, to Edward G. David has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Fortune of Auburn, Calif. Mr. David, a management consultant in New York, is a son of the late Dr. and Mrs.

LEAD: A speculative foreigner in the city, in the second half of the 1980's, I stand on the deck of the ferry, at the top of the skyscraper, in the green of the park, in the melee of the midtown street, and looking around at the tumultuous presence of New York, I think it can never have been New Yorkier than it is today.

LEAD: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is under increasing fire from within and outside the organization because of a suit over legal fees it has filed against some of its former lawyers.
LEAD: FESTIVAL IN DELAWARE

LEAD: CAN Long Island politicians, businessmen, civic leaders, academia and the public reach a consensus on Long Island's major problems and their solutions for the turn of the century? That's what Long Island Project 2000 hopes to accomplish. But Long Islanders will have to wait a while longer for the results of this 250-member, nine-panel, $100,000 study.
LEAD: A judge has ordered Gov. George Deukmejian to add 201 chemicals to a list of toxic substances he was required to issue under a voter-initiated referendum approved last November.

LEAD: Dr. Helen Marie Shields, an assistant professor of medicine at the Harvard Medical School and an internist specializing in gastroenterology at the Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, was married yesterday to Richard Anthony Aparo, a project engineer for research and development in the medical division of the Hewlett-Packard Company in Waltham, Mass.

LEAD: Perhaps the saddest point of the whole Baby M case is that, in wanting to keep Baby M, Mrs. Whitehead is responding most normally. The surrogates who can part with their children are probably not as emotionally healthy as Mrs. Whitehead. So it is this very natural phenomenon of wanting to mother the child she carried for nine months that has brought Mrs.

LEAD: THE skunk cabbage was peeking through last year's matted brown leaves and coltsfoot bloomed in the meadow. In the space of 24 hours, nature had shrugged off winter and announced that, yes, finally spring had arrived. This was no day to hang around computers. Better to go riding. I popped off to the tack shop to replace a broken set of reins neglected over the dreary winter months.

LEAD: WHAT musical begins with a vaudeville routine, has a mock Russian ballet as a first-act finale, ends with an American jazz ballet and, all along, offers one dandy musical comedy song-and-dance number after another in a tradition that bespeaks the best of Broadway?

LEAD: A battered 18th-century church, festooned with daisies and daffodils and strangely littered with the remnants of cinder-block barricades, stands in this residential community in the far western suburbs of Paris as a kind of emblem of a new stage in the long history of religious conflict in France.

LEAD: The clean-shaven look typical of new suburban developments, with barely a bush or bough to offset the structural monotony, can be unkind to esthetically minded neighbors - and it doesn't offer much in the way of privacy for the residents, either.

LEAD: Anita Storch, the daughter of Irma Storch of Clifton, N.J., and the late Dr. Murray Storch, was married yesterday to Jack J. Kassel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E.Joseph Kassel of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Martin Freedman officiated at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J. The bride, a graduate of the University of Maryland, is a stylist for CGI Textiles Ltd.

LEAD: HARD hat in hand, a motorcycle messenger strode into the beehive-like Park Avenue office of Fidelity Investments earlier this month. He went directly to a multi-colored video display terminal, punched a few numbers into a keyboard, looked up at the screen and walked away smiling.
LEAD: THE REWARDS for the Super Bowl champions were great: parades, celebrations, parties, appearances, endorsements, commercials, autograph parties, dinners, autobiographies and more.

LEAD: Stoop-shouldered, shuffling along, Milton Graton is the last of a kind, a legacy of a fading Americana he is dedicated to preserving. At 78 years of age, he is still building and restoring covered bridges.

LEAD: FIFTY cottages in Cortlandt have been ruled seasonal, for summer use only - but because summer is almost here and 30 homeless families are already living in the cottages, the families may be allowed to stay until the end of summer.

LEAD: CHRIS BARRETT attempts to build his sets of songs in the Ambassador Room of the U.N. Plaza Hotel, 44th Street at First Avenue, around the musicals of the spring season on Broadway and London's West End. But the pickings are pretty slim, especially on Broadway, and he is glad to grasp at revivals of shows by Rodgers and Hart or Jerome Kern presently in or planned for

LEAD: THE FABULOUS EAST HAS CAP-tivated American audiences for more than a hundred years - often through the most blithely fanciful presentations. This season, several revivals recall milestones in this long affair with Orientalia. ''The Mikado,'' the English import that triggered the craze in 1885, is currently on Broadway (this time imported from Stratford, Ontario); it features such merry anomalies as a British patter song sung by kimono-clad officials and a Japanese tea ceremony using Victorian tea service.
LEAD: SEVERAL changes in the time-shares industry are providing fresh opportunities for anyone tempted by this type of ownership.
LEAD: WHILE running backward, Stanley Wunderlich is headed unswervingly into the high-tech future.
LEAD: NOTHING NATURAL By Jenny Diski. 256 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.
LEAD: THE South African Government deployed thousands of police officers and troops in Johannesburg and the black township of Soweto last week to crush a strike by black railway workers.
LEAD: The South African army struck into Zambia early today by helicopter, killing four Zambians and destroying two buildings in the southwestern town of Livingstone, the Zambian Government said.

LEAD: During the Reagan Administration, the relationship between the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the utilities it oversees has met with disapproval from many Capitol Hill Democrats. Last week, grumbling turned into challenge when two legislators accused the N.R.C.'s top management of showing favoritism toward the industry and asked the commission to act to curb it.

LEAD: In her article ''Our Fascination With Baby M'' (March 29), Anne Taylor Fleming expresses with great lucidity that the central issue in the Baby M case is motherhood. Indeed, the right of a mother to her child has been one of very few ''absolutes'' in our society - so basic that the framers of the Constitution never thought that it needed to be guaranteed.
LEAD: THE FIERY CROSS The Ku Klux Klan in America. By Wyn Craig Wade. Illustrated. 526 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

LEAD: Catherine Mabie's goats are self-supporting. The income from the sale of their raw, unpasteurized milk pays for their grain and the bills from the veterinarian. It buys the gas and oil that run the equipment that cuts the hay they eat.

LEAD: India summoned Tamil extremist leaders here for secret talks this week and urged them to negotiate a settlement with the Sri Lankan Government, officials and other sources said today The guerrillas reportedly answered that they would not talk with the Colombo Government until it stopped attacks on Tamil strongholds in the northern Jaffna

LEAD: At first the news sounds hopeful: From 1973 through 1984, the national robbery rate declined by 15 percent. This, however, was because of a decline in unsuccessful attempts, in which a robber accosted a victim but failed to get any loot. The rate of successful robberies remained unchanged. Altogether, there were on average 1.2 million incidents a year.

LEAD: IN November, voters in Boston defeated by more than 2 to 1 a plan to carve a new town, Mandela, out of the primarily black districts of the city. But leaders of the secession movement say they are undaunted by the defeat, and they vowed this week to try to get the issue on the ballot again this fall.
LEAD: A few days ago, when Lesley Welch realized she had no plans for the weekend, she decided to run a road race to keep in shape.

LEAD: To the Editor: On April 12 the Travel section, under the heading Dominican Republic, listed Ciudad Trujillo. For a new generation of Dominicans, such a mistake may be offensive. I am certain you know that after the assassination of the despot the name of the capital was returned to the historical and certainly better sounding Santo Domingo.

LEAD: In the year since the Chernobyl disaster, nuclear power has undergone its most critical appraisal since the invention of the reactor in 1942. But despite the global anxiety created by the Soviet accident, experts say that it has not caused major technical changes in the nuclear power industry of the West.

LEAD: They began arriving 10 days ago, dozens of people on the condominium trail. In warm sun and then cold rain, they lived in a community of cars, campers and trucks, assuring themselves a chance to pay $175,000 and up for one of the 100 town houses that will become Society Hill.
LEAD: FROM THE CAMERAS OF LIFE

LEAD: AFTER 47 years of work, Mary C. Kelly of West Hartford, Conn., retired from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to a comfortable life of gardening and travel. But a few months later, she was back at work: ''I was bored, and the money comes in handy,'' she said. Today, Mrs. Kelly, 69, and another returned worker share a job at the Travelers Companies as co-directors of the Retiree Job

LEAD: THIS 'N THAT By Bette Davis with Michael Herskowitz. Illustrated. 207 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95. NARROW IS THE WAY By B. D. and Jeremy Hyman. 285 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $16.95.

LEAD: FRESH shad, which began to appear in local markets about four weeks ago, is a sure sign of spring. As the weather warms, this fairly large member of the herring family migrates north into coastal rivers to spawn. The shad, a traditional springtime delicacy, makes itself available for harvest.

LEAD: A New York City police officer has told authorities that he struck a man three times with his night stick during an arrest that was filmed by an onlooker last month because the man was resisting arrest and he believed the man had a knife, the officer's lawyer said yesterday.

LEAD: Visiting motorists who travel from northern Italy to Rome or from Venice to Tuscany will, after studying the road maps, in all likelihood head for the Bologna-Florence autostrada. They ought to be warned to drive defensively on that 60-mile highway across the sullen ranges of the Apennines; during peak periods an alternative route may be preferable.
LEAD: Generations have passed, but the terror remains an agonizing rend in the consciousness of the Armenian people.

LEAD: Robert Reed's first novel, THE LEESHORE (Donald I. Fine, $16.95), has a lot going for it. The setting is well-conceived - a watery planet called Leeshore whose sky is home to lighter-than-air life forms so numerous that sunlight is prevented from reaching its surface, where bioluminescent flora and fauna live off the droppings from above.
LEAD: The Giants' and Jets' needs in the draft offer an ironic twist: To round out their championship squad, the Giants could use a top-flight wide receiver, which the Jets have.

LEAD: WHEN Dory Previn emerged onto the pop scene in the early 1970's at the height of the singer-songwriter movement, she stood out as an intriguing oddball. Evoking in song the same Hollywood-as-Babylon vision that Joan Didion portrayed in ''Play It As It Lays,'' Ms. Previn added her personal twists of occultism and feminism, as well as a very dry, quirky sense of humor.

LEAD: WEST GERMANY'S hockey team, which had two victories taken away in the world championships in Vienna last week, had the victories temporarily restored yesterday. The International Ice Hockey Federation took the victories away because West Germany, in its first four games, used Miloslav Sikora, a Polish-born defenseman who competed for Poland in a junior hockey tournament.

LEAD: Having brought men into Lamaze classes and delivery rooms, having rightly demanded that men take up their equal share of nurturing and parenting, now some feminists would condemn a man who is fighting for his right to be exactly that: a loving, responsible father. It was William Stern who yearned for a child, not Mary Beth Whitehead.

LEAD: CHEU TE?'' ASKS DR. JOSEPH Lurio, and the broad-faced Cambodian woman in the chair facing him nods: yes, it does hurt. He turns to Somontha Lam, a Cambodian translator employed by this family clinic, and asks, ''Did she ever go to her orthopedics appointment?''

LEAD: AMTRAK is planning to build a new station in New Rochelle to replace its current stop at the Metro-North station in Rye, but what is planned by the railroad as an improvement is looming in New Rochelle as a threat.
LEAD: BEHIND THE FRONT PAGE A Candid Look at How the News Is Made. By David S. Broder. 393 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.
LEAD: An experimental program to provide health care to welfare recipients through a health-maintenance organization is in danger of failing because the medical providers are threatening to withdraw.

LEAD: THE glamour of ancient whaling ships and the excitement of manned spacecraft are featured on recant sets from the Marshall Islands. The tiny nation in the western Pacific Ocean is administered by the United States as part of the United Nations Trust Territory of the Pacific. Although the United States Postal Service carries mail to and from its shores, the Marshall Islands have been issuing stamps since 1984.

LEAD: A BARGE with 3,100 tons of Long Island garbage has been haunting ocean waters from Islip as far south as the Gulf of Mexico in search of a place to dump. Long-distance truckers are hauling waste from the metropolitan region to dumps as far away as West Virginia, Michigan and Ohio.

LEAD: AT the heart of Boston's plan to transform the Charlestown Navy Yard into a mixed-use waterfront neighborhood is Building 106, a cavernous turn-of-the-century warehouse the Navy built to house a metal-working shop.

LEAD: President Hafez al-Assad, left, talking with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, yesterday as his visit ended. The two also held talks on Friday, and diplomats said differences had emerged on several issues involving peace in the Middle East, including Palestinian reunification and the Iran-Iraq war.
LEAD: LINDA said she had a surprise. I had to drive but she wouldn't tell me where we were going.

LEAD: RUNAWAY. By Lucy Irvine. (Random House, $18.95.) Very early in Lucy Irvine's account of how she dropped out of schools and into communes, hitched rides through Britain, Western Europe and the Middle East, scrounged meals and relied on the kindness of strangers, this reader got the uncomfortable feeling that hers was less the tale of an adventuresome young woman than that of a disturbed adolescent.

LEAD: IN THE 1950'S AND EVEN 60'S, IT was possible to compile lists of recommended recordings from a fairly narrow field, and to know that, in terms of recorded sound, all the competing versions were in the same rough competitive league.

LEAD: With a heave, John Burt pulled the sheep on its back and pinned it between his legs. Then, reaching for his clippers, he went to work.
LEAD: THE SHRAPNEL ACADEMY By Fay Weldon. 186 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

LEAD: Leningrad Visit Question:I have heard that quick visits by sea to Leningrad are possible, and without a visa, from Helsinki. Whom do I contact? - J. D., New York Answer:The North American agent for a Finnish shipping company, the Sally Line, can book short, weekly trips from Helsinki to Leningrad from May 18.

LEAD: Mell Lazarus can relax about his sons-in-law. He fails to take notice of how easily his daughters controlled him. They evidently learned something from their mother. NANCY GLASSMAN North Woodmere, L.I.

The two performances, by Arthur Russell with his cello and Virgilio Marti with his Guaguanco ensemble, called up mental images that were insistently aquatic - Mr.

LEAD: Puerto Rico is really two islands in one. Visitors who come for the beach find enough in and around the capital, San Juan, to fill their days. Another Puerto Rico is nestled in the high mountains, shrouded in tropical wilderness. It is an old Puerto Rico, with a history and culture going back to Christopher Columbus and earlier.

LEAD: I HAVE to say that I am puzzled.

LEAD: Tina Frangos, an associate in the New York law firm Spitzer & Feldman, was married yesterday to Robert DiMino, a vice president of Wilson Pleus & Company, an investment banking firm in Teaneck, N.J. The Rev. Nicholas Magoulias performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Church in Hempstead, L.I.

LEAD: President Reagan is expected to approve creation of a special commission to study the AIDS crisis and suggest ways for the Administration to respond to what he has called ''Public Health Enemy No. 1,'' according to senior White House officials.

LEAD: I SHOULDN'T have been, but I was dumbstruck when a woman, who, like me, was in the doctor's office for a postkidney transplant checkup, talked about the day she would need a pancreas transplant. She had diabetes, a burdensome enough disease in itself and one that may lead to kidney failure.

LEAD: The engagement of Kathleen Ann Clancy to Hallett R. Gates 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gates Jr. of New York and Lyme, Conn., has been announced by Dorothy Clancy of Morristown, N.J., and Richard J. Clancy of Boston, parents of the bride-to-be. An October wedding is planned. Miss Clancy is an associate in the retail division in New York of Allied Irish Banks.

LEAD: The spectacular stock market career of Ivan F. Boesky came to a formal end last week in perhaps the most significant trade of Mr. Boesky's life. Appearing in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Mr. Boesky, who made hundreds of millions of dollars on Wall Street, pleaded guilty to one count of violating securities laws, presumably in return for a lenient sentence.
LEAD: THE headlines have been steady and frequent: Hearst buys Esquire and Redbook. Hearst buys William A. Morrow & Company, the book publisher. Hearst buys television stations and cable TV systems.

LEAD: THE 50's may be back in style, but not soon enough to save the Coliseum at Columbus Circle. The exposition hall has been sold to Coliseum Associates for demolition to make way for a mixed-use project with two towers rising 68 and 58 stories. Construction is scheduled to begin late in the spring and by summer's end the blank, boxy

LEAD: Three members of a family have filed a $601 lawsuit in Federal District Court here against a television ministry formerly led by Jim Bakker, charging that their contributions to the group were used for illegal, illicit and immoral purposes.

LEAD: PRIME Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone visits Washington this week to try to defuse the latest trade crisis. But the importance of the visit is more symbolic than real. Most changes in Japan's economic policies are not the result of bold initiatives from the Prime Minister, but of painstaking bargaining among a group of powerful constituencies, including bureaucrats, politicians and businessmen.

LEAD: LURED by an advertisement, we entered a new restaurant, Chavoya's, in the small revived shopping complex along Whalley Avenue in New Haven. Inside, the configuration of the room revives memories of Bourbon Street, a former inhabitant of the space. The juxtaposition of the long bar area, separate from but open to the large two-tiered dining room, stirs echoes of the past.

LEAD: CLARA SCHUMANN - THE widow of Robert, friend and spiritual mentor to Johannes Brahms, expert and often eloquent minor composer and, by all accounts, a great pianist and teacher - was one of the most remarkable women of the 19th century. Now Pearl, a record company based in England, has issued a nine-disk set titled ''Pupils of Clara Schumann'' (Pearl CLA 1000, LP only, available from Qualiton Imports, 3928 Crescent Street, Long Island City, Queens, 11101.) It is of considerable interest, although it does not tell the whole story.

LEAD: After two years of recruiting bilingual teachers from Spain, the New York City Board of Education has decided not to hire from Spain this year but to recruit more teachers from Puerto Rico and, for the first time, from the Dominican Republic.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Raichelson of West Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lyssa Ann Raichelson, to Steven Scott Girden, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Girden of Stamford, Conn. A November wedding is planned. Miss Raichelson, a magna cum laude graduate of Northwestern University, is a broadcast production assistant at the Louden, Kaplan & Elegant advertising firm in New York.

LEAD: EVER SINCE THE FIRST COURT jester stood before the throne and delivered a one-liner for the king, the stand-up comic has been making his uphill way in the world. It is a calling whose heroes are mostly unsung, whose practitioners are always endangered by the threat of laughless listeners. Comedians rank with actors and other cultural heroes, such as Sergeant York, Emile Zola and Bernadette, when it comes to being immortalized in movies, but the stand-up has been left standing, off-screen.

The nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment as Ambassador to Rumania.

LEAD: In this blue-collar New England city, the American dream has always seemed particularly vivid, embodied in the saga of the proud Pontes, as they are known. By the hundreds, they came here from the small Italian town of Pontelandolfo, where they struggled to grow grapes and olive trees out of rocky soil.
LEAD: WHILE the rest of the world agonizes over the possibility of eventually exhausting the global oil supply, Africa is beset with another kind of energy crisis: a growing scarcity of wood.

LEAD: THE year was 1946. The place was the Milford Drive-In, Connecticut's first drive-in picture show. Hundreds of Buicks, Studebakers and Packards filled the lot every night, paying 75 cents a carload, to watch the likes of Humphrey Bogart, Lauren Bacall and Bette Davis on the 80-foot screen as people listened through speakers attached to their cars.

LEAD: The marriage of Amy Sarah Philips and Joseph Vincent Sullivan Jr., who both received Master of Architecture degrees from Princeton University, took place last evening at Federal Hall in Manhattan. Rabbi Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.
LEAD: DEVELOPERS in Westchester are taking to the skies to solve some of the problems that are hard to solve on the ground - and within a few months, they may even get help from satellites.

LEAD: Despite dozens of medical insurance programs that have been legislated in Massachusetts over the last decade, about 10 percent of the state's residents, many of whom are regularly employed, still have no health insurance.

LEAD: A university lecturer from New York City who is married to a Kenyan historian jailed since 1982 on sedition charges was picked up by four plainclothes policemen nine days ago and held for about 32 hours before being released.

LEAD: During Wayne Shorter's 15 years with Weather Report, his fans grew frustrated, hearing only a few bars of his saxophone here and there. But with his own group, appearing Saturday at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street, he is at center stage, spinning out solos that are fierce and tender and articulate.
LEAD: The police have charged an itinerant handyman with six murders, and detectives are digging at the man's previous residences and work sites for more possible victims.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour I. Toll of Bala Cynwyd, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Anne Toll, to Daniel F. Becker, a son of Dr. David V. Becker and the late Naomi I. Becker of New York. A June 7 wedding is planned.

LEAD: The Sri Lankan Government said today that its navy destroyed a vessel apparently carrying munitions for Tamil guerrillas on Friday night in the strait separating Sri Lanka from southern India.
LEAD: SOME of New York City's finest restaurants are not in the Guide Michelin or the Mobil Touring Guide, but they are becoming the in places to eat - if you are invited.

LEAD: EVER SINCE IT WAS OPENED IN September 1984, the Center for African Art, at 54 East 68th Street, has had a character all its own. It has a clearly defined function. It is exactly the right size. It is run with an eye for true quality. And it deals with subject matter that is compellingly and controversially alive.
LEAD: Passengers waiting for the ''No Smoking'' light to go out on the Air Canada flight from La Guardia Airport to Toronto this morning will be disappointed. It won't.

LEAD: ''Shoah'' (in Hebrew, ''Annihilation''), Claude Lanzmann's huge oral history of the Holocaust is unlike any other Holocaust film ever made. This isn't a conventional documentary composed of newsreel footage from the archives. Everything is of the present - the faces of the ''witnesses'' as well as the tranquil, neatly tended landscapes that once were the death camps.

LEAD: THE owner of the Milwaukee Bucks, Herbert Kohl, said the Knicks had not sought permission to interview Coach Don Nelson in their search for a replacment for Bob Hill. ''I have not had any communication with Richard Evans,'' Kohl said of the Knicks' president.

LEAD: The edge of change is the natural habitat for the leaders in any field. They mnake it their business to know, before the rest of us, who is likely to touch our lives. So we sought out leading figures in some of New York's most notable disciplines, from law enforcement to dance, and asked them to do some stargazing -- to predict who, in their respective fields, will make a difference in the future of New York.

LEAD: IT's not a great National Football League draft this year - strong in linebackers, running backs and players from the University of Miami, but short on offensive linemen, tight ends and defensive backs. Many personnel experts say 10, maybe 12 instant-impact players are available, then there's a round and a half of second-rounders.

LEAD: New York City long offered real estate developers the opportunity to circumvent certain zoning restrictions if, in exchange, they would provide public amenities on the sites of major developments. Now, after some experience, architects have a much better sense of what attracts people than they did in the 1950's, when Lever House and the Seagram Building were among the only skyscrapers in town with outdoor space dedicated to public use.
LEAD: GROWING up in Greenwich in the 30's and 40's, Lawrence J. Pugliese knew little about drugs. ''To me, they were something your parents got at the drugstore when you were sick,'' he said.

LEAD: Posters put up in Italy's major cities in the last few days announced that the Italian Communist Party's newspaper, L'Unita, now offered its readers ''the new battles, the new ideas, the new desires.''

LEAD: In a dramatic international rescue effort, four American crewmen who were injured in a tugboat fire in the middle of the Pacific were transferred Friday to a Japanese freighter by paramedics who had parachuted to their aid.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL 3-20 A request for refuge for Salvadorans has been made by El Salvador's President to President Reagan. He said that the new United States immigration law could have a disastrous effect on his country's economy. LEAD: Bowling Younger Weber Winner: Pete Weber, age 24, became the youngest player to win 10 Professional Bowlers Association titles when he captured the Firestone Tournament of Champions by beating Jim Murtishaw, 222-190, yesterday in Akron, Ohio. The $50,000 winner's share put Weber at the top of the P.B.A.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Lambert of New York and Locust, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Lambert to Daniel C. Churchill, the son of Mrs. James Farley of Cornish, N.H., and the late Creighton Churchill. The couple will be married June 27.

LEAD: An earthquake shook the capital and other areas of the island of Luzon on Saturday night, sending thousands of people into the streets in panic, the authorities said. No injuries or damage were immediately reported. The Government said the quake struck registered 5.5 on the Richter scale.
LEAD: THE spring rush is on, musically speaking, with more than a dozen events jostling for attention today and at least that many waiting to usher in May.

LEAD: Judge Harvey R. Sorkow's decision should be reversed on the simple ground that a contract for the sale of a child is illegal and unenforceable as a matter of public policy in the state of New Jersey, as it should be in every other state.

LEAD: THE native dogwoods need attention since blooms are expanding and leaves will soon follow; use one of the mancozeb-based fungicides applied according to the label rate; make a second and third application at 10-day intervals. On dwarf conifers, use a pruning shears or sharp lawn clipper to cut in half the new growth to keep these needled evergreens in their compact shapes.

LEAD: Sunday's schedule is rich in concerts that will recommend themselves to admirers of the artists involved, but my pick of the bunch is the Boston Early Music Festival Orchestra under Nicholas McGegan at Tully Hall at 8 P.M. This group, associated with the leading festival of its kind in the Western Hemisphere, is what you've been waiting for if you assume that ''early instrument'' orchestras are either sterile or inexpert or both.
LEAD: In elections that reflected the changing politics of urban Texas, the voters of Dallas and Corpus Christi last weekend elected women as mayors for the first time.

LEAD: WHEN prospective employees are interviewed at Simmonds Precision in Tarrytown, they are asked to take a drug test. Simmonds, a manufacturer of highly sophisticated electronic instruments for the aircraft industry, has made it a condition of employment that potential Simmonds employees be tested, by urinalysis, for drug abuse.
LEAD: When Dina Merrill, the actress, was a newlywed in her 20's, her mother-in-law introduced her to the New York City Mission Society, saying, ''Every bride should have a charity.''

LEAD: IN Gian Carlo Menotti's ''Tamu-Tamu'' - revived Friday by the Juilliard American Opera Center as part of a double bill directed by the composer-librettist - Mr. and Mrs. Hudson, an urban couple, see a picture of a family fleeing bullets in a war-torn Indonesia and give expressions of concern and detachment.
LEAD: The number of American families affected by alcohol-related problems has doubled since 1974, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

LEAD: Fifty-three Filipino war veterans have won a 41-year battle for United States citizenship. The men, guerrillas in World War II who fought the Japanese in the Philippines, had sued the Immigration and Naturalization Service, saying the Government had reneged on a promise of citizenship.

LEAD: THE Passage Theater Company here has come upon what Veronica Brady, one of its three producers-directors, calls ''the best marketing program you can design'' for an up-and-coming resident theater: free tickets.
LEAD: A teen-ager who suffered a leg fracture and was trapped in her car after it ran off a road and into a ditch was not found for 16 days, but she survived because she had access to water.

LEAD: UNDER A radical new policy that it adopted last week, the Patent and Trademark Office now will consider patenting all forms of animals on earth, with the exception of homo sapiens. Any animal engineered with characteristics not attainable through classical breeding techniques is now considered a ''human invention,'' qualifying as ''patentable subject matter.

LEAD: AMERICAN princesses come in all colors and religions and may be found anywhere in America (even in K-Mart country, but not, of course, in an actual K-Mart). This is according to the latest sociological studies.

LEAD: Even the supporters of President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative concede that an antimissile weapons system of lasers and particle beams sounds futuristic. But they insist that the technology can be developed to deploy ''Star Wars'' in this century. Last week, a panel of leading American physicists disputed that forecast, saying it will take at least a decade of testing just to determine whether the weapons will work.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A writer's life may be one of dreary solitude, but the Literary Life - ah, the Literary Life promises glamour, fame, a seat next to Hemingway as he scribbles immortal prose in a Paris cafe. The myth is so alluring it can survive even the most scaled-down atmosphere. On a typical New York night, for instance, David Leavitt, Meg Wolitzer and Gary Glickman - all novelists in their 20's and the best of friends - are likely to be having dinner at their favorite restaurant, a dingy, hole in the wall in the West Village.
LEAD: After more than two years of legal maneuvering and public anticipation, arguments are to begin tomorrow in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz in the shooting of four youths on a subway train.

LEAD: The economy grew at a 4.3 percent rate in the first quarter, the best performance since 1984. Still, the news had economists scowling rather than cheering. LEAD: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad consolidated his hold over his divided party today, and Malaysians were waiting to see whether he would dismiss his opponents or seek to heal the rifts.

LEAD: A Cornell University fraternity has been ordered closed for four years by administrators, who have accused the group of sexual abuse, house mismanagement and illegal use of alcohol, the university said today.

LEAD: DR. PAUL A. MARKS IS confident the time is at hand. ''We're ready for the next quantum jump in terms of being effective against cancer,'' he says, his piercing blue eyes staring out through aviator glasses, their very intensity seeming to will the quantum jump to proceed. Marks is president and chief executive officer of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, the nation's oldest and largest research and hospital complex devoted exclusively to cancer.

LEAD: With memories of the January strike and its hardships still in our minds, the unions threatened to strike the Long Island Rail Road again. This threat created anxiety among all railroad users, who desperately searched for alternative transportation. Fortunately, the strike did not materialize; it was settled by negotiations before the deadline.

LEAD: After Bernhard Goetz pulled a gun and shot down four young men he believed were about to mug him on a subway train on Dec. 22, 1984, his case quickly evolved into a Rorschach test. Crime victims, civil libertarians, gun owners - each could find satisfaction, outrage or vindication in the case. The various reactions attest to the ambiguity of what actually happened.

LEAD: A subcommittee of the United States Senate is to hold a hearing next month to determine why the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway bridge collapsed into the Schoharie Creek on April 5.

LEAD: LOUIS T. HOWARD, an unusual legislator in an often unusual Suffolk County Legislature, is winding up a 24-year-long political career that has spanned the most turbulent years in Suffolk County history.

LEAD: IN Paul Zindel's ''And Miss Reardon Drinks a Little,'' currently at the Arena Repertory Players Theater, three sisters outdo one another in various forms of unpleasant behavior. What saves the play from becoming two long, unremitting acts about the facets of vicious, sexually repressed women is that each sister gets as much as she gives.

LEAD: A LIME green bow tie and cummerbund! A white satin laboratory jacket! Orchestral fanfares worthy of the Tonight Show Band! Could this be Lester Bowie, trumpeter with the Art Ensemble of Chicago, erstwhile standardbearer of the avant-garde?

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Beverly Stolzman of Roslyn, L.I., of the engagement of her daughter Ellen Gray Stolzman to Kenneth Ian Moch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Moch of Mamaroneck, N.Y. The couple will marry on June 27.
LEAD: He is slender, almost frail at 79 years of age, a soft-spoken Virgina gentleman whose friends worry about his health. His is not a household name.

LEAD: ''THERE are things about the world I can learn only from 5,000 feet above it,'' writes Diane Ackerman in ''On Extended Wings,'' her poetic memoir about learning to fly an airplane. The author's intense philosophical wonderment permeates Sara Brooks's stage adaptation of the work at the No Smoking Playhouse.

LEAD: A BOOMING economy in Connecticut has not been good news for farmers, who are so short of farmhands that they have been unable to find the help they need to harvest crops.

LEAD: GETTING BLUE. By Peter Gethers. (Delacorte, $16.95.) Ordinary - but for one thing: he is an extraordinary baseball player who makes it onto the farm teams, into the majors and, 30 years later, to the perfect play that he dreamed about all his life.

LEAD: THOMAS B. MORGAN is a classy writer. His new novel, ''Snyder's Walk,'' is about a crusty magazine writer's confrontation with the peace movement in the mid-1960's, and critics will hail it for all the right reasons, but I know he is a classy writer because he makes a poetic allusion the way it ought to be done -cold turkey, no hints, and if the reader gets it, fine; if not, not.

LEAD: A 13-story apartment building under construction in Bridgeport, Conn., collapsed with a roar last week, crushing at least 13 construction workers to death. Fifteen others were missing in the rubble and a dozen more were injured.
