LEAD: Three workers were killed today and another was injured when a 12-story crane collapsed,, the police said. The four ''apparently rode the crane down as it fell and jumped off when it got close to the ground,'' said Sgt. G. S. Beck of the Dallas police. He said one of the workers was crushed by the crane, which was being dismantled when it fell.

LEAD: May and June are bad months for sea monsters in Hong Kong, but not so bad for humans. The dragon boat races are a lavish spectacle designed to scare away local sea monsters and fish, but they lure tourists and Hong Kong residents to the harbor. The boat races are among Hong Kong's endearing anomalies, a reminder that the territory has not lost its soul in the process of building a financial district and a subway that works.

LEAD: THE NEW PRODUCTION OF Aaron Copland's opera ''The Tender Land,'' opening Friday at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, is more than a revival. LEAD: I LAY THERE, THINKING ABOUT HOW MY boat was going to lose. For two weeks, as May turned to June, the Harvard crews trained on the Thames River in Connecticut for the annual races against Yale. This was the 14th morning I had woken up with a pain in my stomach, knowing my junior-varsity boat would practice with the varsity, that no matter how well we raced we would trail behind a superior crew.

LEAD: Mell Lazarus apparently has never noticed the way men routinely treat women and the way husbands routinely treat their wives in this culture. No news here.

LEAD: For a moment, Haris Makkis was delighted by the news that a judge had struck down broad restrictions on smoking in New York State.

LEAD: When the Jewish Child Care Association of New York announced last year that it planned to establish a foster home for adolescent girls in the predominantly white community of Fresh Meadows, Queens, it immediately encountered angry opposition. Residents said that such use of the property would cause real estate values to drop and could endanger their children.

LEAD: It's years since I heard anyone suggest, except with a cynical smile, that travel broadens the mind. Travel has been transformed - by technology, popular taste and marketing pressures. Time and distance contract: We travel in a time warp - is today yesterday, today or tomorrow?
LEAD: Tens of thousands of demonstrators, many representing churches and organized labor, marched through the streets of Washington today to protest American policy in Central America.

LEAD: I AM beginning to think that selling a home is an unsettling experience in every sense. About two years ago I mentioned to my children that when I reached 55, I would sell our house and make a few changes in my life. I had been a widow for a number of years; they had established themselves out-of-town, and it seemed wasteful to be taking up so much space by myself.

LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino applauding at a rally yesterday for senatorial candidates in Bacolod City, the Philippines. Afterward, she met with military and Roman Catholic leaders and asked them to end disagreements and name-calling over strategy against Philippine rebels.

Lang delivered the commencement address nearly six years ago to the sixth graders at his former grammar school, and spontaneously promised to pay their college tuitions, he didn't know what he was getting into. Lang has so far spent $125,000 on the students of P.S. 121 in East Harlem - arranging writing workshops and cultural trips, hiring tutors and mentors.

LEAD: Since enactment of New York City's landmark legislation in 1965, the Landmarks Preservation Commission has brought 51 historic districts, with 15,000 buildings, and 700 individual structures under the protection of the law. Considered by some owners the ultimate architectural distinction and by others a nuisance, designation has expanded to include street clocks and even magnolia trees.

LEAD: In his article ''The Son-in-Law Watcher'' (About Men, April 5), Mell Lazarus asks: ''Does she know the first rule of marriage, the one that says it doesn't necessarily have to last forever?'' Is Mr. Lazarus aware of all the consequences of such an attitude? There is a casual outlook on life - if it doesn't work, we'll simply throw it out.

LEAD: Although the writer Colette changed houses at least 14 times in her long life, the house she always returned to in her memories was her first, the house where she was born. Today it remains unchanged, a solid burgher homestead in the little village of St.-Sauveur-en-Puisaye in northwest Burgundy.

LEAD: ON Tuesday, April 7, we won our fifth straight game, which, for the Phoenix Suns of the last two seasons, was cause for celebration. LEAD: Manhattan's pool halls, smoky dens that were the stuff of neighborhood legend, have nearly disappeared, even as the game is in the midst of a resurgence in much of the country.

LEAD: Japan's reported plan to put up $30 billion for new loans to Latin America is a welcome sign of global responsibility, albeit late. But generous gestures by a nation grown rich on export surpluses mustn't distract from fundamental responsibility -to cut those chronic and disruptive surpluses.

LEAD: Brigitte Haudebourg Brigitte Haudebourg plays the harpsichord with flair, expertise and the grand manner of a virtuoso. Not for her the tinkling, timid interpretations of too many early-music specialists with their desiccated, self-conscious and excruciatingly correct trills. She is a musician first, a scholar second; her performances are extroverted and often very exciting.

LEAD: FEW organizations with the reputation of Musica Sacra would dream of devoting an evening entirely to works composed within the past 25 years. This chorus could easily have sold out Avery Fisher Hall Friday night with music by Bach or Handel - maybe even Carl Orff or Charles Ives - but opted instead for the more difficult task of fighting for the music of our own time, with a correlative drop in attendance.

LEAD: ''WHAT'S next?'' my daughter asks. Her soft, expressive face has that wooden look I have seen once, or twice, in the last few months when she has spoken of her own death, so I know that she is asking me: Is this the place we have come to, now? It is. She is 23. She has adrenal cancer. Adrenocortical carcinoma is rare, with only about 150 cases a year.

LEAD: Faced with growing pressure for action to preserve the earth's ozone shield, the United Nations Environment Program urged a 30-nation conference here today to adopt measures swiftly for eliminating production and use of chlorofluorocarbons by the year 2000.

LEAD: Richard J. Ferris, chairman of UAL Inc., scheduled a news conference in Manhattan Thursday after the company's annual meeting of stockholders. It would be Mr. Ferris's first such meeting since United Airlines' pilots offered three weeks ago to buy the huge carrier for $4.5 billion. UAL said the carrier was not for sale.

LEAD: The Bureau of Land Management is considering a policy change that would allow the killing of surplus wild horses and burros 90 days after they are put up for adoption. Five years ago, the bureau Director, Robert Burford, placed a moratorium on destruction of surplus, healthy wild horses.

LEAD: A special study has found that the policies of Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and those devised by Japan and West Germany in response to his appeals would do next to nothing to improve the world economy, according to officials familiar with the work.
LEAD: Princeton University will announce Tuesday that Harold T. Shapiro will resign as president of the University of Michigan to become the next president of Princeton.

LEAD: A sudden interest in high energy physics is sweeping state capitals from coast to coast. New York, Illinois and Texas are spending millions on surveys and formal proposals.

LEAD: In the corporate bond market, where a sense of wariness still prevails, many investors for the moment are reluctant to commit themsevles to long-term issues, especially after the volatility of recent days. Instead they are favoring maturities of up to 10 years.

LEAD: For a change, Ron Hextall, the Flyers' goaltender, had a night worth forgetting, but he will have bruises to remember it by. The Islanders, the magicians of playoff comebacks, upended Hextall and the Flyers, 2-1, forcing a sixth game in their Patrick Division final.

LEAD: Schenley Industries' Renfield division has assigned Pinch 12 Year Old Scotch from the Haig & Haig distillery to the Chester Gore Company. The billings, about $3 million, previously went through Grey Advertising.
LEAD: AFTER months of expectation, the magic moment arrived.
LEAD: WHAT is your excuse for not exercising regularly, not eating more healthfully or not changing some other unhealthy habit? Is it one of these?
LEAD: Three large oil companies yesterday reported first-quarter earnings that were hurt by lower oil prices.

LEAD: At least two men who are said to have connections with illegal gambling operations have testified before a Maricopa County grand jury investigating drug use by current and former members of the National Basketball Association's Phoenix Suns, according to a report in The Phoenix Gazette yesterday.

LEAD: TOASTER ovens, like microwave ovens, are handy supplementary appliances that have become increasingly popular. They might have been made just for single people, who put a premium on simplicity in their cooking and cleanup; with a toaster oven, you don't have to work with a full-size oven to prepare a small dish.

LEAD: WHEN ''Starmites'' had its premiere in 1980 at the Ark Theater Company, it was clearly the tiniest -and the most intentionally amusing -of intergalactic epics, a musical spoof that could bring smiles to the faces of the most ardent star warrior or trekkie. While its big screen cousins have gone on to a cycle of sequels, the small-stage ''Starmites'' remains singular.

LEAD: There has always been value in trash for those who know where to find it. Nowadays there is also value in disposing of trash, if one can find a place to put it. The National Waste Corporation finds itself with an embarrassment of trash, floating about the Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico on a barge. Its fate remains unclear, but it serves as a warning that more such embarrassments are likely in the absence of sound planning.
LEAD: A Long Island man was ordered extradited to Canada today after a Federal magistrate ruled there was substantial evidence linking him to the fatal shooting of a Canadian highway patrolman.

LEAD: President Kurt Waldheim tonight described as ''dismaying and incomprehensible'' a Justice Department decision to put him on a list of people barred from entering the United States. He said he had a ''clear conscience'' about his wartime activities.
LEAD: The Supreme Court, in upholding a ''propaganda'' label for films produced by foreign governments, acknowledged that the term is widely perceived as carrying a negative connotation.
LEAD: A former student radical who was arrested here last July after 14 years as a fugitive pleaded guilty on Monday to charges of planting explosive devices in 1971.

LEAD: In a year quarterbacks were not expected to arouse much interest - outside of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' taking Vinny Testaverde of Miami with the first pick - the National Football League's college draft shoved them into the forefront yesterday, when four were taken on the first round, leaving several veteran quarterbacks to wonder about their futures.

LEAD: The J. C. Penney Company will announce today that it will relocate its corporate headquarters to Dallas, according to consultants helping to plan the move from Manhattan. About 4,000 people working at Penney's 45-story tower on the Avenue of the Americas at 52d Street are affected.

LEAD: Ellington Observance One of America's greatest composers, Duke Ellington, was born 88 years ago today. He died May 24, 1974. His first composition was ''Soda Fountain Rag,'' inspired by his after-school job as, to use an old phrase, a soda jerk. His last was the musical ''Queenie Pie,'' which he did not complete.
LEAD: A Federal district judge has questioned the Government's attempt to deport two Palestinians because they were reported to belong to a Marxist faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
LEAD: * McDonald's Corp., Oak Brook, Ill., appointed James R. Cantalupo president of McDonald's International.

LEAD: THE dish that I recall most fondly from my childhood is the pot-au-feu made by my mother. It was generally a special treat served on Saturday nights. Yet as often as pot-au-feu was served, its preparation seemed to vary from week to week.
LEAD: American Jews are more willing than ever before to criticize the Israeli Government, a survey by the American Jewish Committee has found.
LEAD: ''Let me say in all simplicity, but with unequivocal clarity: I have a clear conscience.'' - President Kurt Waldheim of Austria. [ A1:4. ]

LEAD: The Senate Judiciary Committee is seeking to expand the scope of the investigations into the Wedtech Corporation to include the relationship of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d with the company.
LEAD: Columbia University will receive a gift of $25 million, the largest donation in its history, from the chairman of the Metromedia Company, Columbia officials said yesterday.
LEAD: Officials announced Monday that the state had been granted an order calling off fines that could have totaled $800,500 a day in a long-running case over prison reform.

LEAD: In a city where officials say there are more guns than people, crime influences almost every decision. It determines when people leave home, what routes they drive, where they walk. Crime is a conversational ice-breaker, like the weather or the Detroit Tigers.

LEAD: By outworking and often outsmarting their American and European rivals, Japanese companies have taken such a lead in doing business with China that other countries have only a meager chance of catching up.

LEAD: I SEE short skirts are coming back. This should make my husband happy. LEAD: The pressure of breaking a United States college baseball winning streak might finally have been too much for the Point Park Pioneers, Coach Mark Jackson said. ''With all the publicity, it makes it harder,'' he said. ''Every team is out there gunning for you. Every game is the World Series for them.

LEAD: ''THE BROTHERS QUAY'' is the umbrella title for the four animated Surrealist films (in which miniature objects are photographed in stop-motion) that make up the program opening today at the Film Forum 1. The Brothers Quay are, in fact, the American-born, London-based film makers, Timothy and Stephen (identical twins).

LEAD: Tony Collins, a running back for the New England Patriots, has apparently suffered a drug relapse and has been checked into a rehabilitation center by the team, according to a report in The Boston Globe yesterday.

LEAD: Virtually all fiscal analysts agree that more revenue is needed to reduce the Federal budget deficit. LEAD: The British Petroleum Company and the Standard Oil Company agreed yesterday on a $7.82 billion price for B.P.'s purchase of the 45 percent of Standard Oil that it does not yet own.

LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair said today that his investigation covered ''high Government officials'' as well as others and gave his strongest indication to date that he would seek indictments.
LEAD: A provincial court justice today overturned emergency regulations that prohibited protests and appeals on behalf of people detained without charge.
LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY International Convention on Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

LEAD: The Mets, playing dreadfully and having plunged into third place Monday night for the first time in 53 weeks, wasted no time yesterday in calling off last night's game with the Houston Astros. It was rescheduled as part of a twilight-night doubleheader July 24.
LEAD: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that New York City had failed to provide social services that would have kept the children of 10 poor families out of foster care.
LEAD: PETIPA, Balanchine and Tudor - not a bad trio of choreographers to represent a company, as the first mixed bill of the American Ballet Theater season proved Monday night.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Reagan Administration today rebuked Edward L. Rowny, one of its senior arms advisers, for criticizing its arms control strategy, and said his comments could complicate talks with the Soviet Union.

LEAD: Deer hunters were ranging the craggy slopes of this pineapple island over the past weekend, which suggests that even in the middle of the Pacific Ocean it's hard to get away from mankind's peculiar touch.

LEAD: ONE icy, quivering tone from Tom Verlaine's guitar is enough to announce his presence unmistakably, but that sound hasn't been heard much recently. Mr. Verlaine, the New York rocker, poet, founder of Television and an imposing influence on post-1977 guitarists, has been living and recording in Britain.

LEAD: Paramedics helping injured passengers of a van that was carrying illegal aliens after accident in San Diego near the U.S.-Mexican border. A baby was killed and at least 21 people were injured when the van rolled over while being chased by Border Patrol agents. Officials said the passengers spilled out onto the center divider when the van turned over as the driver tried to make a U-turn.

LEAD: Gracious Southern Fare Savannah, Ga., is known for its hospitality, and Northern hosts might consider having some of its specialty foods on hand for entertaining. Set out a dish of spiced or caramelized pecans, for example, and cocktail nibbles are taken care of; butter thins are all you need with ice cream or fruit for dessert.
LEAD: Bond prices ended sharply higher yesterday, helped by the strengthening of the dollar in the world currency markets, especially against the Japanese yen.

LEAD: THE mood of ''Solitude Standing'' (A&M), the quietly powerful second album by Suzanne Vega, a New York singer and composer, might be described as translucently grim. One of the most talented songwriters to emerge from the Greenwich Village folk-music world in recent years, Ms. Vega observes the world with a clinically poetic eye.

LEAD: The Milwaukee Brewers were 17-1 and had three games remaining in April as they headed into play at California last night. Here are the best April records since 1961, when the American League, preceding the National by a year, lengthened its schedule and brought about earlier starting dates. W-L Pct.
LEAD: A dispatch from Seville, Spain, on April 20 about Holy Week celebrations misidentified a church there. It is the Macarena Church.

LEAD: The Justice Department's yearlong deliberations over whether to approve a recommendation that President Kurt Waldheim of Austria be barred from the United States was largely spent investigating information that he submitted to rebut charges against him, department officials said today.
LEAD: N.F.L. Fancies the Passers Vinny Testaverde, the No. 1 choice out of Miami, was one of four quarterbacks chosen in the first round of the draft of college players. Page D31.
LEAD: QUITE by coincidence, the Pinkerton Tobacco Company has developed a product that could well find a market among smokers facing government-mandated curbs on that activity.

LEAD: After four days of political consultations, President Jose Sarney tonight named Luiz Carlos Bresser Pereira, an economist with vast business experience, to succeed Dilson Funaro as Brazil's Finance Minister.

LEAD: A pedestrian was stabbed to death on 42d Street in Manhattan yesterday morning after he accosted and scuffled with a motorist whose van may have grazed him as he tried to cross the intersection at Eighth Avenue, the police said.
LEAD: A campaign for the Prime Minister's job by a 76-year-old right-wing politician has shaken up Australian politics and inspired both jeers and alarm among his rivals.

LEAD: Research by a mechanical engineering professor at Cooper Union could make the notoriously erratic knuckleball more baffling than ever to hitters, while, for the first time, giving pitchers precise control over its disconcerting movements.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A woman buying clothes these days is justified in feeling disoriented. Designers show raised hemlines for fall, harking back to miniskirts of the 1960's. The new short skirts are said to be a sign of prosperity. A woman in a classically tailored suit, with yards of leg showing, is all set, noted one commentator, for a visit to her broker.

LEAD: The church bells tolled at 5 A.M. to signal the protest, and the people lighted candles by the graves of their dead to bid their ancestors a sort of farewell.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo will support a new six-cent-a-gallon tax on gasoline and a new property tax on automobiles to raise $975 million for improving New York's roads and bridges, officials familiar with his position said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Senate Democrats are trying to complete a bill to restrict spending on political campaigns, but the issue of public financing of campaigns could become an obstacle to passage next month.

LEAD: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, will join the actress Elizabeth Taylor at a fund-raising dinner for AIDS research on May 31, officials said Monday. The dinner, to be held in Washington, is expected to attract an audience of politicians and Hollywood celebrities. It is being given by the American Foundation for AIDS Research, a nonprofit organization.

LEAD: TIME has generally been a good editor. In this age of historical re-examination, the process of unearthing lost works by long-gone composers has become a flourishing business. Private archives, neglected library shelves and an attic or two have yielded to inquiring musicologists a good number of finds that have then found their way to the concert stage, and, in many cases, onto recordings.

LEAD: Members of the two committees that will monitor Texaco Inc. during its bankruptcy proceedings yesterday chose a representative of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to head one panel and one each from the Pennzoil Company and Tenneco Inc. to head the other.
LEAD: Frank C. Watson has been named president of Lord & Taylor, the retail fashion chain, its parent, the May Department Stores Company, announced yesterday.

LEAD: A senior Soviet arms control negotiator said today that the Reagan Administration was taking an ''unconstructive'' attitude toward Soviet proposals for the elimination of medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles in Europe. But he said an agreement remained possible this year.
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. plans to spin off a company that will develop, publish and sell software for Apple personal computers, the company said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Kirk McCaskill, a 17-game winner for California last year, underwent surgery Monday for the removal of bone chips in his right elbow and will miss about three months, according to the Angels. He was 2-0 this season. . . . Saying he didn't know where he would fit him into the outfield, General Manager John Schuerholz of Kansas City said the Royals would not re-sign Lonnie Smith, the free-agent outfielder who is eligible to rejoin the team Friday.

LEAD: Merrill Lynch Capital Partners disclosed today that the Haft family of Washington planned to sue the investment firm for unspecified damages stemming from the takeover battle for the Supermarkets General Corporation.

LEAD: Harry Seletsky, president of the Election Commissioners' Association of the State of New York and a Sullivan County Election Commissioner, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Pembroke Pines, Fla. He was 72 years old and also lived in South Fallsburg, N.Y.

LEAD: New Mexico yesterday priced a $35 million issue of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Capital Markets Corporation. Yields range from 5 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 6 percent in 1992 and 6.75 percent in 1996. Backed by the full faith and credit of the state, the issue is rated Aa by Moody's and AA by S.&P.

LEAD: SOME foods enter the mainstream of what might be called ''new'' American cooking with such subtlety as to go almost unnoticed by the casual restaurant-goer. LEAD: Two police officers were cleared Monday of wrongdoing in the death of Otis Bernard Miller, a 35-year-old transient who was the fourth black man in five months to die in confrontations with white police officers here. Mr. Miller, who had a chronic heart valve disorder, died a few hours after scuffling with the two officers, Roxana Wollam, 25, and Michael Noyes, 33, on April 5.

LEAD: Rescue workers removed two more bodies today from the rubble of a collapsed apartment complex and found a device - a central hydraulic-lift control unit - considered critical to the investigation of the disaster, Mayor Thomas W. Bucci said.

LEAD: A man arrested after a bungled jewel robbery led to a siege at a jewelry store on Rodeo Drive in Beverely Hills last June entered surprise guilty pleas today to 12 charges. The defendant, Steven Livaditis, 23 years old, pleaded guilty to three counts of murder, five of robbery, one count of burglary and three counts of kidnapping.

LEAD: The National Academy of Sciences, the nation's leading honor society for scientists, rejected a prominent Harvard political scientist today after a bruising internal struggle over whether his work amounted to ''pseudoscience'' in which equations were used to dress up mere political opinion.

LEAD: KOMUSO (priests of nothingness) was a Japanese name for the wandering Zen monks who refined the playing of the shakuhachi, or bamboo flute, during the 17th and 18th centuries. One of the first albums of traditional shakuhachi music released in America was called ''A Bell Ringing in an Empty Sky.''

LEAD: Hoping to make the health of cities a major issue in the Presidential primaries, the United States Conference of Mayors today began drafting an urban policy platform here to serve as a ''message'' to candidates of both parties.
LEAD: The Tonka Corporation announced yesterday that it had named James D. Miller president of its new unit, Tonka Toys International.

LEAD: Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said today that Japan appeared to have ended its dumping of computer chips on overseas markets. The comment was the strongest suggestion yet from a high Reagan Administration official that retaliatory tariffs against Japan might soon be lifted.

LEAD: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said its exploration and production unit would be renamed the Maxus Energy Corporation on Thursday when it becomes independent from Shamrock's refining and marketing unit. LEAD: THE more one hears Handel on period instruments, the more one realizes how individual and particular are the orchestral pieces that have sometimes seemed cut in a generic pattern. The familiar Concerto Grosso in A (Op. 6, No. 11) begins with one of those dotted-rhythm movements that one thinks of as severe and majestic; grins of delight must have spread around Alice Tully Hall Sunday evening when the Boston Early Music Festival Orchestra gave forth instead a gentle jogging or rocking sound, nimble on its feet, moving by whole measures rather than single beats.

LEAD: The word ''orphan'' to describe children who have lost one or both parents early has an old-fashioned ring. It seems as out of date as the black stockings and high shoes worn by inmates of asylums that used to take up city blocks and loom large in the countryside. As adult mortality caused by infectious diseases declined, and parents lived long enough to raise their children, the number of orphans dropped so sharply (from 16.3 percent of the total population in 1920 to 5.4 percent in 1953) that they became what one statistician called ''a vanishing phenomenon.

LEAD: IT didn't quite have the celebrity quotient of the Academy Awards ceremony, but last week's International Center of Photography Awards Dinner in New York managed to bestow some Hollywood-style glamour on the field. The I.C.P. awards were the third installment of a program to honor outstanding talents in the field.

LEAD: Jan Stephenson and Cindy Hill both birdied the 18th hole to take a one-shot lead today after three rounds of the S&H Classic. But the player capturing the most attention was Myra Blackwelder, seven and a half months pregnant, who is among four players right behind the leaders.

LEAD: GEORGE BALANCHINE did more than specialize in the kind of plotless dance works that have come to be known as abstract ballets. He made certain that all his abstractions were different in character. Just how different his ballets could be was demonstrated Thursday night when the New York City Ballet offered ''La Source'' and ''Stravinsky Violin Concerto'' at the New York State Theater.
LEAD: Geraldine Fabrikant's article ''Not Ready for Prime Time?'' (April 12), echoes the runaway excesses of all three networks and the protests from their operating managements.

LEAD: AT 8 A.M., PIERRE CARDIN AWAKENS TO TRUMPETS. Across the street from his four-story Paris town house, reveille is sounding at the Elysee Palace, the residence of the President of France.

LEAD: You like music and you like to travel. It follows that you would probably like to travel to Europe to attend one or more music festivals, but one consideration may be holding you back: how to get tickets to performances.

LEAD: Places that have seen their days of glory but still bear themselves with the dignity of a dowager are often among the most rewarding for travelers. However prim and staid, they offer an adventure in time, a plunge into the not-quite-past, a stroll through a present that no longer looks toward a future.

LEAD: Air fare cutting has come to France.

LEAD: The plans of the National Museum of American History for an exhibit on the forced relocation and detention of Japanese-Americans in World War II are arousing new debate over that period. The exhibit is part of the museum's observance of the 200th anniversary of the Constitution.

LEAD: BILLY BALDWIN'S IN-teriors - those crisp-lined rooms that epitomized elegance and sophistication from the 1950's through the early 70's - had such a powerful effect on design that his name became synonymous with American style. Popularly referred to as the dean of decorators, Baldwin, who died in 1983, has been an inspiration to old-guard designers for as long as anyone can remember.

LEAD: Feminists and their friends roasted and toasted one of their own, Dr. Donna E. Shalala, the president of Hunter College, last week at a champagne-and-stuffed-chicken dinner atop the World Trade Center.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II speaking yesterday in Bottrop, West Germany, as he addressed an audience of some 12,000, many of them coal miners and steel workers. The Pope called for ''the just distribution of jobs and wealth'' and urged better treatment of foreign workers. He said, ''Unemployment that is not the fault of the unemployed becomes a social scandal when available work is not distributed fairly and the profit of the work is not used to create new work for as many possible.

LEAD: Alison Collier, a daughter of John D. Collier of New York and Mrs. Robert Woodruff of Atlanta, plans to be married June 20 to Robert Bajek, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bajek of Clifton, N.J. Miss Collier is an executive assistant at the New York real estate company S.K.S. Associates. Mr. Bajek, a graduate of Colorado State University, is a sales manager for Nozaki America, a New York import company.
LEAD: PLEASE,'' SAID THE frustrated politician on the other side of the Formica breakfast table in a New Hampshire hotel, ''keep your mind open to the possibility that I'm not weird.''

LEAD: The Reagan Administration's support for the Nicaraguan rebels has been marked by contradictions - and the potential for misleading Congress - ever since President Reagan approved support for the rebel forces nearly six years ago, according to present and former Administration officials.
LEAD: THE Rent Guidelines Board faces uncertainty about its membership and jurisdiction as it prepares to hold public hearings on setting new rent levels for tenants in 18 Westchester communities.

LEAD: ELIZABETH BOWEN'S ''DEATH OF the Heart,'' published in 1938, remains an exquisite exploration of adolescence. Even today, when teen-ager anxieties seem centered on whether or not Molly Ringwald will get a date for the school prom, the novel can whisk readers back a mere 50 years to a time when a sensitive 16-year-old girl named Portia might still have to confront the profoundly unsettling specter of Innocence Betrayed.

LEAD: Snipers inside a trailer opened fire today on police officers searching a rugged mountain wilderness for three heavily armed fugitives, then were killed when a fire destroyed the mobile home, the authorities said.
LEAD: Tony Fernandez's two-run double in the bottom of the ninth inning gave the Toronto Blue Jays a 9-8 victory over the Texas Rangers today. It was the fifth straight triumph for Toronto.

But while the scholars have been theorizing, Mr. Copeland has been busy putting theory into practice. LEAD: THESE DAYS, IF A WOMAN LEANS FORWARD and a bit of an essential underpinning shows, it is not considered a fashion faux pas. Quite the opposite. Today's teddies, brassieres, bustiers, camisoles and corselettes are designed to be seen, and not just in the boudoir. The best do the things they have always been intended to do - help support or shape up a comely figure.
LEAD: Susan Gail Santon was married yesterday to Dr. Athleo Louis Cambre at the Helen Hills Hills Chapel at Smith College in Northampton, Mass., by the Rev. James Sipikowski, a Roman Catholic priest.

LEAD: Jay L. Turoff, the former head of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission, already facing a prison term after having been found guilty three weeks ago of tax evasion, was indicted on new Federal and state charges last week in a case that prosecutors said involved illegal medallions.

LEAD: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan departed today, carrying President Reagan's pledge to oppose protectionist trade remedies in Congress and lift $300 million in tariffs on Japanese goods ''as soon as possible.''

LEAD: The pilot of a military jet who was performing aerial maneuvers was killed when his plane crashed and exploded Friday night, the authorities said.

LEAD: Troops shot to death a doctor and another civilian who were violating the nightly curfew intended to curb violence by leftist rebels in Lima, newspapers reported today. The shootings Friday raised to at least 18 the number of people slain by security forces during curfew hours. The restrictions, in effect from 1 A.M.

LEAD: SINCE the 1970's, health and life insurance for people labeled high risk - either because they have medical problems like hypertension or because they engage in hazardous activities like sky diving - has become more and more affordable. The reason: Medical and technological advances have enabled the industry to assess more accurately the underwriting risks, and more insurers began competing to cover risky applicants.
LEAD: Iranian marines looking for goods bound for Iraq intercepted and boarded 14 foreign oil tankers and other ships Friday at the Strait of Hormuz, the Iranian press agency reported today.

LEAD: LEFT-handed starting pitchers havethrown a shutout at the Detroit Tigers, but their irrepressible manager remains undaunted and as orally outrageous as ever. The Tigers, in games played in April, lost all six started against them by left-handed pitchers, making them the only team in the major leagues without a victory in such games.
LEAD: The marriage of Susan Nathalie Smith to James Mark Stiles took place yesterday at St. Peter and Paul Russian Orthodox Church in Meriden, Conn. The Rev. Raphael Rodiliski performed the ceremony.

LEAD: While they single out a few companies and top executives for plaudits, the graduates of six leading schools of management are generally critical of American management as shortsighted and preoccupied by merger mania. They also disdain members of corporate boards as inattentive, ill-informed and too slow to fire inept chief executives.

LEAD: After six games of provincial passion, the Montreal Canadiens relentlessly established themselves as the dominant team in Quebec, if only for one night. On the evening that the Stanley Cup series against the Quebec Nordiques reached its climax, tonight was enough.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: FOR ROBERT RAUSCHENBERG all the world's a canvas - and a palette. Up to his elbows in paper pulp in China, in mud-manure straw clay in India, in red-brown tribal facepaint in a Venezuelan village on the Amazon or a mixture of sands from Israel, Mr. Rauschenberg takes materials and images, techniques and information from cultures around the globe and uses them in his art.

LEAD: A TRIP to the Corporate bookshelf usually provides some food for thought,and my latest excursion was no exception. In ''Managing Your Mind and Mood Through Food,'' Judith J. Wurtman, a nutrition expert, says the overriding, undeniable reason many people feel listless at conferences and seminars - wait, don't nod off yet -is that they eat incorrectly.

LEAD: What is happening to our priorities when we train 800 children to make clowns of themselves in a ludicruous extravaganza masquerading as ''creativity for the gifted''? [ ''Olympics of the Mind,'' Long Island Journal, March 15 ] . This is pure entertainment and, as one official said, ''mass insanity.
LEAD: Harness racing returns to Roosevelt Raceway with the opening of the spring meeting Monday. The meet will offer 48 programs, concluding Sunday, June 14.

LEAD: THERE WAS A TIME WHEN GOING TO THE movies let us sink into solitude, when the archetypes of ideal women were before us in all their vast simplicity, as aloof as goddesses, nine feet high. They represented what we wished we were or thought we were, would like to be, ought to be, ought not to be.

LEAD: The sight of Carl R. (Spitz) Channell after he pleaded guilty this week to felony charges for raising money for the Nicarguan rebels brought out strong emotions in Mary J. Adamkiewicz, who contributed $60,000 to his organization last year. She wanted to give him more.

LEAD: OF all the grim images that have ruled Newark, overshadowing small signs of hope whenever they arose, none has been more severe than that of its high-rise housing projects. Ravaged, worn, largely vacant and looming over their crumbling neighborhoods, they have become towering reminders of the city's failure to care for its own.

LEAD: IT was a warm afternoon, but Lynne Arico said she felt a chill as she watched the caretakers throw dirt on the coffin, slowly burying it. Aaron Brown stared at the hole; he said he was wondering how deep it went and whether the man inside had led a happy life.

LEAD: The search for really good original crime novels in paperback can have its rewards, and one of them is HE DIED WITH HIS EYES OPEN by Derek Raymond (Available Press/Ballantine, $4.95). Mr. Raymond, a British author, writes about an unnamed Scotland Yard sergeant who works in what is called the Factory.
LEAD: 'Castle' in Search of a King LOOKING for a new Long Island abode? If you have $52 million and enough matches to light 39 fireplaces, Oheka may be just the place for you.

LEAD: FROM the southernmost tip of Texas to way down East in Maine, battle lines are being drawn in the sand over the fate of the nation's remaining undeveloped beaches, marshes and wetlands. LEAD: NOW that publishers are printing their best children's books in their own paperback editions, brows are knitting as serious trend watchers ask what it all means. Will paying one-third the hardback price deprive a child of two-thirds of the book's literary experience? Is the only real book a hard-cover book?

The measure, signed into law Nov. 25, 1986, resulted from dozens of complaints by people who were turned down for an apartment because their jobs were considered a potential nuisance.

LEAD: D.O.A. Hal Roach Studios. 83 minutes. $29.95.

LEAD: Million-dollar lawsuits and other financial woes have forced 106-year-old Bishop College here to file for bankruptcy, according to attorneys for the school. Bishop's filing Thursday under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws came five months after the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools revoked its accreditation because of the college's financial instability.

LEAD: ONE of the great experiments in American history begins Tuesday, when the Immigration and Naturalization Service will offer legal status to millions of illegal aliens. No one is sure what to expect, and perhaps the only thing certain is that, like much social policy legislation, the new law will have unforeseen, unintended consequences.
LEAD: COCAINE has become a fixture on the American sports scene.
LEAD: A Federal grand jury has indicted a New York company, accusing it of using untrained workers and falsifying safety tests on an asbestos removal project.

The Rev. David Earnest performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church. The bride is on the administrative staff of the Unette Corporation in Parsippany, N.J., a contract packager of which her father is president.

LEAD: ''The vote shows an overwhelming majority is for a tougher trade policy.'' Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Missouri Democat, on passage of his trade amendment.

LEAD: The search for an edge will be a little more difficult for criminal defendants in Federal District Court in Manhattan after July 1, when defendants who plead guilty will no longer be able to ''judge shop'' in search of a lighter sentence. The judges of the court voted unanimously last week to have all cases assigned on a random basis.
LEAD: This decaying industrial city in the northwest corner of Massachusetts may soon become the site of the largest contemporary art museum in the world.

LEAD: FRANK MORGAN'S alto saxophone improvisations proceed with the relaxed pacing and solicitous empathy of a conversation between old friends. Just as a complex phrase is winding down, he thinks of something else, another angle, and so he adds an aside. Sometimes the asides take such an unexpected turn that the fabric of the conversation threatens to unravel.

LEAD: The Navy has awarded a $4.1 million contract to a New Hampshire company that has been embroiled in a labor dispute for the past nine months and has become the object of a Congressional inquiry. A Navy spokesman said Friday that the contract, awarded to the Simplex Wire and Cable Company in Newington, N.H., did not alter the service's policy of labor neutrality.
LEAD: JAZZ: EARL HINES AND COLEMAN HAWKINS Earl Hines, Coleman Hawkins, George Tucker, Oliver Jackson. Produced by Stephen Schmidt. Directed by Karl Genus. Rhapsody Films. 28 minutes. $29.95.

LEAD: The Justice Ministry said today that it would release 24 political prisoners on Monday in an amnesty marking the birthday of Buddha, an official holiday. In addition, it said, 1,082 others in jail for other crimes will be released.

LEAD: I think what Bruce Weber is trying to say is that romantic love is a luxury, that America is growing old and tight-pocketed and that we, the ''unromantic generation,'' are the necessary result. He is correct.

LEAD: I DROVE ALL THE WAY IN THE RIGHT-HAND lane this morning,'' says one of the senior executives proudly. His five colleagues sitting around a conference-room tabel nod approval. They are part of the fast track, at the San Francisco headquarters of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, but they are also determined to sample life in the slow lane.

LEAD: THE Jersey Devil has come a long way in the last couple of hundred years. For a long time, he was generally known as the fiendish son born ''one stormy and gusty night'' to a Mrs. Leeds, a Burlington County woman ''suspected of a little amateur witchcraft.''

LEAD: ''THE TENDER LAND,'' Aaron Copland's second opera, was produced in 1954, revised and revived the next year, and has been seen occasionally - mostly on college campuses - since then. It has never really caught on, but the manifest merits evident in excerpts, workshop performances and an abbreviated recording have placed it high on the list of American works deserving re-evaluation.

LEAD: In a refreshing departure from the usual vein of such events, none of the actors who paid tribute to Sir Alec Guinness last week appeared to be practicing his or her craft. Instead, the ''Tribute to Alec Guinness'' by the Film Society of Lincoln Center was marked by unabashed admiration of his mastery.

LEAD: THE struggle over placement of public housing in predominantly white Yonkers neighborhoods as part of a court-ordered desegregation plan reached a critical stage last week with allegations of delay and conflicts over sites and the type of housing to be built.

LEAD: The Hudson River Keeper Fund will be the beneficiary of an auction at 3 P.M. today in the Garrison Union Free School on Route 9D. Ron DeSilva, a former vice president of Christie's, will wield the gavel as some unusual items go on the block.

LEAD: Americans are more likely to donate the organs of a loved one for transplant than to donate their own, according to a new survey of public opinion.

LEAD: DURING THE FIRST SCENE change of ''Little Murders,'' which opens Wednesday at the Second Stage, the sound of ''Abbey Road'' fills the theater. The Beatles music, like the Jimi Hendrix and Sly Stone songs used for breaks later in the play, provides one of the few obvious clues that Jules Feiffer's tragicomedy itself arose from the cultural and political ferment of the late 1960's.

LEAD: THERE WOULD SEEM, AT FIRST glance, no common ground whatsoever between serious architectural intentions and a tenement on Mott Street. The tenement is harsh, cramped, a pile of tiny warrens that barely meets any rational standard of decent housing. Its problems would not seem to be those that can be solved by a dose of high art.

LEAD: To the Editor: As Irvin Molotsky reports in ''Pay As You Go at National Parks'' (Travel, March 29), this is just another tax. It's repulsive in the extreme to be charged a fee to enjoy the great outdoors. Let's hope a more enlightened administration will rescind these revolting fees. BEN CALDERONE

LEAD: ON the first day of school, my junior high English teacher used to make us write essays called ''What I Did on My Vacation.'' I always invented healthy, normal activities like sailing and swimming to conceal the fact that I had spent the summer in our beach cottage pantry soaking up the fiction of Frank Yerby.

LEAD: SHARP debates have erupted in the General Assembly over legislation on housing, English as an ''official'' language, the death penalty, homosexual rights and plant closings - to name a few issues. A singular bill - H.B.7607: An Act Creating a Task Force on Manufacturing in Connecticut - that could have elicited an equal amount of polemics has surprisingly brought together quite diverse interests.

A young assistant district attorney is arguing in court against the release of an accused rapist.

LEAD: Eleven months of the year Roskilde is a peaceful town. At midday church bells sound, as they have since medieval times. Through the crisp air comes the call of a gull or a mockingbird. And then, July rolls around. Church bells are drowned out by the sound of applause. The occasional sound of a strident guitar is heard across the town, as are the voices of a sing-a-long.

LEAD: I am the same age as Bruce Weber, and I find this ''unromantic'' generation to be more honest and up front about who they are and what they want than my own generation, especially those 30- to 40-year-olds working in corporate America. LEAD: EARLIER this year, Mayor Koch lashed out at the American Telephone & Telegraph Company after learning of its plans to transfer hundreds of executive jobs from Manhattan to Basking Ridge, N.J.

LEAD: ''COMING AROUND AGAIN,'' the title song of Carly Simon's latest album, embodies everything that the 41-year-old singer-songwriter does best. This deceptively simple song, written for the movie ''Heartburn,'' distills the film's themes and atmosphere in broad, blunt strokes. Depicting a high-powered, high-strung woman struggling miserably through the rituals of daily life while her marriage is coming apart, its verses paint a concise picture of domestic desperation: ''You pay the grocer/ Fix the toaster/ Kiss the host goodbye/ Then you break a window/ Burn the souffle/ Scream the lullaby.

LEAD: I AM an insomniac. ''Me too! Me too!'' cry 30 million bleary-eyed bedfellows from apartments, Cape Cods, bungalows, condos, mansions, igloos and lanais all over the United States. LEAD: Horse Racing Pine Tree Lane Wins Easily: Pine Tree Lane continued her dominance over male rivals when she raced to a front-running 2 1/2-length victory in the $284,000 Carter Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct. Carrying 119 pounds, including Randy Romero, the 5-year-old daughter of Apalachee posted sizzling quarter-mile fractions of 0:21 3/5 and 0:44 on her way to a time of 1:21 1/5 for seven furlongs.

LEAD: Describing the low-rated but superb ''Our World'' as a ''cheap news show'' does a disservice both to the intestinal fortitude it must require of ABC honchos to keep it on the air and the intelligence of the people who produce it. LEAD: Since it was founded in 1863, the National Academy of Sciences has been dominated by practitioners of physics, chemistry and other sciences whose subject matter is particularly amenable to the rigors of mathematical analysis. Human behavior is more difficult to quantify, however, and members of the so-called soft sciences - which include sociology, political science and economics - have had trouble penetrating American science's most prestigious club.

LEAD: STOCK options have always come in a variety of shapes and sizes. There are qualified options, so-called because they ''qualified'' for tax-favored status. There are non-qualified options, on which corporations get a tax break but employees do not. And there are incentive stock options, particularly beloved by executives because they incur no tax when exercised and until recently were taxed at low capital gains rates when the stock was sold.

LEAD: ''GEOLOGIC MOMENTS'' was the mysteriously evocative name Molissa Fenley gave to the full-evening piece she and her company presented on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater. But there were times when wondering about the context and extra-dance content of the work proved more absorbing than the dance itself.

LEAD: George Steinbrenner must think all Yankee fans are fools, after he ''sold out'' on us once again. Well, I will never go to the Stadium again, and I feel the only recourse we fans have is to pool together and boycott games. When Mr. Steinbrenner sees those picket lines, maybe, just maybe he'll get the message.

LEAD: At the turn of the century, commercial traffic in New York Harbor forced most yacht racing to develop in Long Island Sound. Now there is a move to bring sailboats back into the city through a novel idea for yacht club competition.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Decades of bitter debate over the vexing problem of controlling American borders will come to a historic climax Tuesday. That is the day when the first of an expected 3.9 million illegal aliens all across the country are expected to emerge from the legal and social shadows to claim amnesty under the new immigration law.

LEAD: THERE is something different in men's dress shirts these days - women. They've worn them before, but generally not to the office. Now they have discovered that the roominess these shirts afford looks both chic and professional. What's more, men's shirts are usually more reasonably priced than standard women's styles, and who's willing to turn her back on a bargain?

LEAD: THE simple facade of an authentic folk art hints always at some deeper and more mysterious ur-world behind it. Grieg at his best -which is usually when his music is at its simplest - invents such a tradition out of thin air. And it is a world of such charm and fascination that even an entire evening of his songs - like the one Norma French and Richard Gordon offered at Alice Tully Hall

LEAD: The marriage of Sandra Bond Tregellas and Michael A. McManus Jr. took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Manhattan in a ceremony performed by the Rev. Thomas J. Joyce.
LEAD: THE LAST OF THE ONE NIGHT STANDS Written and directed by Jeff Belker. Evergreen Video Society. Available by phone (2l2) 714-9860. 28 minutes. $19.95.

LEAD: Demonstrators at Blydenburgh Road Landfill in Hauppauge yesterday, protesting return of an errant garbage-laden barge. The barge has been turned away from several states as well as Mexico and Belize, and is now in the Gulf of Mexico off Florida. Protesters hoped to urge the State Legislature and Federal Government to require the barge to dump its refuse at a hazardous-waste facility.

LEAD: THE TOMATOES ARE AGAIN flying, as they always do with the advent of a new Blake Edwards film. For a director who specializes in light farce, Mr. Edwards certainly can generate a lot of ill humor. ''Ever been steered by a critic to a movie you ended up actively despising?'' asks Amram Whiteman of New York City, one of numerous annoyed readers.
LEAD: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini appears to be in better health than Western intelligence officials generally believe, according to a magazine editor who saw the Iranian leader earlier this year.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Dr. Herbert L. Volchok, the director of the Federal Department of Energy's environmental measurements laboratory in lower Manhattan, died Thursday after suffering a heart attack at Wayne (N.J.) General Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Wayne.

LEAD: One New Yorker who does not own an automobile and needs to rent a car whenever she leaves town on business has express-service reservation numbers with major rental companies and can reserve a car without spending time dictating information.
LEAD: SHOULD companies take from the rich or give to the poor?
LEAD: To the Editor: As a long-time francophile and museum lover, I took special interest in your article on the small museums of Paris (Travel, Feb. 8). I would like to add two personal favorites.

LEAD: I AM NOT A DESSERT FANATIC. NOR do I suffer withdrawal in the absence of chocolate. However, when the mood strikes me -and it happens often enough - then I seek pure, unrestrained decadent pleasure. For the seduction to be complete, the object of my affections will be a combination of caramel with nuts, or fruit with chocolate.

LEAD: The newest building in town, a one-room Swedish log cabin held together with notching rather than nails, will resemble those of 350 years ago as soon as the logs weather a bit and shingles are cut for a roof.
LEAD: With local government in turmoil in this small Vermont town, only one thing is certain: Job openings abound.
LEAD: Trampled by the be-ins of the 60's, invaded by the drug dealers of the 70's and defaced by the graffiti of the 80's, Bethesda Terrace deteriorated into a sad, sinister mess.
LEAD: He was born in Princeton and went to Yale. Now Randy Wood is the first player from the Ivy League to perform for the Islanders, valued for his versatility and work ethic.

LEAD: THE dining room at the Culinary Arts Center of the New York Institute of Technology in Central Islip is breathtaking: soaring 20-foot ceilings, tall multipaned windows, fresh flowers and an elegant pink, rose and burgundy color scheme. If this were a commercial enterprise rather than a university restaurant, it would be the talk of Long Island.
LEAD: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan says that New York City will be able to raise $45.7 billion for major public works projects despite new Federal restrictions on tax-exempt financing.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ON THE HOT TURF OF CONTEMPORARY art, museums are beginning to look like corporate raiders. In today's market, where seven-figure prices for major 20th-century works are increasingly evident, institutions can no longer come up with the money to buy them. So they are making more aggressive pitches than ever for donations of single works and whole collections, and boldly invading the ''territory'' of other institutions to do so.
LEAD: LONG ISLAND'S pariah garbage barge gathered more than just flies last week as it meandered through the southern seas.
LEAD: The Soviet Union maintains an elaborate system for eavesdropping on sensitive United States Government communications from Soviet-bloc embassies here, according to intelligence authorities.

LEAD: WHAT kind of restaurant is Uwe's in Oyster Bay? It's a puzzlement. The slightly nautical decor with wall hangings of sailing ships and fish suggests a seafood restaurant. But the menu doesn't confirm the nautical theme.

LEAD: A chance remark in Zurich in 1985 and the subsequent discovery in Berkeley, Calif., of six manuscript pages in the plastic cover of a notebook led to the discovery of about 50 letters between Albert Einstein and his first wife. The letters are to be published this month by Princeton University Press.

LEAD: KEYSTONE An original musical composed by Lance Mulcahy. Lyrics by John McKellar. Book by Dion McGregor. Starring Ann Leslie Morrison and Wayne Bryan. 1983. Sony Video Software. 90 minutes. $59.95.

LEAD: Dr. Nina Carol Blumenthal, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Blumenthal of Southfield, Mich., was married yesterday to Dr. Scott M. Corin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Corin of Roslyn Harbor, L.I. Rabbi Lane Steinger performed the ceremony at the Northfield Hilton Hotel in Troy, Mich.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''I'm ready. This is home for me. I've lived here a long time, and the condition of life is much better here. I want to get this taken care of so I can visit my family in Mexico.'' - Melesio Sidon of San Antonio, Tex., an illegal alien who will seek amnesty. [ 1:4. ]

LEAD: MY first response was ''poor old Bridgeport.'' She's a wonderful town and would never ask for my condolences. I should have known that before I saw what was left of L'Ambiance Plaza. The huge slabs of concrete jutting into the spring sunshine and the crumbled cookie bits of the stuff looking so harmless on the muddy ground; before I heard the reporters with their endless questions - some of them humane, some astute, some just plain repetitive and dumb.
LEAD: WHILE the State Museum here pays homage to Victorian gardens in its main galleries, another show as fresh as this year's tulips has been installed in the South Gallery.

LEAD: Normally we don't pay much attention to teachers. We expect them to educate our children and practically to raise them by protecting them from drugs, crime and sexual disease, all for a lot less than we pay plumbers. From time to time, when they slip a bit in their police functions, we yell at them but we don't actually try to find out what is on their minds.

LEAD: President Reagan will seek to redefine the legislative debate over United States aid to the contras by muting a desire for military aid to overthrow the Sandinistas, White House officials said today.

LEAD: SOME 30 comedians, most from the New York area, donated their talents Wednesday evening to Comedy Cares, a benefit for several organizations serving the city's homeless. The two shows, each featuring a different lineup of talent, were taped at the Eisner and Lubin Auditorium of New York University.

LEAD: I appeal to you, a future generation of Party leaders, whose historical mission will include the obligation to take apart the monstrous cloud of crimes that is growing ever more huge in these frightful times. . . . -Nikolai Bukharin, a few days before his arrest in 1937 Will Mikhail S. Gorbachev give Leon Trotsky, Bukharin and other Bolshevik revolutionaries their rightful place in the history of the Soviet Union?

LEAD: The Harkness Chapel at Connecticut College in New London was the setting for the wedding yesterday of Alison V. Rogers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brian Rogers of Mystic, Conn., to Robert Simko, the son of Mrs. Morris Schapiro of Bayonne, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., and John R. Simko of Bayonne. The Rev.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mrs. William Sands of Malibu, Calif., of the engagement of her daughter, Susan Elizabeth Sands, to Edward Wesley Harbert 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harbert 2d of Westport, Conn. The couple plan to marry June 13. Ms. Sands, the daughter also of the late Mr. Sands, an actor, graduated from the University of California at San Diego.

LEAD: She was always short of money but managed to build herself a sumptuous opera house and a couple of palaces; she was married to the ruler of a tiny, previously obscure German state, but managed to make her village-like capital one of Europe's great cultural centers. In the mid-18th century, Wilhelmina, Margravine of Bayreuth, corresponded with Voltaire, set a new fashion in gardens and so embellished her surroundings that, today still, they make her city one of the most fascinating in Central

LEAD: THE latest United States Postal Service commemorative honors the United Way concept which was conceived 100 years ago in Denver, Colo. The stamp was released in Washington, D.C., and is on sale now.

LEAD: IN flights over the Louisiana marshes, Dave Hall, a Federal fish and wildlife agent as familiar with the territory as with his own backyard, now becomes disoriented, he says, ''because it's changing so quickly.''

LEAD: Anne Meigs Blodget and Philip Vaughan Holberton plan to be married June 6, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis M. Blodget of Wolfeboro, N.H., have announced. Miss Blodget is vice president and senior account manager in the Boston office of Johnson & Higgins, an international insurance brokerage.

LEAD: Although intensive governmental surveillance is uncovering troubling numbers of fatal medical errors at many New York hospitals, Dr. David Axelrod, the State Health Commissioner, said recently that ''the quality of hospital care in New York has never been better.''

LEAD: ALL the archeological sites along the proposed gas pipeline from Canada through upstate New York and Connecticut to Long Island were carefully identified and mapped, so that they could be properly protected. Now, an archeologist, in a view becoming increasingly widely shared, says the attempt at protecting the sites has endangered them.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: CRONUS' CHILDREN By Yves Navarre. Translated by Howard Girven. 319 pp. New York: Riverrun Press. $19.95. OUR SHARE OF TIME By Yves Navarre. Translated by Dominic Di Bernardi and Noelle Domke. 237 pp. Elmwood Park, Ill.: The Dalkey Archive Press. $20.

LEAD: MY daughter turns this way and that, striking professional model-like poses as best she knows how. I regard her with mixed feelings, my mouth perhaps too tight, lips more pursed (as my own mother might say) than smiling openly and appreciatively: an independent, willful tear sneaks warily down my cheek.

LEAD: I USED TO BE AN ANIMAL, BUT I'M ALL RIGHT NOW. By Eric Burdon. (Faber & Faber, $9.95.) Eric Burdon's autobiography should dispel any illusions readers may have about the romance of being a rock star in the 1960's. Mr. Burdon, leader of the now-defunct band the Animals, begins this cautionary tale with upbeat memories of his working-class roots in Newcastle, England, and his first exposure to American blues at the Newcastle College of Art and the Liverpool and London club scenes.

LEAD: PRESIDENT REAGAN stood in the White House Rose Garden Friday and said he was optimistic about reducing economic tensions between Japan and the United States, but there were not many people in Washington who shared his characteristically rosy outlook.

LEAD: BREAKING up large, underoccupied apartments into smaller dwellings could produce 100,000 additional housing units and lessen New York City's housing shortage, according to a report that will be released tomorrow by the city's major landlord group.

LEAD: Mary Ellen McCabe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. McCabe of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert D. Kirschner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton I. Kirschner of Brooklyn and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Rabbi Shimon Berris performed the ceremony at the Monmouth Hills Club in Highlands, N.J. He was assisted by the Rev.

LEAD: Sports and cable-TV executives should remember that over-the-air broadcasts were powerful marketing tools used to build the huge audience and interest they now command. By shutting out sizable portions of the market (especially in the case of the Yankees and SportsChannel) who are they serving? The issue is not necessarily entitlement, but more a question of access for the non-cabled viewing market.

LEAD: Dr. Cooperman is not the only state aide to have been honored recently. Hope A. Arvanitis of Lawrenceville, a media consultant at the Department of Human Services in Trenton and a former reporter and anchor newscaster for WMGM - the NBC-TV affiliate in Atlantic City - has been named an Outstanding Young Woman of America by Outstanding Americans, a Montgomery, Ala., biographical publisher.

LEAD: Smokers and nonsmokers were united in uncertainty last week as the Appellate Division of New York's State Supreme Court said it would not decide until the last minute whether the state's new smoking restrictions should go into effect Thursday as planned.

LEAD: WETLANDS are places rich with life. Swamps, bogs and estuaries, tidal flats, prairie potholes and shallow lakes, are breeding grounds and habitats for insects and amphibians, fish and mollusks, waterfowl and mammals. They are are keys to the food chain.

LEAD: WALTER TERRY once suggested that dance critics ought to try writing reviews without adjectives. There were adjectives all over the place in a program presented by Mark Haim and Dancers on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church. There were also ideas. But one longed at times to get Mr. Haim into a room without a single striking lighting or scenic effect, antic bit of soundscore, rubber face or funny walk at his disposal and see what the results would be.

LEAD: The building dominates the San Francisco skyline, not only by its 52-story height but also by its bulk: a monolith rising without setbacks from most of a city block. And the institution that occupies the building, Bank of America, was also until recently a dominator - the biggest bank in the world.

LEAD: Lewis A. Tambs, who resigned as United States Ambassador to Costa Rica in January amid reports that he and his staff had improperly assisted the Nicaraguan rebels, said today that all his actions were taken on specific orders from senior Government officials in Washington.

LEAD: NOT knowing what a piece of software really can do is one of the greatest stumbling blocks to putting it to use. Ten years ago, for instance, few writers had any idea of the value of moving blocks of text or of searching and replacing words or phrases. Today these functions are standard on most word processing packages.

LEAD: The wind whistled through a broken window and neon light bounced harshly off a cracked mirror. On the 15th floor of Manhattan's Gotham hotel on Fifth Avenue, last December, four men were assembled around a large table. Three were real estate investors, representing the new ownership of the hotel, and they were directing their fury at the fourth - 59-year-old Jack Pratt, an ambitious hotel developer from Dallas.

LEAD: WHAT may be most heartening about the emergence of an ongoing professional theater - even if only twice a season - at the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck is the concentration on plays of intelligence and substance by the producing director, Norman Kline.
LEAD: DIVINE HUNGER Cannibalism as a Cultural System. By Peggy Reeves Sanday. 266 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. Paper, $12.95. Cloth, $37.50.

LEAD: AS the creator of ''Keeping Up With the 80's,'' a mild-mannered performance piece dealing with computer technology in everyday life, Michael Smith deserves the label ''user friendly.'' Co-author of the script (with Howard Mandel) as well as the show's principal performer, Mr. Smith has an amiability that might earn him an open invitation to ''Mr.

LEAD: At the First Unitarian Church in Rochester yesterday Marion March Shackford was married to Gary Muldoon by the Rev. Robert M. Lindberg, an Episcopal priest. The bride's daughters, Laura and Sarah Chazan, were bridesmaids, and Arthur W. Muldoon was his brother's best man.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The sights and sounds will be familiar: the Senate Caucus Room overflowing with people and overheating with television floodlights; the questions about what the President knew and when he knew it; what the President's men did and why they did it; what laws were bent, broken or ignored by zealots for whom the end was more important than the means.
LEAD: DEMAND for housing in Rhode Island has brought a Texas-based developer to this growing town next to the state's capital and about an hour's drive from Boston.

LEAD: Striking employees at a missile electronics plant here have voted to decertify the United Automobile Workers as their bargaining agent, a company spokesman said. The union, which has been on strike against the LTV Aerospace plant since June, called off the strike Friday night and recalled its pickets, according to Tommy Wilson of LTV Aerospace in Dallas.

LEAD: Walt Disney World greeted visitor No. 242,831,300 at 11:14 A.M. Friday, a number officials said matched the population of the United States at that time. The visitor, Kent Robertson, a 27-year-old mechanic from Collinsville, Ill., clicked the turnstiles at Epcot Center, making him and his family instant celebrities.

LEAD: Since most Yankees and Mets games are on a cable channel I cannot receive, when I am in the mood for baseball I find myself forced to watch two other teams whose games I do receive - the Braves and the Cubs. Need I say more? GIL RENBERG Chappaqua, N.Y.

LEAD: PAT DAY recalled in the jockeys' quarters immediately afterward that when he and Demons Begone, the favorite at 2-1, broke from the starting gate in the 113th running of the Kentucky Derby Saturday, ''we broke excellent, broke clean.''
LEAD: A MAJOR cut in transportation reimbursements may force thousands of New Jersey veterans to pay their own way when seeking treatment at Veterans Administration medical centers.

LEAD: ''Dear Daddy, I really did it.'' What 9-year-old Felix had done was to climb a tree in Connecticut. ''Dear Mommy, I'm not afraid anymore.'' What 10-year-old Lanette no longer feared was the water in a lake in Vermont. ''I feel like a real kid,'' said 10-year-old James, who suffers from sickle cell anemia.

LEAD: Hope Baldwin Wickser, a daughter of Mrs. Roy D. Chapin Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and Nantucket, Mass., and the late Robert Livingston Wickser of Buffalo and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to David Scott Weil, the son of Nancy E. Weil of Philadelphia and Fredrick S. Weil of New York. The Rev.

LEAD: Bruce Weber's perceptive article ''Alone Together: The Unromantic Generation'' (April 5), did not go far enough. It should have been entitled ''The Unromantic Age.'' Though yuppies in their mid-20's may reflect most obviously a loss of human values, the trend is much more pervasive. Consider the longstanding success of ''Dallas,'' Madonna's hit song ''Material Girl,'' the beer commercial ''You Can Have It All'' and the recent scandals originating in greed.

LEAD: An article April 19 profiling the community of Hoboken, N.J., incorrectly charactrized house prices. Detached single-family houses sell for up to $700,000; brownstones range in price from $200,000 to $500,000.

LEAD: KINER'S KORNER At Bat and on the Air - My 40 Years in Baseball. By Ralph Kiner with Joe Gergen. Illustrated. 239 pp. New York: An Associated Features Book/Arbor House. $16.95. NAILS The Inside Story of an Amazin' Season. By Lenny Dykstra with Marty Noble. Illustrated. 215 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company.

LEAD: ENCOURAGED by recent Federal grants toward its new $36.4 million center for the diagnosis and treatment of cancer, the Center for Molecular Medicine and Immunology in Newark has begun adding to its staff.

LEAD: Not all those in Moscow who are being denied the right to travel abroad are victims of Soviet restrictions. At least one, a pianist, has failed to get permission from the United States to accept American concert engagements booked for him since he won the Chopin piano competition in Warsaw in 1980.

LEAD: Even with their Twin Towers intact, the Houston Rockets cannot seem to figure out how to beat the Seattle SuperSonics. The Sonics beat Houston in four of their five regular-season meetings when the Rockets' Twin Towers - Ralph Sampson and Akeem Olajuwon - were hobbled with injuries.

LEAD: When he resigned in March from the PTL television ministry, the Rev. Jim Bakker hoped his exile would be brief. But last week the board of PTL (which stands for Praise the Lord and People That Love) unanimously agreed that he would not be reinstated. They voted to stop paying him and his wife, Tammy Faye, who together made $1.6 million last year in salaries and bonuses.

LEAD: The marriage of Eileen Theresa Burke and Thomas Andrew Sheridan Bucaria took place yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Plainfield, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the bridegroom's brother, the Rev. James A. Bucaria. who was assisted by the Revs. Joseph Mirandi, Dennis Corado and Charles
LEAD: About 300 demonstrators converged on the Seabrook nuclear power plant today to protest attempts to reduce its evacuation zone, and 99 were arrested when they refused to leave.
LEAD: Study this scene and spot the one false note.
LEAD: AFTER a lively campaign, the Swiss voted overwhelmingly in a nationwide referendum last month for Government proposals that will restrict the entry of people seeking asylum here.

LEAD: I wish you had interviewed me. After all, I fit the mold. I am 27, an honors graduate of Stanford who worked on Madison Avenue. I had my own income, my own apartment, a great social life and no intention of marrying before 30.

LEAD: AS the Presidential race begins, Long Island's two Republican Congressmen, like most of their New York Republican House colleagues, have endorsed Vice President Bush at an early stage of the contest for the Republican Presidential nomination.

LEAD: As the United States and the Soviet Union seemed to be moving cautiously toward an agreement to remove their medium-range missiles from Europe, there was more contentious talk last week among officials concerned with arms control.

LEAD: He strode through the flower-draped paddock at Hialeah Park in Florida, an intense man in a navy blazer. A shock of silver-streaked hair spilled down his forehead; his craggy features were deeply tanned. As he stopped next to one of the horses being saddled for the afternoon's featured race, a woman nearby tugged at her husband's sleeve.
LEAD: About 200 leftist rebels backed by artillery and mortar fire attacked the main army base here today and at least 18 people were reported killed.
LEAD: To the Editor

LEAD: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Charleston, S.C., yesterday, Caroline G. Barone, a daughter of Mrs. Oliver Rhett Talbert and Dr. Bartolo M. Barone, both of Charleston, was married to Mark Dana Schultz, the son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Carl F. Schultz Jr. of Glastonbury, Conn., and Craigville, Mass.

LEAD: Stanford and Clemson received a record payout of $900,000 for playing in the Gator Bowl football game last December, bowl officials announced Friday. The previous high payout was in 1984 when Oklahoma State and South Carolina received $831,020 each.

LEAD: America's schools have failed in their task of educating children about the country's racial heritage and teaching them constructive ways of confronting prejudice and fear, a group of mental-health and education experts agreed last week.

LEAD: When the Phelps Dodge copper smelter in Douglas, Ariz., closed for good in January, the city of 14,100 people lost a $9 million yearly payroll and 350 jobs - a substantial blow to its economy. But it gained a potential asset: unpolluted air.

LEAD: Sports fans are not guaranteed the right to have free television coverage of games. But it is to the ball clubs' advantage to let the fans view the games on broadcast television. By encouraging fan interest and hence loyalty, people will want to go to the ball park. A professional team has to balance the need to increase revenues with cable television and the need to encourage fan loyalty.

LEAD: Bruce Weber does offer hope, though, when he states that ''young people are older than they used to be.'' I suspect that by the time they are 30 they will be sufficiently bored by their own constrictions to go through ''mid-life crisis.'' Fortunately, they will be young enough to start over, or to start, period.

LEAD: HANSEL AND GRETEL Opera by Humperdinck. Starring Judith Blegen, Frederica von Stade, Rosalind Elias, Jean Kraft. Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and Chorus, conducted by Thomas Fulton. Bel Canto: Paramount Home Video. 104 minutes. $39.95.
LEAD: CAN WE DO WITHOUT AN enemy? Can the United States do without the Soviet Union as its archfoe, and vice versa? What kind of world would we see without this habitual animosity and confrontation?

LEAD: EVERY SEASON BY THE PAUL Taylor Dance Company brings into focus a different and rich aspect of Mr. Taylor's choreography. In the past, both the sense of ambiguity and the theme of duality common to his work have been highly noticeable. More recently, some of his pieces have demonstrated an uncanny use of abstract form to evoke realism in character and locale.

LEAD: EVEN as Congress made final preparations for the opening this week of its public hearings on the Iran-contra scandals, a central question was resolved. There is no longer any doubt that Federal criminal laws were broken.
LEAD: As Israeli leaders lunge for each other's throats and Reagan policymakers dabble, the Soviet Union has moved swiftly and deftly to reestablish itself in the Middle East.

LEAD: ONCE, musical comedies were just what Broadway did best. Now, the season's new American musicals have dwindled to none. What to do, but to turn to ''Guys and Dolls'' for sustenance. After all, if one musical can represent the best of Broadway's best, this is the one.

LEAD: I wish to protest negative reporting re the shortage of electric power on Long Island [ ''Lilco Sounds Sharp Alarm on Power,'' April 12 ] . LEAD: Turning parking lots into housing is old hat to George Greene, whose most recent project along those lines is a condominium development in the heart of Queens called White Oak at Elmhurst. The difficulty is finding and buying the parking lots.

LEAD: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney announced that Quebec had finally agreed to sign the Canadian Constitution last week, after holding out for 20 years. Under a widely applauded agreement with Mr. Mulroney and the premiers of the nine other provinces, French-speaking Quebec will be recognized as a ''distinct society.

LEAD: SUDDENLY, IT IS NO LONGER enough for a photograph to be a picture of something. For a photograph to succeed in the art world, all the signs this spring suggest, it needs to be an object. And the more elaborate, the better.
