LEAD: DESPITE its size and prominence, the Samuel R. Smith Infirmary - a great red-brick Victorian castle in New Brighton, S.I. - is a building that has fallen through the cracks.

LEAD: The waterfront in Hastings-on-Hudson and that of Irvington have both come into sharp focus recently [ ''Development Along the Hudson: Two Villages, Two Approaches,'' April 5 ] . The approaches to the problem are in direct contrast.

LEAD: It seems everyone is making a big fuss about the paucity of games being broadcast on free television these days. Others may welcome the opportunity to experience a season of baseball in a new way. Actually an old way, the way it was before picture tubes, slow-motion replays and remote controls evolved to render the fan an unthinking, lifeless lump, slouched six times a week in a recliner.

LEAD: The marriage of Kristine Kachlein and David Rome Ehrlich took place yesterday at the Ione (Calif.) Community United Methodist Church. The Rev. Faith Whitmore performed the ceremony.

LEAD: THERE are too many living ghosts of the Nazi past around for any European nation to feel that the case of Kurt Waldheim is simply an isolated Austrian matter. This month France warily confronts the trial of Klaus Barbie, the erstwhile Gestapo chief in Lyons; his lawyer has vowed to expose alleged betrayals by the French resistance and even of the French Jewish community during World War II.

LEAD: A proposal to build a special residential high school for gifted students in New York State continues to face stiff opposition, even though the Legislature recently approved $1 million for the project.

LEAD: AS the death toll rose in Bridgeport last week, weary investigators from Federal, state and local agencies continued their search for clues in the collapse 10 days ago of an apartment building under construction there.

Does this mean that the apartment building in which I live would be reassessed at 45 percent of value if sold to a converter or a co-op corporation?.

LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North today firmly asserted his innocence of wrongdoing in his role assisting the Nicaraguan rebels and insisted his actions were taken to help the United States.

LEAD: Helen Suzman, a human-rights campaigner and South Africa's longest-serving Member of Parliament, has always reserved her anger for the apartheid policies of the National Party Government.

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 9 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $4.95.) A plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 2 1 THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter becomes a consuming passion.

LEAD: JOE PISTILLI, a Meriden silversmith, likes to talk about the Connecticut silver industry of yesteryear. Meriden, he noted, was known as the Silver City of the World, producing the largest volumes of silver and silver-plated wares in the world.

LEAD: As a professional team with expertise in women's career development, we wish to respond to an article by Mary Jane Genova called ''Training Women for False Hopes'' [ Opinion page, April 5 ] . Wherever a need presents itself, resourceful people are likely to hang out a shingle and solicit business; and as in most businesses, service providers include competent professionals, shysters and also-rans.
LEAD: The Federal Fish and Wildlife Service, which usually defends wildlife vigorously, was in the uncomfortable position of proposing to poison some sea gulls in the Cape Cod area.
LEAD: KIDDO By David Handler. 200 pp. New York: Available Press/ Ballantine Books. Paper, $4.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Two Massachusetts residents, a carpenter from Chelmsford and an operator of a messenger service in Melrose, and a resident of Connecticut won Wednesday's $9.7 million Massachusetts Megabucks jackpot. David Ellis, a spokesman for the Massachusetts Lottery Commission, said Thursday that the three winners each would each receive $121,626 a year for 20 years.
LEAD: SINCE early this year, a Soviet frigate has been steaming outside the Strait of Hormuz at the entrance to the Persian Gulf.
LEAD: METROLAND By Julian Barnes. 176 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. Paper, $4.95.
LEAD: IN counterpoint to an anti-Administration protest Monday that ended with more than 550 arrests, one man carried a sign reading: ''Go Home Amy - You Too Abby.''

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Nathan Kase of Manhattan and Katonah, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Anne Kase to James Henry O'Brasky, a son of Elizabeth H. Barnston of New Haven and Harris O'Brasky of Medway, Mass. The couple plan to be married June 21.

LEAD: Leslie Joy Shecter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Shecter of New City, N.Y., was married there last night to Todd Andrew Hammer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Hammer of New York. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Dellwood Country Club.
LEAD: If you need to watch a ball game, go to the ball park. Support your home team. Otherwise, we may find ourselves watching a free broadcast originating from New Jersey. SALVATORE MESSANO Brooklyn

LEAD: The matter of ''entitlement'' to view free games at home may be debatable, but to baseball teams concerned about increasing the ranks of their fans there can be but one answer. Make it as easy (especially for those without access to cable) and as inexpensive as possible to follow what players are accomplishing.

LEAD: TO JUDGE BY THE JUNK MAIL, TELEVISION commercials and print advertisements, a great many people are worried that you, whoever you are - corporate employee or self-employed, old or young, white collar or blue collar - do not have the right kind of health insurance.

LEAD: FOR nearly a decade now, analysts have been saying that American income inequality is growing and that the middle class is declining. Yet, while casual observations - widespread layoffs, large numbers of families headed by single women - support their point, Census statistics paint a different picture.

LEAD: Ronald Weigel of East Germany won the 50-kilometer event in the World Cup of race walking yesterday in Central Park, and that's not too surprising. Weigel has walked the two fastest times in history in the distance and yesterday's finish, 3 hours 42 minutes 26 seconds, was a World Cup record.

LEAD: STORIES. By Cesare Pavese. Translated by A. E. Murch. (Ecco, $12.95.) In 1950 the Italian novelist and poet Cesare Pavese committed suicide at the age of 41, just three months after receiving his country's highest literary prize, the Premio Strega, for his novel ''Among Women Only.'' Numerous short works of fiction were found among his papers; the present collection includes 22 examples, of varying length and quality, rather ploddingly translated by A.
LEAD: Hector Camacho, the World Boxing Council lightweight champion, came into the ring today at the Convention Center to the sound of boos - a reaction to his performance in recent fights.

LEAD: NUCLEAR FALLACY Dispelling the Myth of Nuclear Strategy. By Morton H. Halperin. 173 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Ballinger Publishing Company. $19.95.
LEAD: A Federal district judge has appointed an outside overseer to supervise the Veterans Administration's compensation and pension division for an indefinite period.
LEAD: THE OLD LEFT By Daniel Menaker. 132 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

LEAD: WHY should the average American care about the record trade deficits? Because, many economists say, they may lead to lost jobs, fewer products at higher prices and general austerity. The recession in the farm belt, which was deepened by contracting overseas markets for American food, may spread across the economy if the imbalances are not redressed.

LEAD: The Sacred Sites and Properties Fund, a matching-grant program for the preservation of architecturally significant religious sites in New York City, is a year old this month and once again is looking for beneficiaries of its largesse.
LEAD: Patients may have died needlessly in Veterans Administration hospitals because of doctors' mistakes, according to a report made public today by a Congressional panel.
LEAD: FAST LANES By Jayne Anne Phillips. 148 pp. New York: Seymour Lawrence/E. P. Dutton. $15.95.
LEAD: IN matters of institutionalized life and death, Florida and Texas share some bleak statistics.

LEAD: In this bicentennial year of the Constitution, the home of Charles Pinckney, one of the document's original 39 signers, is at the forefront of a proposed multimillion-dollar housing development.

LEAD: A HISTORY OF PRIVATE LIFE Philippe Aries and Georges Duby, general editors. Volume One: From Pagan Rome to Byzantium. Edited by Paul Veyne. Translated by Arthur Goldhammer. Illustrated. 670 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $29.50.

LEAD: When his name was announced as he went to the plate in the 10th inning with the bases loaded, many of the 37,235 spectators tried to boo him. It came out more like a groan. What they were thinking could practically be heard across Shea Stadium: ''Oh no, it's Raines again.''

LEAD: In the sometimes conflicting testimony on many issues at the New York City Charter Revision Commission hearings so far, a common complaint has emerged. Private citizens and elected and appointed officials are saying that municipal government needs greater decentralization so that officials at every level can be held more accountable.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor
LEAD: I'm 10 years older than Bruce Weber, having graduated from Smith College in 1965. My generation began what his ended.

LEAD: Perhaps somebody in Jacob Shute's house at 25 Barrow Street thought it was a fine day for spring cleaning. Out into an abandoned cistern went all kinds of junk: pottery, plates, medicine bottles, a tobacco pipe, fish and mutton bones, teacups, buttons and at least one bullet.
LEAD: The story of an anguished love affair between Albert Einstein and the woman who would later become his first wife has emerged in newly disclosed correspondence between them.

LEAD: As the United States and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations prepare for new rounds of talks with Vietnam on missing Americans and the Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia, the Japanese are being criticized in this region for steadily expanding Hanoi trade.

LEAD: FOUNDATION - THE NAME ALONE SAYS this is serious business, the critical part of makeup. It also happens to be the most confusing. With the growing number of foundation shades and the dizzying variety of formulations - from moisturizing to oil-absorbing, from heavyweight to almost sheer - finding the right foundation can be a challenge.

LEAD: Charles E. Rothwell, a former president of Mills College and a onetime State Department official who played a key role in the conference that founded the United Nations in 1945, died Friday in Point Reyes, Calif. He was 84 years old.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: MOST people don't deliberate over Schonberg's ''Phantasy'' on their Stradavarius. But when the violin virtuoso Stephanie Chase saw that score on Herbert L. Cohen's music stand in his home a few years ago, during one of the musical evenings hosted by the Cohens in Westport, she knew he was more than an amateur.

LEAD: Of the 262,808 letters received by President Jose Sarney last year, one came from a 55-year-old woman who appealed for help in finding a husband, and another was signed by a beggar who asked to be given a 1975 taxi to take him to ''work'' each day.
LEAD: LOOKING to save $10 on a favorite perfume, $80 on a Seiko watch or perhaps $10,000 on a Mercedes-Benz?

LEAD: Carl R. (Spitz) Channell, a fund-raiser who pleaded guilty this week to illegally raising money for the Nicaraguan rebels, tried unsuccessfully last spring to involve President Reagan in soliciting contributions from military contractors for promoting the Administration plan for a defense against missiles.

LEAD: Mayhem, anyone? Try ''Murder on the Orient Express'' or ''Malice Aforethought.'' The two classy British-based suspense puzzles are back on TV this week. Novices should pounce. Those who know whodunit can savor the expertise.

LEAD: REPUBLICAN PARTY REPTILE Essays And Outrages. By P. J. O'Rourke. 220 pp. New York: Morgan Entrekin/The Atlantic Monthly Press. Paper, $6.95. THE BACHELOR HOME COMPANION A Practical Guide to Keeping House Like a Pig. By P. J. O'Rourke. Illustrated. 127 pp. New York: Pocket Books. Paper, $5.95.

LEAD: To the Editor: The discussion of the Swiss countryside (Travel, April 5), jarred some personal memories. More than a score of years ago, my family toured Switzerland, staying for a few days in Interlaken. My father and I walked up into the hills. As Judith Mandelbaum-Schmid implied in ''Where Heidi Belongs,'' the Swiss mountains, even where they are not Alpine, are always Heidi-esque.
LEAD: DR. SPOCK IN PLAINFIELD
LEAD: Massachusetts has started a program in which all 150 state district court judges will be trained in better handling of cases of domestic violence.

LEAD: The Pacific yew tree, which up to now has had so little going for it that it has been left to rot when cut in logging operations, has suddenly become so much in demand that environmentalists are expressing fear about its survival.

LEAD: With pandas few and far between in New York, the city's residents - who can safely be said to have seen just about everything else - are journeying north to the Bronx Zoo. There Ling Ling and Yong Yong, loans from the Beijing Zoo, are doing what pandas always do, which is to say not much, while cameras click and voices urge ''Look over this way.

LEAD: Livingston $300,000 39 Shrewsbury Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, older colonial; kitchen with breakfast area, deck, dining room, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes, $4,004. Maplewood $143,000 22 Manley Terrace 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 45-year-old colonial;

LEAD: Pope John Paul II tread some fine theological and political lines in Cologne, West Germany, last week in beatifying Edith Stein, a Jewish-born nun who was murdered in Auschwitz. Some Jews criticized the beatification, apparently the first of a Jewish-born Catholic, saying Edith Stein was not martyred as a Christian but as a Jew.
LEAD: Antonio Borja Won Pat, former delegate to Congress from Guam, died of a heart attack Friday at Holy Cross Hospital, hospital officials said. He was 78 years old.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: The real issue facing us is not whether viewers should have to spend a few extra bucks a month to see games on cable as opposed to free television; it's whether they should be able to see games at all. People are finally getting awfully mad about the unavailability of cable television for most New York homes.
LEAD: Throughout the 1960's, Mountain View, Ark., was cut off from the world. There were no paved roads, no railroad tracks and no bus lines into this remote Ozark community.

LEAD: THE United States is fast becoming a nation of two classes, with the haves growing richer, the have-nots growing poorer, and the middle class slowly sinking into oblivion. We should resist this trend, not just to preserve a more equitable society, but also to avert disaster.
LEAD: CONSTITUTION IN LEXINGTON

LEAD: Who but the madcap Mark Morris would rent the grand ballroom of the Manhattan Center for a striptease - and two other dances based on the essays of Roland Barthes? The Mark Morris Dance Group moves into the ballroom on Wednesday for five performances of ''Mythologies,'' which includes ''Soap-powders and Detergents,'' ''Striptease'' and ''Championship Wrestling.

LEAD: New Rochelle,N.Y. $173,000 54 Clove Road 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 66-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, den, fenced yard, walk to schools; taxes $2,144. North Salem, N.Y. $255,000 Hilltop Drive 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, new clapboard coloni
LEAD: WHEN THINGS GET BACK TO NORMAL And Other Stories. By Constance Pierce. 255 pp. Normal: An Illinois State University/ Fiction Collective Book/Sun & Moon Press. Paper, $7.95. Cloth, $15.95.
LEAD: The way things are going, it will be hard for the Democrats to lose the Presidential election of 1988, but they might just do it.

LEAD: Well-tuned by the religious observances of April, choral groups now propel themselves into a busy May. Sunday afternoon at 4:45, the Manhattan Choral Festival sings Vivaldi, Vaughan Williams and Samuel Adler at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue and 50th Street, in a Christian sabbath celebration, and Sunday evening at 7, the Merkin Concert Hall at the Abraham Goodman House (129 West 67th Street) offers ''A Time for Freedom,'' a concert in support of Russian Jewry.

LEAD: Harvard alumni who want the university to purge its endowment of holdings in companies doing business in South Africa have put together a slate of candidates for the Board of Overseers, one of the university's two governing bodies.

LEAD: Ken Perry, a 27-year-old rookie on the PGA Tour, said he was so nervous he couldn't sleep. Tied for the lead with three more experienced golfers -Hal Sutton, Dan Pohl and Ken Brown -Perry will be going after the top prize of $225,000 in Sunday's final round of the $1.2 million Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational.

LEAD: ''I AM AS INSECURE AS I EVER was,'' says Ned Rorem, the 63-year-old Pulitzer Prize-winning composer. ''If I don't have tangible proof every day of the week that I am appreciated - a commission, a letter from a stranger, a performance by someone somewhere - I suffer.''

LEAD: When his best logger quit for a better-paying job cutting timber in California, Bruce A. Vincent felt cheated - not by the employee but by the Montana Division of Workers' Compensation. ''There was nothing we could do,'' said Mr. Vincent, business manager for Vincent Logging Inc. here. ''With the cost of workers' compensation insurance so high, we can't compete with neighboring states.

LEAD: MY TIRADE AGAINST MYSELF At 71, Jorge Luis Borges had had such a copious literary career that he even grew a bit tired of himself. At least this is what he says in ''Critical Essays on Jorge Luis Borges'' (G. K. Hall), edited by Jaime Alazraki.
LEAD: BARRY GERSTEN wants to light up a lot of cigarettes outside his new pharmacy in Stamford, but not in the conventional manner.

LEAD: COD STREUTH. By Bamber Gascoigne. (Available Press/Ballantine, $4.95.) When Jacques le Balleur, the Calvinist monk at the center of this bizarre short novel, is captured by Tupinili cannibals in the Brazilian jungle in 1560, his primary concern is that he will become the pagan tribe's next meal.

LEAD: I disagree that ambition or even a moderate amount of consumerism, per se, creates an emotional void. Is a winter sunset any less brilliant when viewed through an office window? Is ''West Side Story'' less memorable on a VCR?

LEAD: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Theme and Variations'' is more than a set of choreographic patterns to music by Tchaikovsky. When well danced, this ballet can have the elegance of a fancy party. Its variations can seem like sparkling repartee and its duets can resemble the sonnets two sophisticated lovers might send each other.

LEAD: It took a ruling by New York's highest court before a group of homosexuals was permitted to incorporate as the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund Inc. in 1973. Even as recently as 1980 Lambda was, in the words of its executive director, ''still a bit too fringe'' to be taken seriously by many people outside the homosexual community.

LEAD: A strong trade bill was passed by the House with enough votes to override the Presidential vet that is certain to come if the bill makes it to the White House included in the omnibus legislation was an amendment sponsored by Richard A. Gephardt, a Missouri Democrat, that requires the President to retaliate against nations with the biggest trade surpluses with the United States, if it is determined that the surplus was a result of unfair trade practices.
LEAD: The political party of Joshua Nkomo designed an emblem not long ago intended to reflect an anticipated merger with the ruling party of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe.

LEAD: When the chief labor negotiators for the National Football League players and owners exchanged opening proposals for a new collective bargaining agreement two weeks ago, they gave each other documents that reflected vast differences in how they think professional football's economic system should operate.
LEAD: FOR ITS last play of the season, the Crossroads Theatre Company is presenting, through May 17, an incendiary work: ''Split Second,'' a 1984 Off-Broadway production.

LEAD: SOUTH AFRICA: A Different Kind of War - From Soweto to Pretoria. By Julie Frederikse. (Beacon, $12.95.) This collection of interviews, government statements, opposition leaflets and posters and photographs is as vivid a slice of life as can be found since the South African Government clamped down on press coverage, especially photographic, of this tormented country.

LEAD: RECORDINGS THAT EXPLORE byways of the classical repertory can often prove more stimulating and satisfying than repeated versions of the familiar. There is always a possibility, however unlikely, of discovering unaccountably ignored major works. Furthermore, this is an area in which performing groups that cannot quite compete with the world's finest in the standard repertory can make real discographic contributions.

LEAD: IN the days when coal was king, mules on a narrow towpath pulled canal boats along an elevated aqueduct near Lackawaxen, Pa., spanning the Delaware River from coal-rich Pennsylvania into New York.

LEAD: New York City's prison ferry, which opened three months late and $3 million over budget, is 60 percent empty because its operation is being changed to prevent $3 million in unexpected staffing costs.

LEAD: THIS IS BEING WRITTEN IN THE MIDST OF A new production here of ''Der Ring des Nibelungen.'' The subject, however, is neither the performance of Wagner's music nor Ruth Berghaus's avant-garde staging. My concern here is with the sociology of opera - how the very experience of going to opera in Frankfurt seems so different from that in New York.

LEAD: MOST errors are banal and need no explanation; they are made by grandmaster and amateur alike. Yet every once in a while there is something intriguing about an error. We are prompted to ask why. Consider, for example, the game between Grandmasters Alonso Zapata of Colombia and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland in the ninth round of the Hoogoven International Tournament in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: HE's 59 years old now, a retired Wall Street institutional broker living in Stuart, Fla., in a condo on a golf course. Every so often he puts on a sweat suit and sneakers and goes over to the Martin County High School gym where the coach, Don Wallen, lets him shoot baskets. One day not long ago when the high school players were shooting free throws, one of the kids asked him if he wanted to shoot, too.

LEAD: During its 10 seasons, the Pan Asian Repertory Theater has introduced audiences to plays of Chinese, Japanese, Indian, Filipino and other Asian - and Asian-American - derivation. The current show, Che Inhoon's ''Wha . . . i, Whai, a Long Long Time Ago,'' is the first from Korea. In common with many of the previous plays given by this resourceful company, it demonstrates both a universal application and a cultural specificity.
LEAD: SCIENCE IS HAVING a picnic with the human embryo. In South Africa it has a woman pregnant with her own grandchildren - three of them at latest count.

LEAD: A STRANGE paradox has developed in retailing lately. When department stores increased the initial prices of the merchandise, their profits ebbed. Now that they are reducing some of the list prices, their profits have picked up.

LEAD: THE homeowner who decides to repaint the outside of his house often finds that shopping for exterior paints or finishes can be confusing, because there are quite a few types from which to choose. This is particularly true when manufacturers make conflicting or exaggerated claims, or when you are dealing with a salesman who may not be as knowledgeable as he should be.

LEAD: A strong trade bill was passed by the House with enough votes to override the Presidential vet that is certain to come if the bill makes it to the White House included in the omnibus legislation was an amendment sponsored by Richard A. Gephardt, a Missouri Democrat, that requires the President to retaliate against nations with the biggest trade surpluses with the United States, if it is determined that the surplus was a result of unfair trade practices.
LEAD: The political party of Joshua Nkomo designed an emblem not long ago intended to reflect an anticipated merger with the ruling party of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe.

LEAD: When the chief labor negotiators for the National Football League players and owners exchanged opening proposals for a new collective bargaining agreement two weeks ago, they gave each other documents that reflected vast differences in how they think professional football's economic system should operate.
LEAD: FOR ITS last play of the season, the Crossroads Theatre Company is presenting, through May 17, an incendiary work: ''Split Second,'' a 1984 Off-Broadway production.

LEAD: SOUTH AFRICA: A Different Kind of War - From Soweto to Pretoria. By Julie Frederikse. (Beacon, $12.95.) This collection of interviews, government statements, opposition leaflets and posters and photographs is as vivid a slice of life as can be found since the South African Government clamped down on press coverage, especially photographic, of this tormented country.

There is always a possibility, however unlikely, of discovering unaccountably ignored major works. Furthermore, this is an area in which performing groups that cannot quite compete with the world's finest in the standard repertory can make real discographic contributions.
LEAD: THIS month marks the start of the Lyme disease season, and because there are indications that the disease is spreading rapidly, health agencies are devoting increasing efforts at prevention.

LEAD: WITH ATTENTION concentrated on the ascendant CD, developments in conventional phonography are easily overlooked. Yet millions of LP's, accreted over nearly four decades, still make up the bulk of the world's recorded music, and the audio industry continues to provide conventional turntables to serve the needs of listeners loyal to their older disks.
LEAD: IN ''True West,'' Sam Shepard's riveting play now at the Long Island Stage, two brothers play out a modern Cain and Abel story.

LEAD: MANY women are reluctant to splurge on expensive maternity and baby clothes. But a stylish pregnancy is possible without breaking the bank, and children can be outfitted without taking out a second mortgage.

LEAD: WHEN Mayor Koch wrote builders in 1985 for ideas on how to expand the supply of housing for households in the $15,000-to-$48,000-a-year income range, one reply came from a group organized by the Real Estate Board of New York.

LEAD: THE dollar has fallen more than 40 percent over the last two years, and some investment strategists think it could soon hit bottom. If so, investors should consider changing the strategies they used while the dollar was heading down.

LEAD: FOR the last eight years, Harold T. Shapiro has served as president of the University of Michigan, one of the country's best public research universities. Now the 51-year-old economist will be switching to the private sector. On Tuesday the trustees of Princeton University announced that by January he will succeed William G.
LEAD: Pesticides, industrial chemicals and sewage flow into the harbors along America's coasts, often collecting and concentrating to pollute the sediment, according to a Government study.

LEAD: BEGINNING Wednesday night, Pace University will be the site of an ambitious five-day series of educational programs that showcase the Smithsonian Institution's collections and research materials.
LEAD: New York City will celebrate the nation's 200-year-old Constitution, and the city's role in its creation, with various activities over the next two years.
LEAD: The 41-year-old private airport in Waterford, Conn., will soon disappear and be replaced by a high-tech office complex planned by the Reynolds Metals Development Corporation of Richmond, Va.

LEAD: THE WICHITA WINGS not only lost their final regular-season game Friday night, but their shirts as well. Following their 6-4 loss to Tacoma in the Major Indoor Soccer League finale, the Wings auctioned off their jerseys in a fund-raising move to help cope with a deficit that threatens the future of the franchise.
LEAD: With an eye to the weather, the 1990 Goodwill Games will be July 20 through Aug. 5, organizers have decided.
LEAD: THE crew of the Japanese commercial vessel Sindia got good and drunk one night in 1901, so the story goes, and she sank in the Atlantic off Ocean City.

LEAD: The chorus of doubts that has greeted the Reagan Administration's proposal to eliminate nuclear missiles from Europe includes some surprising voices. But the White House need not have been surprised to find Edward Rowny, one of the President's own arms control advisers, among the critics. He criticized the negotiations and indicated that the missile pact would be a profound mistake unless linked to relieving the

LEAD: After a week of preliminary investigations into the collapse of the L'Ambiance Plaza apartment complex here, engineers and investigators have reported little progress in determining what caused the building to fail, killing 28 people.

LEAD: THE DEFIANT MUSE Hispanic Feminist Poems from the Middle Ages to the Present. Edited by Angel Flores and Kate Flores. 145 pp. New York: The Feminist Press. Paper, $11.95. Cloth, $29.95. THE DEFIANT MUSE German Feminist Poems from the Middle Ages to the Present. Edited by Susan L. Cocalis.

LEAD: LAST WINTER, WHEN THE STEPPEN-wolf Theater Company's production of ''Educating Rita'' was closing in Chicago, a New York producer, checkbook in hand, offered to bring it all to Manhattan - the director, the two stars, even the set. It was the summons most regional and nonprofit theaters await, and one that most actors dream of.

LEAD: PAUL LAXALT is a well-known politician in two relatively small jurisdictions: his home state of Nevada, which he has served as Lieutenant Governor, Governor and Senator off and on since the early 1960's, and Washington, where he became President Reagan's unofficial agent in the Senate and the official head of the Republican

LEAD: THE J.C. Penney Company, a retailer long known for its budget-priced apparel, decided last week it was no longer comfortable in the high-rent district of Manhattan. The company announced it would move its headquarters to Dallas next year, emptying its 45-story tower on the Avenue of the Americas at 52d

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Michael Henry deYoung Tobin of Hillsborough, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Katherine Oliver Tobin to George Carroll Whipple 3d, the son of Mrs. Whipple Jr. of New York and the late Mr. Whipple. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: Scores of anti-abortion protesters demonstrated this morning at a women's clinic that performs abortions, and 75 to 80 people were arrested, the police said. The demonstration at the Northside Women's Clinic in this Atlanta suburb was part of a day of protests planned in the region by anti-abortion advocates.

LEAD: Kinji Moriyama, a Member of Parliament and a former Japanese Cabinet minister, died today of heart failure after suddenly becoming ill at a resort hotel west of Tokyo. He was 70 years old. Mr. Moriyama, a member since 1949 of the House of Representatives, the decision-making body of Parliament, served in the 1970's as Transport Minister and as director general of the Science and Technology Agency.

LEAD: For the first time in these playoffs, the Islanders could not scramble their way into a comeback. Finally, faced with a sixth glimpse of elimination and the unrelenting force of the Flyers, the combination proved too much for the Islanders.

LEAD: Judges of the New York State Court of Appeals, hearing oral arguments in a lawsuit in which a Long Island town is accused of using its zoning powers to discriminate in housing against poor people, expressed strong doubts this week about whether the plaintiffs have a right to sue.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Carl Berg of Floral Park, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Lee Berg, to Juvenal A. daSilva, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonardo daSilva of Sao Paolo, Brazil.
LEAD: ''HERE lies Les Moore,'' reads the headstone on Boot Hill. ''Shot down by a .44. No Les, no more.''
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A LIFEGUARD shortage is expected this summer and, as a result, swimming hours may be curtailed and some pools and beaches could be closed, officials say.

LEAD: BALLET COMPANIES dream regularly of new productions. But American Ballet Theater went about acquiring its latest production of ''Giselle,'' which will be seen for the first time in New York at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday, in a novel way. The fresh new sets and costumes that will be unveiled this week are actually glamorously secondhand.
LEAD: ICE AND FIRE By Andrea Dworkin. 181 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $14.95. INTERCOURSE By Andrea Dworkin. 257 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

LEAD: ANY dead stems and leaves left over from last fall should be carefully pulled or cut off perennials now and composted. Be careful not to disturb new growth and shoots. Last call to apply general garden fertilizer to established shrubs and perennials; be sure to use acid-type fertilizer for azaleas, rhododendrons and pieris.

LEAD: Thailand's Government, shaken last month by a show of disapproval from the powerful military, came under attack again this week from a new and apparently well-organized movement advocating a populist revolution.

LEAD: If it was an attempt to assassinate John Gotti, it didn't work. The reputed Mafia chief was still alive, outside his Queens headquarters with several companions, after the noise that could have been a gunshot startled the neighborhood Wednesday afternoon. Mr. Gotti denied that he had been shot at, and there was no suspect for the police to arrest.
LEAD: The shuttle Columbia on display yesterday in the Vehicle Assembly Building during the annual open house for employees and their families.
LEAD: STARTING today, New Yorkers will pay more to take a taxi. The initial ''drop of the flag'' charge is now $1.15, up 5 cents.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William Walter Gustafson of Pasadena, Calif., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Gustafson's daughter Lisa Ann Fiedler to Virgil Thomas Fryman Jr., the son of Mr. Fryman of Washington, Ky., and the late Elizabeth Louis Marshall Fryman. A June 20 wedding is planned.

LEAD: As the number of first-rate Jewish sculptors grows, the small sculpture court of the Jewish Museum becomes increasingly important. LEAD: Stephen Lunn, a London antiques dealer, holds up a big linen sheet, old and worn. Not long ago it might have wound up in a trash heap. But for a small, ardent following, this old sheet is a treasure. Its appeal lies in the soft, smooth feel that crisp new linen lacks. Renewed interest in antique textiles has further burnished its popularity - and its price.

LEAD: For decades, the effort to contain the spread of nuclear weapons has depended on several assumptions. LEAD: ACT II of ''Sleight of Hand,'' the new John Pielmeier play at the Cort, is set in ''an empty Broadway theater.'' Delmore Schwartz, who died in 1966 at the age of 53, graduated from New York University in 1935.

LEAD: New York's House delegation of 19 Democrats and 15 Republicans rarely finds itself united on any legislative action, but one of those unusual moments of unanimity occurred Thursday when Representative James H. LEAD: The Women's Foreign Policy Council, a New York-based group, has published a Women's Foreign Policy Directory of women who work as foreign policy specialists and women and groups working in international affairs.

LEAD: J. D. Salinger won another round in his legal fight with Random House when the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled yesterday in Manhattan that it would not rehear the case between the author and the publishing company.

LEAD: Some Republican and Democratic politicians said today that Gary Hart's Presidential campaign is in peril as a result of a newspaper report that a young woman spent Friday night at his home here. But Hart aides insisted that the article was based on lies and that the former Senator would emerge with his candidacy intact.

LEAD: WHILE some researchers seek better ways to detect language delays in children that could herald developmental problems, others are exploring factors that foster linguistic ability in normal children. Their findings suggest that some common parental tactics - such as talking a lot to a child in one-way conversations - are ineffective at stimulating early acquisition of language skills.

LEAD: David Hefner, the AIDS patient who renewed his wedding vows at St. Patrick's Cathedral after being told he would not be allowed to because of his illness, died Sunday night, one year after his diagnosis. He was 38 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: A Polish freighter struck a tower of a bridge at this Atlantic Coast city Sunday, causing an estimated $3 million in damage and closing the structure for up to 21 weeks, the authorities said. LEAD: Riot police entering University of the Witwatersrand hall where students had gathered for speech by Winnie Mandela, anti-apartheid campaigner. Meeting was banned minutes before she was to speak. In ensuing clash, the police arrested 120 students and fired tear gas at about 50 faculty members. Page A3.

LEAD: WAYNE SHORTER used to draw Flash Gordon-like comic strips when he was growing up in Newark; he included one on the inner sleeve of his most recent album. The music he's making these days is a lot like science fiction in its enthusiasm for new technologies and oblique strategies. His tenor saxophone sound is more down to earth; he is still the gritty Newark hard-bopper.

LEAD: Q.Why do birds molt? A.Molting is determined by a combination of physiological and environmental changes, such as breeding, light and temperature. Most birds shed their feathers once a year just after breeding, but some species molt while breeding, and still others molt after breeding and before migration.

LEAD: SUCH a shame about the baked potato. Most other vegetables cook spectacularly in a microwave oven, but the baked potato is a bust, if by baked potato you mean something with a crunchy skin and mealy, fluffy insides (but if all you want is a quick starch fix, well then, be my guest).

LEAD: FOR several years after my mother's death, I felt about Mother's Day the way I suppose recently divorced people feel about Valentine's Day. It seemed to be an organized effort by the immediate world to spit in my eye, and I gladly would have set fire to every card in every card rack in every card shop in town.
LEAD: Ken O'Brien dropped his protective emotional bubble today as he conceded that he was ''tight'' in the Jets' staggering finish last season.

LEAD: Was it bad judgment for Gary Hart, a Presidential candidate already rumored to be ''a womanizer,'' to conduct himself in such a way that he might appear to have spent a night with a woman who was not his wife? Of course it was.

LEAD: Many voters in the state that holds the first Presidential primary in 1988 seem ready to overlook the possibility that Gary Hart has been unfaithful to his wife, or, if he was, to forgive him for it. They think the more important question is whether he told the public the truth.

LEAD: Judged by weather and finances, New York City had a good winter. Mayor Koch's executive budget for the year starting July 1 reflects a big swing since early January, when the budget forecast a deficit. Tax revenues now are virtually certain to produce a $514 million surplus, an ample cushion for the new fiscal year.

LEAD: FOR children, coming down with the flu used to mean a day off from school to read comic books, watch reruns of ''My Little Margie'' and be the happy beneficiary of undivided maternal attention. Today - when nearly half of the women with children 14 and under are working outside the home - many children with colds are spending the day in places like Chicken Soup, Rainbow Retreat and Grandma's House.

LEAD: CAN the United States continue to provide the leadership required to keep the world economic and financial system stable and growing? LEAD: 1.Pins With a Past Susan Kramer makes nostalgic pins from Victorian illustrations. She lacquers them and then adds decorative touches with multicolored rhinestones. The pin shown here, the face of a pretty young woman under a jeweled hat, costs $22.50. The collection, which might have been designed especially for Mother's Day, also includes pins illustrated with cats, flowers and full-length figures.

Davis, associate director of athletics at Oregon State and the immediate past N.C.A.A.

LEAD: A 44-year-old Bronx delicatessen owner has been indicted on charges of embezzling $1.1 million in city checks meant to go to hotels that house homeless families, officials said yesterday.

LEAD: Kiss tinsel teeth goodbye. A new system of orthodontic braces made of clear industrial sapphire was introduced yesterday. Its developers hope it will replace the stainless steel, plastic or ceramic brackets that are worn by one million new dental patients each year.

LEAD: Martin T. Sosnoff, the New York investor, urged shareholders of Caesars World Inc. to support his proposal to remove four of the gaming company's inside directors from its nine-member board. LEAD: MARKETS Interest rates fell modestly as the Treasury sold $10 billion of three-year notes, the first of three auctions this week. After the sale, prices of notes and bonds rose modestly. Experts said that trading was affected by attractive yields and rumors of heavy Japanese participation. The firming of the market and the decline in rates prodded stock prices upward.

LEAD: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence until last February, whose role in the Iran-contra affair is under scrutiny in Congress, died of pneumonia yesterday in Glen Cove Community Hospital on Long Island. He was 74 years old. Mr. Casey died less than 24 hours after the first witness in Congressional hearings on the affair named him as having assisted in providing arms to Nicaraguan rebels after Congress forbade such support.

LEAD: The American flag flying in the position known to be a signal of distress over the Senate wing of the Capitol yesterday morning. Spectators waiting in line to attend the hearings on the Iran-contra affair noticed the inverted flag and pointed it out to Capitol police. Minutes later, the flag descended the pole and reappeared right side up.
LEAD: Gary Hart will announce his withdrawal from the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination at a news conference in Denver today, his friends and campaign associates said yesterday.

LEAD: A lawyer for former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan concluded his defense yesterday by charging that a Bronx prosecutor had created a false criminal case against Mr. Donovan for publicity purposes.

LEAD: The United States Embassy, in its most extensive travel advisory since Corazon Aquino became President, urged Americans today to avoid large areas of the Philippines because of ''relatively high levels of unrest.''

LEAD: If there were any wisps of doubt about the Reagan Administration's involvement in arming the Nicaraguan contras, the first few days of Congressional hearings have blown them away. Ambassadors, C.I.A. agents and lawyers, Director William Casey and numerous White House staff members played vital parts in the covert operation.

LEAD: MARKETS A surge of Japanese orders lifted bond prices and created hopes that the trend toward higher interest rates had been thwarted for now. Al Carmines served as a minister at the Judson Memorial Church on Washington Square, he wrote a series of provocative and award-winning Off Broadway musicals, including ''Peace,'' ''Promenade,'' ''The Gorilla Queen,'' ''Home Movies'' and ''In Circles,'' which has lyrics by Gertrude Stein.
LEAD: Europeans are having extra tongue exercise clucking at peculiar American habits, especially the way the U.S. treats Presidents and Presidential candidates.
LEAD: Contra Leaders Reorganize

LEAD: ''EDUCATING RITA'' is a Pygmalion play with a slight ''Equus'' twist. A teacher educates - and elevates - a vulgar, waif-like student and, to his dismay, the student sheds her distinctive coloration and eagerly embraces conformity. This is, of course, taking ''Educating Rita'' too seriously. At its heart, the Willy Russell two-hander is a comedy about an odd couple who have nothing in common except for the fact that they are the only characters on stage.

LEAD: An article on Wednesday about Irving Berlin on the eve of his 99th birthday misstated the history of his musical ''Mr. President.'' The show did open on Broadway, at the St. James Theater, on Oct. 20, 1962, and ran for 265 performances.

LEAD: Emile Francis, who has seen the Hartford Whalers move from last place to fourth place in the overall National Hockey League standing in his four seasons as president and general manager, has signed a five-year contract to continue in those posts. ''We'll continue to do what we're doing and hopefully do it a little harder,'' said Francis, who engineered a series of trades and draft choices that has left just two players from the roster of the team he took over in May 1983.

LEAD: At 12:59 yesterday afternoon, one minute before the Treasury Department was set to sell $9.25 billion in 30-year bonds, activity on much of the vast trading floor at Salomon Brothers came to a standstill.

LEAD: AIDS was unknown in 1979 when Representative Stewart B. McKinney, the Connecticut Republican who died of an infection brought on by the ailment, received several transfusions during coronary bypass surgery.
LEAD: The ability to set a record at sea is an arduous task by any standard. But Philippe Jeantot, the French solo sailor, has proved that he can do it more than once.

LEAD: The Afghan Government brought foreign journalists to this embattled eastern border area today to see the wreckage of a transport plane said to be carrying women, children and other civilians when it was downed by an American-made rocket last February.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Five young instrumentalists have been awarded Avery Fisher Career Grants for 1987, the Avery Fisher Artist Program has announced. Each recipient receives $10,000 to be used for career advancement.

LEAD: Biblical influences in works by Marc Chagall will be explored in an exhibition opening Sunday at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue and 92d Street. The exhibition, titled ''Chagall and the Bible,'' features more than 100 etchings done in the 1930's and 50's; the pieces depict images of biblical stories interwoven with memories from the artist's childhood and journeys.

LEAD: Martin A. Siegel, the former investment banker who pleaded guilty to insider-trading charges in February, secretly tape-recorded telephone conversations in January, according to transcripts provided yesterday by the United States Attorney's office to defense attorneys in the insider-trading case.

LEAD: The European Court of Justice rejected today an appeal by five Japanese companies against anti-dumping duties imposed by the European Community. The decision came at a time of worsening trade relations between Japan and the 12-nation trade bloc.

LEAD: Ron Darling, the Mets' pitcher, with children at Intermediate School 70 on West 17th Street. Mr. Darling, Governor Cuomo and the Yankees' Dave Righetti were there to kick off a drug-prevention campaign at the school. While there they taped a series of public service announcements. The pitchers, campaign co-chairmen, will be visiting schools around the state.

LEAD: Car driven by Danny Ongais breaking apart after slamming into wall near the fourth turn during practice at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. Ongais suffered a concussion and was hospitalized. (AP)
LEAD: Major women's organizations rallied today behind legislation that would require employers to grant up to 18 weeks of unpaid leave to workers to take care of newborn or seriously ill children.

LEAD: Professionals from the worlds of dance, music, theater, literature and art will take part in a career seminar for young artists from 1:30 to 4:30 P.M. tomorrow in the main building at New York University, 100 Washington Square East, at Waverly Place. Among those on hand to discuss how to break into the arts will be Senta Driver, the dancer; Toby Olson, a poet, and Ross Bleckner, a painter.

LEAD: GOLF Norman, Stewart Lead: Greg Norman, a playoff loser in the Masters, sank a short eagle putt at the seventh hole yesterday for a 64 to tie Payne Stewart for the first-round lead in the $600,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic in Irving, Tex. Gary Hallberg, Fred Couples, and Gary Krueger each had five-under 65's over the 6,767-yard course.

LEAD: The issue that seems to have doomed Gary Hart's quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, that of marital fidelity, appears to be considerably less important to Americans in their voting choices than other lapses of personal conduct, such as cheating on income taxes, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.
LEAD: Putting on a brave show in the face of tough economic times, Houston is preparing to raise the curtain this weekend in a new opera and ballet house, the first in this country in 16 years.

LEAD: The Washington Post reported today that Gary Hart decided to withdraw from the Presidential campaign hours after the newspaper presented a top campaign official with ''documented evidence of a recent liaison between Hart and a Washington woman.''

LEAD: An Army investigator has recommended a court-martial for a private charged with assault for having sexual relations with three people when he knew that a blood test showed him to be infected with the AIDS virus.

LEAD: The 40th Cannes Film Festival opened today with ceremonies dedicated to film directors and special tributes to Ingmar Bergman of Sweden, Bernardo Bertolucci of Italy and Richard Brooks of the United States.

LEAD: Watch out, America. Mark Gastineau is back, slimmer than ever, perhaps as fast, probably not as strong. And he will be bicycling across the country, Los Angeles to New York, 3,000 miles in 20 days because . . . well, because he's Mark Gastineau of the New York Jets.

LEAD: President Kurt Waldheim of Austria announced today that he had authorized the Vienna state prosecutor to file suit against Edgar M. Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress, for slander.
LEAD: The Bemis Company, a 130-year-old packaging concern based in Minneapolis, announced changes in its top lineup yesterday in what it called an orderly management transition.

LEAD: Larry Kucharz, a film maker and composer, is presenting several of his new works at 8 tonight at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation, 224 Centre Street (212-349-1980). Admission is $3.

LEAD: Canada's first $1 piece, a gold-colored coin with 11 sides, was struck today at the Royal Canadian Mint in Winnipeg. The coin will enter circulation in July and eventually replace the dollar bill.

LEAD: The Sony Corporation of America said today that it had completed a long-term agreement to supply Capital Cities/ABC Inc. and its owned and operated television stations with Betacam half-inch professional video production equipment.

LEAD: Gould Inc., a computer maker based in Rolling Meadows, Ill., said it had agreed to sell its microwave products division to Litton Industries, based in Beverly Hills, Calif. The division, which employs about 300 people, makes gallium arsenide semiconductor products as well as microwave amplifiers and subsystems, primarily for military applications.

LEAD: Representative Harold E. Ford, Democrat of Tennessee, was released from the Washington Hospital Center today after being treated for an adverse reaction to antibiotics, his office said. He was admitted to the hospital Thursday after complaining of severe chest pains. Mr. Ford is currently under indictment in Tennessee on Federal fraud charges, which he has denied.

LEAD: The Veterans Administration said today that it was raising its maximum interest rate for federally backed V.A. home mortgages to 10 percent, the second increase in less than a month.

LEAD: The Sione Nomine Singers, under the direction of Harry Saltzman, will perform music of Orlando di Lasso, the Renaissance composer, at 9 P.M. today at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street (362-8719). Admission is $10.

LEAD: A Soviet magazine published an article this week warning that efforts to introduce elements of a free market into the Soviet Union's planned economy were bound to fail and saying the country would have to chose between complete economic freedom and central control.
